New World is nearly everything someone would want in an MMO. It has a huge open world, stunning graphics, and incredible combat. There are many pro's to the game, but with pro's always comes a few con's. That is what I would like to talk about. Although at the moment I only have 17 hours on the game, I do not intend on stopping anytime soon and this is just what I've seen so far. I am planning on updating this as I progress farther in the game.

Pros: 
- Combat ; Silky smooth, great animations, doesn't get boring
- Graphics ; Beautiful. Words cannot describe how amazing the graphics are. Even on low graphics it feels like Ultra High 4k. 
- Resource Gathering ; Although some people do not like the gathering aspect of new world, I am quite fond of it. Its relaxing, enjoyable. On the flip side, it is extremely grindy.
- Open World ; New World is a massive open world. Different biomes, different monsters. The levels scale in each biome as well. 
- Crafting ; Something that you can do in New World is craft items, resources, weapons, almost anything. It makes gathering worth it. 
- Mobs ; The mobs are extremely diverse and the level's range. Each mob is different to its biomes with certain perks when skinning or fighting. 
- PvP & PvE ; PvE is New World's main focus. As I stated previously, the combat in this game is amazing and never seems to get boring. PvP is also great with a player being able to flag themselves for PvP when joining a faction.

Cons:
- Server Lag ; Server lag is a very big issue in my opinion. I can't seem to get below 70 to 80 ping whilst my ping sometimes skyrockets to 500 or more for an extended amount of time. I usually get good connection with the games I play. The Server lag makes it hard to enjoy the game sometimes. This is the biggest issue in my opinion. 
- Walking ; There is a lot of running in New World. Sometimes you spend more time running to do the quest, than actually doing it. Although there is fast travel, you can only fast travel so much and to a certain area. 
- Resource Gathering ; One of if not the most grindy thing in New World. You will spend hours upon hours mining or chopping down trees just to level up that skill a tiny bit. 
- Economy ; The economy is run by the players. Although the prices can seem a bit unfair, this issue is by far not to big of an issue seeing how it is cool to see the prices change for different items as the game progresses. 
- Questing ; Quests are extremely repetitive. It goes somewhat like, "Run here. Kill these. Talk to this person. Collect this." And you have to do that a lot. 

Overall, New World is an 8/10 game with a great focus on exploration, gathering, and combat. 

That is all I have so far. As stated previously I do plan on updating this list as time goes on. If you are looking to buy New World. I highly recommend it. As the game progresses it is sure to get better and better. I do believe it is worth $40 but I recommend buying it on sale as sometimes it can feel like a $20 game. Thank you for reading my review and have a great day.

2024 review of New World
I didnt expect much from the game, since the game was know to have some issues and the player count and stuff wasnt rly big anymore, but on sail I still want to try it! Now is the time to give and review and sadly prob also the last time I played this game, because I dont want to keep playing much anymore at this point ...
Heres a short summary of what I like and what I dislike about the game:

What I like:
+++ The game is very newbiw friendly, getting to know things and learning new stuff is very easy, I didnt have to google or watch a guide or anything the whole time while playing New World!
+++Graphic and soroundings look rly good I think, its also open world and you can pretty much go whereever u want
++ Like above, u can go explore however u want and find a lot of interesting spots I think, even tho some obviously repeat themselves in each region (like caves and stuff for example)
++ I rly like the crafting, this is what keept me playing in the first place, you can gather almost everything u see in this game and in the meanwhile level up you geathering skills
++ with this comes a great crafting system which allows you to craft armor/weapons and all combat related stuff u want and could need in leveling, which feels pretty good
++ the system releated to gathering and crafting is pretty cool, you level its but crafting/agthering more which then increases the stuff you can gather/craft, which I really liked!
+ The first dungeons I did seemed pretty good, also not to easy but challenging enough which gives hope for later dungeons

What I dislike and why I will stop playing:
--- This game is a running simulator. Whereever I go, I need to run over the whole map. The shrines, where you can port from shrine to shrine are so far form each other, you have to endlessly run and run and run, which is imo the biggest flaw of this game, it got me so enoyed because im gathering so much but im actually running 80% of the time and the rest I actally collect stuff ,very dreadful!!! 
---> this is also why you should buy the dlc, because then you can use mounts, maybe this improves the game but why would they make a system like that, that you have to pay MORE to just get a mount in the first palce??? I dont get it
- After coming from other MMOs like lost Ark or Eso or basicly any other MMO, I think the combat is not that good. You only have 3 skills per weapon (you have a total of 2 weapons) and it just doesnt seem like any skill is involved. You press your 3 skills, swap weapon, do your 3 skills, do 1-2 heavy/light attacks and then repeat. I tink the only skill that New World has is dodging at the right time, so u dont get staggered and dotn take dmg. I just think its not a great system and it doesnt rly feel good, you are imo def not playing New World for the combat ^^
- Gathering levels your skill lvl - Why is this a problem? Well once you gather, you gain pretty good exp, which then makes you overlevel for the sotry main quest, which you should do, which makes it even more boring, which is also not a good system imo

What they could fix imo to make the game a LOT better:
1: Give all players mounts, I dont care at all if dlc get cooler mounts and for example mounts that are twice as fast and none dlc placers, but pls give ppl the ability to move faster over the map. Im mindblowing that this isnt in the game already and even the dlc isnt out for that long I think ... I would rly love to know the reason for that!
2 and follow up to 1: If you dont do that, double or even tripple the amout of shrines over the WHOLE New World map, just do so much more shrines so you can port faster 
3: AND also just make ppl port to any shrine for Azoth, why only from shrine to shrine?? Its just enoying and a bad system imo ...
4: Make gathering an different system so you dont get level exp from that, but exp for itself with some cool rewards maybe, like maybe an Axe Skin for chopping a lot or something? Thats just a quick idea, give some nice rewards for that. Prob some ppl dont agree with it and they like to get exp from gathering, but I think its not good to mix that with questing and stuff, I think that should be sperate 
5. Make Gatherables respawn faster, expec ores, they are always on cooldown and its also rly anoying when you go to a spot, nothing is there and then you walk to the next spot and there is nothing there 2 ... Its painnnnn
6. Maybe better combat with +1 skill for each weapon, that just would be my preference but ya, I def think combat could get better somehow

Sadly there is some stuff I didnt experience yet like endgame, from wwhat I heard its dungeons and pvp, which I also dont know if it is a good idea to make pvp a main source for endgame because not everyone likes pvp, but ya, this was MY OPPINION on New World in 2024!!! 

If you read this much, ty and take care <3

REVIEW POSTED AT 1556 HOURS IN GAME.

as someone who has played this game for a very long time and hoped the devs would continue to support its casual community and its die hard community, it saddens me to say that i no longer recommend this game because of these reasons.

1. time commitment.      the time you need to commit to this game to get to its current player base level is absurd. even after 1500 hours i still have things to collect and work on. the commitment ive had to this game over the years has taken me away from other games because of the time requirements. it felt like working on a battle pass in another game with such a time and resource sink that the game becomes the only thing you play.

2.  the resource sink.      the resources required to gather in game are absolutly absurd to get to the point as to where you can upgrade your artifacts, i understand they are the penultimate item of a build however if it takes most of the player base over a week to upgrade one item. then id consider that grind worse than warframe for the reason that each upgrade could be meaningless in a few days due to bugs and glitches in the game. not to mention if you wanted to get your usually 3 perk armor set up to max level and get back to running mutations again you need to not only spend the 3 cromatic seals to upgrade them (5k gold each) but you need the proper matrix and the other items to upgrade. this in my eyes is killing the casual community. 

3.  real world money.  the game at base is $40 from when i purchased it the new dlc is $30. round about a total of $70 doesnt sound bad being now a days prices on games for the ammount of content you get in the base game $40 is really good however to get up to the current player base's level you need to get the dlc which in my opinion adds 1/5th of the content that the base game comes with only to give you a slight bump in power and the ability to go back into the old content to try to earn something of value out of it. I.E. artifacts

4.   the community.  in the current state of the game on my server two of the three factions absolutely dominate the pvp and pve. being the one faction that is not one of the ruling ones sucks because its impossible to do almost anything open world because the nodes, named enemies, and loot spawn locations are always picked over and over farmed upon your arrival. this major imbalence in the factions has made the game impossible to get a community together in the first place unless your already going into one of the dominant factions then your going to have a misserable time doing almost anything in the game.


at the time of posting this review i can not recommend you get this game.

It's pretty fun so far.  Stats are also very simple, only being for damage and Con for HP. Many weapon damage stats cross over, so you can use a Fire Staff and a Shotgun. Or a Bow and a Spear. Without sacrificing damage. You get the idea. The main draw is smashing together 2 different weapons, juggling weapons so you never really get bored. Then choosing 1 of the 3 armor types changes the gameplay even more.

You can even put Elemental Gems into weapons that scales off Intelligence at a weaker but viable scale than using the proper main stat. So you wanna be a Fire Mage with a Hammer? Go for it. Bow and Ice Mage? Yep. So the main draw of making weapon combos is even bigger than you think! 

Unless you're a Healer. There's only 1 main healing weapon, the Life Staff. And 1 free off-healing weapon, Void Gauntlet. You have to buy the DLC to get the 2nd off-healing weapon, Flails. So despite being a very important end game class - and lacking in population compared to DPS - they don't really get to join in the weapon juggling fun. On the plus side those 2 off-healing weapons are pretty OK damage dealers and fun, but again, being stuck in a playpen with 2 toys isn't fun when everyone else is running free in a land of infinite toys.

Honestly, game is hot garbage. That being said, I know I have over 400hrs in game so before the knockers try to attack me for that, the only reason I put so much time into is because a friend of mine was foolish enough to buy me the DLC for Christmas. I wish he'd bought me a pair of socks. At least the socks would've been useful.
The combat is absolutely woeful, you still get hit, even if you dodge because the animation has already plotted it's going to hit you. I can not tell you the amount of arrows or leap attacks I've watched back where the arrow or attack will turn 45 degrees with your dodge just so it can hit you. If you utilise a combat skill, you can't break the animation to dodge if you see an attack coming during the utilisation of said skill. There is no escaping it. You just have to hope you can take the hit & keep going, simple as that.
Speaking of dodge! It lacks in stamina, sure, you can get it up to 3 dodges with the right perks but if you use it all up you then need to wait for it to fully recharge before being able to utilise it again, not part way, not half way but fully recharge.
Now I'll move onto what I think is the biggest farce in the whole game, the parkour. The parkour is the most tragic parkour of any game I have ever played (& I'm old, so I've played a hell of a lot of games) For a game so heavily dependant on parkour it is really pathetically implemented.
The other big disappointment is the elite chests. Very underwhelming in their allocation of loot. From my experience (even with a high luck gear set) 90-95% of what you get from looting the elite chests is absolute trash also. You'll spend a lot of time deconstructing the trash to see if you actually found any gems. I've run innumerable ECR runs & very rarely get anything worthwhile from them. What do I do with a common chestpiece with a gear score of 700, I mean come on, be realistic. Why are we getting common items in high tier/elite areas.
All in all, the game looks great. The game plays like trash. The biggest positive this game has is the community. Great community in a poorly made game.

-- THE QUEST HAS BEEN FIXED!! --

Three months prior to my posting this, a gamebreaking glitch has not been patched; predominantly effecting returning players. The glitch in question occurs around level 45+ MAIN STORY QUESTS, causing your main story quest to disappear with no ability to be picked up further. This means the Azoth staff T3 (Needed to complete overworld events) as well as countless XP and Item rewards/gold are inaccessible, and have been, for over three months. 

This is a level of unprofessionalism in MMO's that is considered game-ending. There is no mention of this error, nor any hotfix for it. Please consider this before purchasing the game, or it's DLC -- as it's NON-REFUNDABLE -- yet, I am fairly certain it doesn't count as a finished product currently, if the game itself cannot be played according to it's design..

If/when the issue is resolved, I'll change my review. I have many reasons to enjoy and appreciate the game; but I cannot abide by negligible development at the expense of consumers.

I'm redoing this review:

1-Game looks good.
2-Running animation feels awkward.  I feel like the animation goes at 100 mph while my character moves like a snail.
3-They added mounts, but the ability to get one is behind a pay wall.  You have to buy the first expansion for $30 to get one.  The mount is barely faster than the run speed unmounted.  It gets better over time, but I'm not sure how long it takes.  Cooler mounts such as lions or wolves can't be obtained until you're a minimum level.
4-The price tag for the expansion is a bit much honestly.  They didn't add much.  if they plan to continue to charge $30 for one new zone, then I won't be inclined to buy them.  Everything I've read about the new expansion, other than the mount, says it sucks.
5-The addition of the ability to collect sheet music and play the guitar, mandolin, drums and upright bass is awesome.  I REALLY like this.  It's my favorite part of the game.  You can even play with other people.  The buffs you can get such as the ability to carry 100 more weight for 2 hours from the music is a nice touch.  There are other buffs as well.

The PvE is decent.  I will never PvP in this game.  I have yet to do any sort of group dungeon.  I do see complaints here and there about not being able to get a group for the first one.

Leveling up harvesting and crafting skills seems stupid easy so far.

I wish I could give this game a neutral recommendation, but since I can't, overall I'd say it's barely a thumbs up.

NW - perspective of player with 35y exp in gaming.

Pros:
*You can look like Cpt. Jack Sparrow.

*Very nice nature locations, diverse, climatic.

*Encountered lag only twice and only for a moment. No crashes either while GFX drivers were up to date.

*Very good music (feels like inspirated by the feel of L2 music). And cool ability to play own music, even together.

*Combat system isn't bad, requires skill and some planning. Almost free respecs make choices unimportant since you can change them anytime.

*No P2W. Having to pay extra to get from lvl 60-65 and get a mount is actually better to pay full price in the start.

*Quite nice armors and weapons - everyone will find something to feel good in.
Dungeons (expeditions) are fun at 1st run, especially if the party is understrength.

*Quite big population, game feels alive (but seeing devs merging servers = playerbase is in decline).

Negatives:
*Faction concept (3 factions fighting endless war without a reason or perspective of winning) is STUPID. Lineage2 system was way better since it based only on guilds so it was more entertaining and realistic.

*Quests (both mandatory and optional) are TOTALLY STUPID. Made it to lvl 65 without reading ANYTHING and skipping ALL cutscenes. Just typical go to point A, then collect 8 items, then go to other NPC and so on.

*Most players "speedrun" everything. Man - it shall be fun to lurk in dungeons and feel the thrill! Speedrunning is like work, but actually you're only loosing time for nothing.

*Been on few "sieges" on Nysa server, Marauder faction. Haven't seen not a SINGLE PIECE of organisation, planning or communication in battle. Just running back and forth in groups. Yikes. Good for 6 year olds. 

*Cities are planned STUPIDLY without any logic. Without memorizing locations you will run searching all the time.

*Housing is useless since houses are shared with other ppl and nobody can see other's house. Their only purpose is to extend storage and give some buff.

*Castles are nonexistent, you got only forts - all similar to themselves.

*UI is mostly ok, but could need some improvements.

*Game throws useless armors/weapons at you all the time.

*If you find out you've landed on a server full of Turks - no way to change it wisely, because you might end up on russian populated server and need to wait 180 days.

*Game is like they ripped off something from every major MMO out there and put it in the Pirate/magical/barbarian/chivalry wonderland.

So if you're looking for a game to immerse yourself for years and do something interesting and satisfactory - this is not the right game. At least for an old warrior.

I'm one of those lunatics who jumped into New World right from the get-go, fueled by excitement and a truckload of optimism. Once I battled through the queues – and believe me, it was a battle – I'm in this MMORPG wonderland, having the time of my life. Server launch? It was like a chaotic, digital carnival. People everywhere, desperate for some gaming kicks. Now, don't get me wrong, contrary to the buzzkill brigade, I was actually enjoying the leveling process. But let's face it, I'm the kind of bloke who grinds away in every game, so take my enthusiasm with a healthy dose of skepticism, yeah? :D

Cut to a few weeks later, and like many others, I waved the white flag. Bugs and exploits were raining down like a plague, and those duping escapades were the final nail in the coffin. I didn't sign up for a game where the market felt like a done deal.

Now, fast forward to a week ago, a mate of mine resurrects his New World odyssey and somehow convinces me to join the madness again. And would you believe it, I'm genuinely gobsmacked – in a good way! The servers got a facelift with a merge, packed to the digital rafters with players on the one we landed in (we can still hop around if we fancy, like game-hopping nomads). They're buzzing with activity! They've flipped the script on all the negatives in a way that I'm absolutely chuffed about. Most crucially, no more crafting keys for dungeon entry! (Or expeditions, if you want to be all official about it.) And guess what? All storages are accessible from every town, so no more absurd journeys lugging around your digital loot. Thank the gaming gods!

If you were vibing with the game at launch and had a soft spot for PvP, I'm giving you a big, fat recommendation to dive back in. You might just be as pleasantly surprised as I am. Cheers to that, my digital compadres!

Now, let's not sprinkle fairy dust on everything. There's still a bit of a downer – the developers seem to be moving at a pace slower than a sloth in a yoga class when it comes to improvements and new content. Sure, there are bugs, but from what I've bumped into, nothing that'll ruin your gaming day. Workarounds are the name of the game. All in all, though, the game's in a way better state than its debut, and credit where it's due.

This game is a wild ride, and it's got some pretty cool stuff going on.

First things first, Aeternum, the world they've cooked up, is seriously impressive. Massive landscapes, beautiful scenery – it's a virtual playground. I found myself getting lost in the details, like how the weather changes and the sun sets. It's like stepping into a fantasy nature documentary.

Creating your character is a breeze, and there's plenty of room for personalization. As you go along, you'll run into different factions, each with their own stories. It adds a nice touch of drama and makes your journey feel like it's yours.

Combat is a big highlight. It's not your run-of-the-mill MMO click-fest. It's real-time, action-packed, and feels like you're actually doing something. There's a bunch of weapons and skills to play around with, so you can fight your way.

Crafting is a big deal here too. The crafting system has some depth to it, which I appreciate. Whether you're into forging weapons or mixing up potions, there's something for everyone.

What really grabbed me is the whole territory control thing. Player-run companies battling for regions? That's a game-changer. It brings a whole new level of drama to the world, and your actions actually matter. It's not just about you; it's about the community.

Now, let's keep it real – New World isn't flawless. There have been a few server hiccups and balancing issues, but the devs are on it. It's clear they're listening to the players, which is a good sign.

To sum it up, New World is a big, wild adventure. It's got the looks, the action, and this living, breathing world that's ready for exploration. Whether you're rolling solo or looking for a group, New World is carving out its place in the MMO scene, and it's worth checking out. I'm curious to see where this journey takes us as the game keeps growing.

Very fun game. Never really gave an MMORPG a shot, but since this was on sale and a one-time purchase, I went for it.

Exploring is pretty fun, I like the parkour segments. The world is easily the best part of the game (makes sense lol), so many of the environments, especially late-game, are stunning. Sometimes I just ride along the road looking around and listening to the OST. The expeditions are really cool from those I've done. They pose a decent challenge, especially with difficulty mutations, and running them with friends is a blast.

PvP is pretty fun, but usually conflicts are very one-sided. Not to say there aren't some close ones, I've had some really fun back-and-forth moments, especially in influence races (PvP events where factions can fight over territory).

Definitely worth picking up on a sale. Also worth grabbing if you just want a solid game with a vast world to explore.

New World presents a visually stunning and expansive world that beckons players into a promising MMO experience. I've found myself sinking more hours than I'd care to admit into the game, captivated by its intricate crafting systems, dynamic combat, and the allure of a player-driven economy. However, despite the substantial time invested, New World seems to struggle in finding its place within the MMO genre.

The game boasts a beautifully realized open world, teeming with both dangers and opportunities for exploration. The combat system is visceral and engaging, offering a refreshing departure from traditional MMO mechanics. Yet, it's in the broader aspects of the MMO experience where New World falls short. The endgame content feels somewhat lacking, and the progression system could use further refinement to keep players engaged in the long run.

While New World introduces intriguing concepts, it appears to grapple with establishing a distinct identity within the competitive MMO landscape. The constant updates and adjustments from the developers demonstrate a commitment to improvement, and the potential for greatness is evident. Despite its current shortcomings, New World is a title that holds promise, and I remain hopeful that future updates will elevate it to new heights within the MMO genre.

The gameplay is good, there's a storyline or 3 or 5 or something if you're into that stuff. I hit lv 60 after about 58 hours of gameplay and lv 65 not long after and there's plenty of things to level up between combat and crafting systems. Resources are shared so high population servers are competitive for resource locations but you can buy it in the trading post too. Low population servers take a bit longer to find enough people for expeditions and raids etc. For $40 its definitely worth it especially if you like grindy games. Lots of number go up. The $30 DLC is a bit pricey for what it offers especially since it almost feels necessary to be relevant since it increases the max level and therefore offers better gear. All in all, would recommend, has its pros and cons, like needing friends but otherwise has been fun.

They also increased the EXP gains for the MSQ - so it's much easier to reach end game content.

I was excited to hear they dropped the open pvp part of the game, as it initially looked interesting. But since the closed beta, and through the open beta, they have made it clear they are not interested in fixing the bugs in the game, despite delaying the game, and taking an extra month to do something.
Something so basic as [attempting to] display uninitialized variables in a production release speaks volumes about their [lack of] QA.
Data issues usually speak to profound underlying problems in the code, bad exception handling practices, and generally sloppy development practices. 
I haven't really run afoul of the queuing issues plaguing launch, as I usually log in early, but if I log in during the afternoon it is a no go.
I will hang on to the game, and check in later, but I certainly would not recommend it to others at this time.
...
Weeks later, still they have data issues with game, unable to load their own static data reliably, much less player data. I'll give it 'till the next patch.
---
I'm going to go ahead and flip to thumbs up, I gave it a couple of years and it's way more fun, but many of the same issues with QA and inability to deal with static data remain. 
---

Okay, I gave this game a really good chance over a long period of time but it is just boring and utterly pay-to-win when it comes to the PVP side of things. 

The new artifacts are a complete joke, allowing players to become almost invulnerable to many forms of damage. This means the long term players and people with deep pockets regularly crush newer ones, ruining the experience and any sabotaging any chance of a community.

As far as it being a deep MMO, as alleged in many of their promos, there is almost nothing social about playing the game. The only real "social" aspect is joining a company to gang-bang newbies or joining a group "raid" when 20-100 players follow the leader through strongholds to grab as much loot as possible.

The latest expansions are almost souls-like with their punishing bosses, unless you happen upon their weakness in which case you can almost phone it in, e.g. Mordred can be dispatched in about a minute with a rapier by simply standing next to him, constantly flurring and side-stepping when he tries to attack. 
Whoever does the balancing and testing on this game should be hung, drawn and quartered.

Avoid this like the plague.

Rating: ★★★★☆

New World, Amazon Game Studios' ambitious foray into the MMORPG genre, has finally arrived on Steam, and it brings with it a refreshing take on the genre with its blend of stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, and a unique setting.

Visually, New World is a feast for the eyes. The Aeternum, the mysterious and beautiful land in which the game is set, is meticulously crafted with lush landscapes, diverse biomes, and a vibrant color palette. The attention to detail in both character design and environmental elements is commendable, creating a world that feels both fantastical and immersive.

The gameplay in New World centers around exploration, crafting, and dynamic player-driven events. The open-world design encourages players to venture into the unknown, uncovering hidden treasures and facing off against formidable foes. The combat system is action-oriented, requiring skillful dodges, precise attacks, and strategic use of weaponry. It successfully blends traditional MMO mechanics with more action-oriented elements, providing a satisfying experience for players of various preferences.

Crafting and gathering play a crucial role in New World, offering a robust economy within the game. The resource-rich environment and intricate crafting system make every gathering expedition feel meaningful, as players contribute to the in-game economy and enhance their own capabilities.

One of New World's standout features is its player-driven events and faction-based conflicts. Wars over territories bring a real sense of community and competition, allowing players to engage in large-scale battles for control and influence. The sense of agency in shaping the game world is a refreshing departure from more linear MMORPG experiences.

However, it's not all sunshine and rainbows in Aeternum. While the game has made significant strides since its beta phase, some players may encounter minor bugs and optimization issues. It's clear that the development team is actively addressing these concerns, but they are worth noting for a smoother overall experience.

In conclusion, New World is a welcome addition to the MMORPG genre, offering a visually stunning world, engaging gameplay mechanics, and a player-driven narrative. While it has a few rough edges, the potential for growth and improvement is evident. Whether you're a seasoned MMO veteran or a newcomer to the genre, New World is a captivating journey into the unknown that's well worth the investment.

One of the few MMO's that don't require a subscription. Granted recently they came out with a paid DLC that was alright. It added mounts to the game but the DLC was pricey. It did increase the level cap from 60 to 65 which is a good thing. They added a lot more stuff to the game dealing with armor, reworking gear score (light level for the destiny players) and minor things across the game.

- PVE 5/5 (Very fun and fluid)
- PVP 2/5 (Not that rewarding and is a grind to build good gear)
- Crafting 3.5/5 (It's alright in the beginning and then gets too grindy)
- Map 5/5 (Diverse map and biomes)
- Raids 4/5 (Cool boss fights)
- Events 4/5 (Thanksgiving, Christmas)

For someone that enjoys playing a lot of MMO's, I hated the purpose of a subscription based game because how limited I am with time and don't have all day to play games. I might have 5-6 hours a week to play a game and I don't want my money going to waste on a subscription game that I can't play. 

With New World, you just buy the game and you own it, that's it.

It's very fun to play with friends and it's easy to find a group and some friends on this game to party up and do raids (expeditions), quest, or even just level up your trade skills (woodcutting, mining, etc).

If you're afraid to get this game because of its price, wait for it to go on sale and then purchase it. The DLC will make traversing around the map more fun and easier but you don't need the DLC during the first 25-30 levels of the game.

/*---------------------------------------------------
EDIT: Played another ~200 hours. Some updates:
---------------------------------------------------*/
- Mount system is ok. All the decent-looking ones are locked behind a paywall (no surprise there)
- Transmog is SHAMELESSLY locked behind a paywall.
- There's a lot of storyline content to catch up on if you're brand new so you'll probably get your money's worth as an RPG. I HOPE YOU LIKE CHOPPING DOWN TREES.
- The weapon/skill system is kinda meh. There are a couple of cookie-cutter builds that are the only viable options for activity x.
- Trying to get into a (I HOPE YOU LIKE CHOPPING DOWN TREES) decent company that isn't just you and your cousin Phil (who will not shut up about lizards) is nigh impossible unless you're on the cutting edge of the PvE scene. Did I mention that to get into groups you need to have done the thing before? One of those catch-22 situations where you need experience to get groups and you need groups to get experience. I HOPE YOU LIKE CHOPPING DOWN TREES. Good luck to you finding a company that'll take on a new person unless it's one of those spam recruiters.
- Did you accidentally turn on PvP at lvl 54? Lol get wrecked noob. Enjoy getting ganked for the next 30 minutes while you try to complete your quest.
- End-game content is very repetitive and grindy. (compared to GW2 / WoW) You will spam the same dungeon over and over and over and over and over and over. There are like five of them.
- The proxy voice-chat is great for people spamming their Donald Trump soundboard or Carameldansen in every major town.
- I
- HOPE
- YOU
- LIKE
- CHOPPING
- DOWN
- F^&($#*
- TREES
- Still pretty (visuals and audio still gorgeous) and some of the collision bugs have been fixed.
- I'm trying to think of a single positive experience I had (apart from the novelty of unlocking new things, new weapons, new skills, buying and decorating your house) but once you're done with the story, it becomes SERIOUSLY repetitive and boring. (This coming from someone who has been playing WoW since 2006.)

In, summary, I hope you like chopping down trees.
Okay, real summary: 
 - Recommended as an RPG (or Exotic Lumberjack Simulator), but not as an MMORPG.
 - Is it worth the price? Sure.
 - Will you play it for more than a month? Probably not. But there's no sub fee, so you can come back any time, which is a plus.

/*----------------------------------------
    ORIGINAL REVIEW:
----------------------------------------*/
The only positive thing I can say about this game is that **visually** it's absolutely beautiful.
The art team did an AMAZING job here.

But the flesh and bones of this homunculus leave much to be desired;
it's made of a the collection of systems don't fit well together.
There are still plenty of things that you will not like if you come from other well-known MMO's:
1. inefficient quest pathing. You will often get random quests on the other side of the map requiring you to run across zones where the enemies are twice your level.
2. irregular and inexplicably sporadic spawn timers (e.g. you fight hard to clear out a difficult elite and his two friends that he summons from a cave and then respawns every time before you can even loot the chest or mine the ore he was guarding. He also brings his friends with every time. Hope you remembered to make a camp nearby so you don't have to run all the way back to your corpse from the nearest town.
So you will get ganked by randomly respawning mobs a lot when you're not getting ganked by other players.
3. weird/buggy player character behaviour especially with jumping and dodging.
4. buggy PvE enemy AI that frequently (gets stuck on rocks or can't find it's way around a tree)
5. Tradeskill grinding is tedious and excessive. I HOPE YOU LIKE CHOPPING DOWN TREES. Also, better hope the town you're in has a high enough level kitchen for you to make the food for that quest or you'll have to run aaaaaaaaaalll the way to another town that YOUR faction controls just to go make that one thing you need for a quest. No problems; you'll have plenty of time to chop down trees on your way there.
6. finding/joining a clan is difficult.
7. The bots and gold-sellers have already infiltrated the game. Soon the regional chat will look like Trade Chat (TM).
8. NO SPRINT. Seriously; you can't run any faster. There is one running speed and that's what you've got from level 1 to 60.
9. No Mounts.
10. Seriously, no mounts.
11. Did I mention there aren't any mounts?
12. Loot RNG is particularly frustrating. There doesn't seem to be any logic behind perk distribution, even for curated quest rewards.

If I only had three words to describe New World, they would be "FRUSTRATING", "BEAUTIFUL" and "TEDIOUS".

A metaphor that feels appropriate is it's like having a really hot girlfriend/boyfriend, but they're also a flat-earther and will remind you frequently of what their starsign says about everything.
They insist on making you wear colours whose names have the same number of letters as the numbers their psychic picked out for them.
Playing New World is like this relationship; there's something fun about it and it's kinda enjoyable at the start, but deep down you know there are systematic problems that will prevent you from sticking with it long-term.

Unless New World makes massive system overhauls, I will probably not be logging in too often.

Review after 4,000+ hours in the game

Pros:
* Best action combat there is
* Open world pvp is the best content
* One of the best Tradeskill system for MMOs (Fishing, Music, Mining etc etc)
* Satisfying crafting
* Great Audio design/quality
* Great level design for each environment/zones
* One of the best lighting
* Immersive world.
* VOIP
* Good dungeon designs. 
* Traversing / vaulting is one of the best in MMOs as well.
* Casual friendly
* Solo friendly
* Quarterly event - Seasonal contents
* Clean UI
* QOL - inventory management system, gear sets etc.
* Arena, OPR - PVP rewards
* PVE ranking rewards
* Clean Auction House/Trading hall UI
* Every weapon is viable. 

Cons:
* Feels clunky at times due to desync problems
* Server population problem (game feels dead when there's not enough people roaming the world)
* Static NPCs
* Housing not fully utilized
* Camp should be vulnerable/can be attacked when the owner is PVP flagged
* OPR is not fully utilized. 1 map for almost 3 years after release
* Arena is not fully utilized. No ranking/mmr system (1v1, 3v3, 5v5)
* World mobs is using 3 to 5 same move-set
* Re-skin mobs
* Open world dungeons/elite areas is not fully utilized
* Dungeons/expedition becomes bland after you cleared it twice. 
* Expedition bosses does not pose threats. Use 2 to 3 move set the whole fight
* Mutated mechanics is not fun (elemental hazard). Should have different move-set for mobs/bosses instead to every mutation level.
* The only in-game *raid Sand worm is not worth it (rewards is worthless). This content has so much potential.
* Bugs in every content patch
* No gear chase once you reach end game. everything is attainable solo. can craft, can hunt alone.
* Company / guild system lacks depth. There should be guild skills/bank/guild quarters/camp/guild auction.
* Influence pushes/race should be placed in open world forts / castles like the ones in monarch's bluff, everfall.
* Wars becomes bland. Fighting for a wooden fort after almost 3 years? where's the castles --- look at monarch's bluff open world castle. siege equipment should be brought back in the meta. What's the point of having them when the only useful thing are the horns. Bring the cannons, turrets back, add trebuchet etc. 
* Factions are limiting the PVP possibilities for companies. make it that you can fight companies in your own faction. new system that could enable governors to declare hostilities/war, to a company from your faction and other factions. This adds intensity on open world PVPs
* Character progression is lacking

* Summary
Overall, game is great. it just need more polish/add more system that makes MMOs enjoyable.
But AGS is taking so long to fix game bugs/issues, which I think the reason they are so slow releasing meaningful contents. 

PVP is also the one keeping this game alive. They should put time and effort on this. implement new things that could make open world pvp fun. improve the current systems specially influence races. place it on open world castles, POI with PVP quests that makes sense. Delivering siege materials, castle defenses, that will be used during wars.

- Faction Imbalance
- Casters classes are an after thought
- Story is half baked, developers took the super lazy route by leaving "notes" to read..... 
- Markets are busted
- No mounts
- Combat is limited to 3 skills on a hot bar
- The grind is real, expect to invest time and be required to group up.
- Limited end game content

Pros:
- Dungeons can be fun
- Crafting has potential
- Skill point trees are basic and to the point
- Environments are beautiful
- Lots of weapon combinations

best pvp MMO out there, always buy this game when its on sale -  cant miss. good grinds much like runescape if youre an OG that wants to max their woodcutting/mining/crafting. 20+ weapons to choose from, loads of raids in-world and dungeon types. 8/10, only problem for me is that the game can be a bit choppy on your GPU when in larger groups of 20+ but if you play at 60 capped, no issues.

after 3500 hours i would say the game has provided a lot  of great and fun times, its a great game but yes it has been a bumpy road for the devs and the game they have had some tough moments to say the least. i think they have fixed most of the major buggs for now.

would i recommend this game? 

simple answer-yes

longer answer- i would only recommend this game to player that either really enjoy lore, RNG crafting, gathering, PVP and players that aren't shy to join/communicate with others in game via joining a company/discord.

i would not recommend it to some one that is antisocial or just don't have a interest in joining up with other players and working together as the end game is rather hard to find a group as a solo (unless ur biss gear). The end game can also get stale quick without a good friend group/community to interact with and keep things interested. example- running the same dungeons over and over. I find the best part of the game for me is the PVP with friends.

As for the people saying its pay to win thats simply not true there's no real advantage to buying anything on their in game store skins do nothing but look pretty there are boosters you can get but its just xp boosters and since most the community was already maxed before they added them not really much of a pay to win. The only thing you could even say is pay to win about the game is the expansion which raises max level / gear-score lets you use artifact weapons and gives you a mount. that being said how is it any different from any other mmo that releases and expansion giving you access to higher level and better gear? some will say well the mounts should be free to everyone and yeah i could get behind that but still not needed there's tons of fast travel points in the game already. All i can say is they asked for another what 30 bucks after 2years and no monthly payments? not a bad deal tbh.

                      THE BIGGEST THING IF YOU WANT TO ENJOY NEW WORLD
                              PLAY WITH FRIENDS/INTERACT WITH COMMUNITY

When I first played New World's beta. I hated this game. Thought it was bare bones and lacked a lot of content. After about 2 years later I decided to give this game another try. So far I'm impressed and I'm liking the game. There are some issues here and there but it's a lot better compared to that awful beta they released. The world and it's atmosphere is fun and can be mesmerising at times. The combat is decent and fun, the only problem I have here is the weapon abilities can lack a little compared to other MMORPG's. Either way it's still pretty decent. There are some minor issues in terms of performance but nothing too major, at least for me. The quests can sometimes be repetitive but somehow still pulls you in to continue the grind. The crafting mechanics is good and gathering resources can actually be fun. If you were like me and didn't like New World during it's beta release, maybe think about giving it another try.

New World is currently a very good game. Too bad release was a flop and all the hardware issues made the game hated. From what I've seen, they have fixed a lot of the issues, and the game is very enjoyable.

This is kinda just an advanced version of Runescape. And I don't mean that as a bad thing. It is a fun game that will keep you engaged for a good while. Is it a replacement for something like WoW or FF14? No. But it is enjoyable and has no monthly fee. Worth the into cost for sure. The ability to level into whatever stat you want at each level, along with your choice of weapon combos makes for enough diversity to keep it interesting for sure. If you just want to play a game that is easy to get into and play for short sessions or long ones, this is a worthy try. 
Graphics are slightly dated: 7/10
Questing is simple and easy to follow with map markers, yet satisfying: 7.5/10
The story is interesting and easy enough to follow: 8/10
Combat is live with dodging, blocking, and aiming, but cool-downs are slow: 7/10
Crafting is a great way to get great items, but very grindy: 6/10
Stability of the servers is decent, with few errors, but not none: 6.5/10

Overall, an even 7/10. Its a solid and enjoyable game, but nothing revolutionary. If you can get it on sale at all, it is worth playing.

Year 2021, Amazon makes decision to target hoarders and torture them with their game called New World.
[i]"There's loot everywhere!"[/i] - whispers one hoarder to another.
- [b]I'm loving it![/b] - exclaims other one, while chopping trees outside of settlement. - [b]So much stuff to loot, and those resources that I'm gathering now on my baby character will be useful later on too, all of this is NEEDED.[/b]
- [u]Tell me, how far do you get from settlement, friend?[/u] - asks shadowy figure, that suddenly appeared from behind. Or maybe it wasn't that much of unforeseen thing to happen, after all, loot lover was distracted by chopping sounds. - [u]I am looking for someone to share in an adventure that I am arranging, and it's very difficult to find anyone.[/u]
- [b]I should think so-in these parts! We are plain quiet folk and have no use for adventures. Nasty disturbing uncomfortable things! Make you late for dinner, especially with all this stuff we have to carry around! I can't think what anybody sees in them. I personally never go further than twenty feet away from my place. Good morning! We don't want any adventures here, thank you![/b]

This game repeats some of the things that were done wrong by other MMOs before, such as: floating herbs and rocks; animals dying above the ground level, so you can't loot them; chat being spammed by goldsellers. But in no way it stops there! It goes above and beyond, on getting things to new level of wrong:
Humanoid mobs were voiced by man that was talking in a cup.
Chat helps you ignore people and lose friends, by constantly getting "why don't you reply to me?!" from them. And it's "totally not" because there's no custom tabs for you to make.
In-game achievement tab doesn't work for half of the time you're trying to access it.
Questing done with great idea of "can I copy your homework?" in mind. You might even pick literally same quest x2 on townboard, then go to place, loot x1 of the item you need (and there's only one chest on this pylon anyway), then go back to place to turn them both, to get to know that only one did turn since you had only x1 of the items and you need to run back to loot another one.
Did you just put your hands on this shiny chest? How dare you! Now chest can reject being looted, by not letting you end the action, making you sit in it, till you get bored and let it go. Happens with gathering too!
This isn't place to roleplay either, with amount of premium emotes being sold in Store being higher than those that you get for free. Go back to Goldshire you weirdo!
And so much more!

Yes, this game did hurt me in no way any other before it. It almost drowned me with weight of my bags, when you can't open your inventory in water, but you also can't jump or climb if you're carrying too much. And nobody cares if you looted this chest in the same water. That was a trap!

I can in no way recommend this product. I purchased New World for myself and my wife, and we managed to play some 11-16 hours before she received a permanent ban for no reason. The reason given was "detection of cheating software", my wife has an average computer with Steam installed and she uses Nexus Mod Manager for her Skyrim and Baldur's Gate 3 installs, and that's pretty much it as far as anything that could be considered dodgy by Easy Anti Cheat. She uses standard Windows Defender, so it's not dodgy anti-virus software causing it either, and she only uses Razer products and I'm sure Razer Synapse would not cause a false flag.

So I can only conclude that Amazon Game Studios have false thought she was cheating based on bugs in their own game or in Easy Anti Cheat. That said, their support is non-existant. Everything is automated and they're hiding from their own customers by not offering any way to reach an actual human being when you have a support case.

We've asked for refunds from Steam and I can only urge you to stay away from this game as it can't be trusted. We were lucky we got this problem only after 10-15 hours and not after 500 hours. 

I honestly don't trust Amazon Game Studios after this -.-

Would probably recommend this game as I found it pretty fun to play! If you like gathering resources it's pretty perfect and the combat is actually quite fun despite having quite simple skill tree system for each weapon type.

Unfortunately their automatic anti-cheat system seemed to ban me permanently for no reason and the customer support at Amazon just seems to ignore tickets completely, copy pasting the same message over and over again (sometimes forgetting to even add their name to the template message).

I'll have to unfortunately leave a negative review for this occasion as they might have this issue happen to also other players and treat them the same. Had bought the game for two of my friends and decided to spend some money on the in-game store, only to notice they just take the money and restrict access to their game without any proper notice nor support to handle the situation on their behalf as this was clearly an error on their behalf...

If they manage to improve their process on handling such issues I'll probably swap the review to positive as the game itself is pretty good and very enjoyable to play (I had almost 140 hours in two weeks, crazy).

EDIT: It took quite a while for them to review my ban, but as I promised I'll flip the review to positive.

While the game has quite a bit of annoying bugs and lacks some optimization and has memory leaks. The experience of leveling your character up from 1 to 65 and then questing around the world is qutie the positive experience. On the other hand the game lacks fundamental bases like fast travel points being accessible from the open world instead near a shrine or town, as well and the serious lack of the option to select TAB targeting instead of Aiming have put me down quite a bit since I would expect from a mage class to have TAB targetting. This is what most mage players expect, as well and the option to choose between Aim or TAB Targetting.

The dungeons of the games are fun. The grind fests though for levelling up your crafting is REAL and painful. Especially levelling up your weapons, it happens so slowly that you see almost next to no progress with your weapons due to that. I would expect from the game to provide way faster levelling for your weapon if the max is 20. I see minimal leveling when doing dungeons or quest for my weapons and that is putting me off.

Other than that, the game could really use more variety when it comes to mage classes. Having just four, fire, ice, void and life (where life is heal and not damaging mage class is a let down). I would expect a class like an elementalist who would wield all four elements, and then a void class (which we do have with the gauntlet), necromancer (since we do see quite a bit of necromancers in-game but for some reason they don't have it as class) and so on. Choosing between Fire and Ice for main mage DPS class feels like a huge let down, for someone who does not enjoy Pyromancers or Cryomancers for their mage class.

All the above is as I say, until you reach the zones that are level 60+, this is the moment when this games becomes hardcore Dark Souls type of game which truly turned me away and off from the game. I do not recommend the game simply because the Dark Souls genre is NOT for MMORPG titles. The idea behind an MMORPG is for the player to enjoy their power and not get smashed or destroyed in a quest zone that matches their level.

The game does have a stunning open world with tons of content to keep you busy. I would definitely recommend people to at least give it a try.

ETA 1/10/24: UI and graphics issues look fixed; the other issues still prompt me to disrecommend for now on the basis of inferiority to other gaming options. I will likely revisit if/when the developer releases their forecasted cross-world expedition feature, as a solid implementation would substantially reduce the friction associated with finding a group for expeditions.

Blockers to me returning for this new expansion after 1.7k+ hours of gameplay:

* Gear reset (due to meta mixup with vast number of perks changing, bane/resil removal, etc) accompanied by very little in way of new content - reprogging would be very low novelty.
* Looks like I can't do anything challenging solo; still arbitrary floors on # of players to enter an expedition so I can't try to solo tempest for fun. But - no PvE crossplay, so player pool for group play is pretty limited too.
*Extrapolating skills from 1-200 up to 250, adding in a new tier of items and calling it a day isn't satisfying for me in terms of new content for crafting etc.
* UI issues - text is very pixelated, strange things like bags being sorted into headers that don't fit, resulting in things like "LEATHERW..." being shown. Something broader may be amiss - the text issue exists with pre-interaction text for gatherables etc as well, but there are also oddities like the skill-gain circle for getting xp when gathering being sometimes really small (but not always.)
* Graphics issues - game looks supersaturated, but only has brightness/contrast configuration. Performance is sub-par compared to other games, probably due to not supporting DLSS (or its AMD equivalent) etc. 

The combat system is kinda neat, but WoW wins for dungeons and BDO wins for pretty much everything else, making New World the Microsoft Surface of MMOs :/

I play this every day, and have put more than 700+ hours into it, i've had my decent amount of fun with it, not that i won't keep playing but the price i paid for it and the xpac i consider it a great purchase.

The good:
- The combat is better than any MMO out there.
- The graphics are better than any MMO out there.
- NW Team pushes updates to try an balance the weapons and skills every now and then.
- World events, influence races (open pvp) and overall interaction with the server community is great.
- There is a lot of stuff to do besides just questing, there is housing, transmog, other game modes like OPR and 3V3 (this last one depends on the server you are on until they get crossworld 3v3s).

The not bad, not good:
- NW Team delivers updates slowly and QA seems non existent.
- Almost every patch comes buggy and delayed by a day or two.
- Crafting and Gathering are huge time sinks.
- PVP is not the priority right now and it's kinda unbalanced.
- Game has cosmetics and a season pass, this isn't that bad as you are not paying every month for a suscription and its entirely up to the user to purchase (it doesn't really offer anything you cant get by just playing).
- Game has mounts now (paywalled by xpac, but it isn't that expensive if you play this every day).
- Game will get cross-world expeditions (dungeons) and a revised group finder wich is great and also should have had from day one.
- Seasonal events are kinda repeated, this MMO has been out two years so this isn't really that bad but yeah.

The bad:
- Performance is not that great, it is perfectly playable but hiccups and other issues do affect the game.
- The game often has very weird and game breaking bugs, this is bad, but if you do play you can help out by reporting said bugs in their official discord channel.
- It should have gamepad support, it has been hinted as coming in this year (2024).

I'm revising my previous review due to the amount of time and development that has been completed on the game. I've also spent a lot more time playing it, including the additional content that has been added.

I have played this game a lot and enjoyed its MMO-repeat-the-same-type-of-quest action with fun combat abilities and mechanics. I reached max level, enjoy the PvP options, open world and not. Since my previous review there have been many quality of life improvements that have reduced the barrier to enjoying the play experience.

Unfortunately, I still haven't played dungeons much because the improvements and fixes came too late and too slowly and none of my gaming friends play any more, nor do I expect they ever will. However, there are solo options for the main story quests that otherwise would require a dungeon (expedition) run.

I have to say that I've enjoyed the additions and changes to the game play and have now played to level 60 on more than one character (leveling is much faster now). This means I have been through several of the story lines two or more times. I particularly like the added "Soul Trial" solo boss fights and additional story driven quest lines; I even used paper and pencil to solve a burning sands quest puzzle at one point.

This is not to say that all the bugs have been fixed. Looting a chest still occasionally fizzles, starting a new character had an issue that required resetting the initial tutorial quest, and sometimes I find a resource node that is frozen or has placement issues. I would say these are infrequent enough to prevent ruining the experience, and at least Amazon doesn't break the game every week with an update anymore.

I think if you spent your money now, you would enjoy the game, and even consider buying the DLC for the mounts (much faster), increased level cap, and increased skill cap.

Overall I will say that you will get your 70 dollars worth out of this game (base game + needed expansion). 

Pros: It doesn't reinvent the wheel as far as MMOs are concerned and it has taken a lot of things that work well from other games, but what is special about this game is that due to it being swapped from a survival crafting pvp game to a traditional MMO at the last stages of development, the combat in the game is so clean, skill driven, and team oriented. There is no tab to target, and you have to aim all your attacks/abilities. 

Zero pay to win (season pass can give you some mats but its nothing you can't easily obtain) and all micro-transactions are cosmetic only, 

There is grind, as with all RPG/MMO games, but the game has implemented systems over numerous updates that both improve QoL as well as respect players time. It is much easier to get your final endgame set together than it has ever been before. That being said, some items for purchase needed for endgame upgrades are time gated. These items are needed only for max level crafts/upgrades, and are not needed to put a build together as random loot does drop high enough from enough different activities.

Cons: The devs seem to be way out of touch with the PVP side of development and enrichment. There been small updates to PVP with the 3v3 arenas, and the influence races have replaced the old system of declaring war, but we still have one single endgame PVP map that doesn't factor role queue, and declaring war is still gated behind territory ownership and influence race. In the future I would hope that they will add wars between companies on demand, and add a role based queue system to instanced PVP (the role based system exists for PVE instances already.) 

Generating in game currency (aside from working the trade market) is still extremely grindy. New players will feel this in their pockets until the knowledge of how to farm efficiently is learned through trial and error or osmosis. 

Customer service for this game is handled solely through the NW official discord. In my experience the devs have been helpful with in game issues you may have, but whenever they make a mistake with a patch or content launch they punish players for taking advantage of an "exploit." In my humble opinion, id like to see them disable whatever is allowing the exploit, but not ban/punish players for things the game allows without cheats or 3rd party apps. 

If you're a prospective player reading this, 99% of you wont get into a winnable war. Until they add queued wars, the content is held by the top 1% of players and is very much social slotting, as it is hard to weigh one player against another in war circumstances even with scoreboards. To combat this, top companies require VODs of you doing wars in order to get a shot at a slot in war. If you have never done a war, you have no vod, and cannot meet requirements for a slot tryout. Also, before you come at me sideways saying skill issue, I got the territory victor drip on both US East and US West regions and have been main war roster for the majority of my time playing. This has just been my experience in competitive companies.

Neither Pro or Con: This game doesn't hold your hand and can be unforgiving. This could be seen as a good or bad thing depending on your personal opinions. I would highly recommend new players to join a large guild regardless of that guilds skill level just to learn from as many sources as possible.

Performance optimization is bad even when way above recommended specs with an optimal configuration.
Trying to render 1080p on 1440p monitor is not implemented properly, so it's EXTRA blurry. If I want proper 1080p, I have to set my monitor to 1080p before playing. This is annoying.
This game will melt your hardware if you aren't careful, both GPU & CPU.
[b]Cap your framerate to a point that isn't overworking your hardware[/b]; monitor your hardware usage%, temperatures, power usage% and framerates. Figure out a safe & stable framerate for the settings you want, then cap it there.
I highly recommend using MSI Afterburner + RTSS (RivaTuner) to monitor all this. You can set up a toggle-able overlay/OSD(On-Screen-Display). Add the NewWorld executable to RTSS and cap your framerate in there. There's no better FPS limiter than RTSS. These 2 programs are made to be very lightweight and run in the background 24/7, and they work in combination with each other. They're widely used by millions.

I'll happily change this to a positive review as soon as performance improves, and ONLY then.

This is a bit of an oddball.  I think this is a VERY WELL put together MMO.  There are a lot of levels to the economy and allegiances within the game.  The gathering and crafting is EXTREMELY deep and the recipes get more complicated as your level goes up.  With that said, I haven't really felt like I have been having a lot of "fun" playing it in this first 25 or so hours.  I am interested for sure.  I like the areas I am in, the combat system, and the aesthetics.  I feel like the crafting and gathering are a bit taxing, but rewarding.  The quests are either interesting or completely boring depending on if it is a story mission or a town project.  It is good, and I think it is going to be around a good while.  The foundation of a GREAT game is there.
EDIT: After 200+ hours.  I pretty much stopped playing it after the initial server changes over a year ago.  I had helped my faction get a large holding in our server then all that was erased.  I wasn't able to do much after that and lost interest.  I log in here and there, but now the game runs poorly on my PC.

This is one of those games where I think about it and go "Dang I haven't logged in a while. I should play it."

Then I log in and 20 minutes later I want to log off.

There is a general feeling of bugginess and shittiness that plagues nearly every second of this game. You have to just walk and bumble around everywhere. Go walk 500 meters this way and kill five things. Then press E on 3 things. Good job. Now walk 350 meters for the next step. You already know the drill. This is the extent of the questing, which you will be doing for a long time.

Doesn't matter what I've done to my settings, I'm constantly stuttering and it never stops no matter where I am or what I'm doing. It makes my eyes hurt. This has made me miss jumps that the game insists on making you do during the questing content which was infuriating.

The crafting is a joke. You will walk around for two hours, fill up your pack, and after refining craft like ten things, make very little progress. 

The invasions and territory system is terrible unless you happen to be available to play video games at the time the game allows you to do them. So if not, well then that sucks because that entire aspect of the game is completely shut off for you.

The combat is abysmal and boring. Just lumberjack away at something while it swings unimpeded through the damage it is taking and staggers you incessantly. It doesn't get better.

The content is you doing chores to get access to higher-tier chores. That's the entire game. Running through a boring map, clumsily flailing at monsters, pressing E on rocks and trees, and waiting five seconds to open boxes. I wish I hadn't bought this game.

Cant talk about content yet, as i am still at the beginning, but i can say the game looks horrible on any settings due to lack of any form of antialiasing other than TAA (blended frames on moving objects), which makes the game look blurry while moving camera (or moving in game) and horribly while static (zero antialiasing - jagged edges, hard pixels on the enviroment during the day light). 
It ignores the nvidia's control panel antialiasing settings other than FXAA (and propably multiframe-sampled aa), which simply makes all the game blurry no matter if stuff is moving on the screen or is static. 
Blurry is bad, while no antialiasing is also bad. Especially in the game with so much visual noise in the enviroment (bazilions of grasses and bushes). With no antialiasing its just a sea of pixels noise, especially while they try to reflect the sun rays.
Would not have bought it if i knew there is no proper antialiasing in the game. Maybe they will add one in the future. For now it looks ugly - nothing like you see on downscaled images from higher resolutions, which increase the quality of otherwise pixelated ugly mess.
To add insult to injury, be aware that by buying the base game without expansion, you still have to do what others hated till the expansion (running miles and miles on foot without access to mount). So if you want better game experience (not just new content), but actual QoL improvements take price of the game and the expansion into the account. Without expansion you buy what you get for free in better looking mmos (old, capped content as free trial).

Edit After a few dozen hours.

Overall really enjoying the game. There are a few design flaws that can be annoying. The biggest challenge is the amount of bugs I have to deal with in every play session. I hope to see this game improve from a technical perspective over the next few years.



Best early game MMO I have played. No character swapping needed as every class can be played on one character. Simple early game crafting and gather. Everything has a low barrier to entry. Really fun to explore and do things in the open world.

The amount of lag experienced every time I log in makes it pretty well unplayable. Even with video settings set as low as possible (on a computer far beyond the minimum requirements). It basically plays like ESO, but at least that you can walk more than 20 feet and not drop in ESO. If you want to play an MMO, look up the current top 10 and choose any one that isn't this game.

Reviewing at 50 hours, level 40 something, 

Let's start with the bad then get to the good:

Bad
[strike]1. Server latency is terrible and needs to be fixed, apparently it is better than at launch but rubberbanding can be really annoying and affects immersion. Do not blame your hardware unless you have a potato, my fps on an older computer is well over 100 in the world and never below 65 in cities.[/strike] Australian internet was the issue, hotspotting my phone fixed this issue for me. 

Good:
1. Crafting is extremely satisfying, very good audio effects, UI is clean, systems make sense and aren't too grindy but also reward time and effort.
2. The world is beautiful and dense and exploration is rewarded, I really like that it is island based instead of this massive empty world like many other games.
3. The story, atleast for me, is immersive. I like the nature theme and the multiple aspect to each side. The journals/lore you pick up are fleshed out and relevant to the area you are exploring, even minor and side quests are voice acted which just helps with immersion.
4. Music perfectly suits the world, it is understated and really helps with the ambivalence. The music instrument system is also a lot of fun, themed profession music is a great touch.
5. UI is clean, satisfying and simple. The last game I played before this was starfield so you can imagine my relief when I saw the menus in this game. 
6. Combat is satisfying, it's not ARPG but it's also not stand still and press 3, there's levels to it, sound effects are nice and you can choose how you want to play.
7. Classless system, amazing, you aren't locked in and don't have to have multiple characters to try different things. Great design. 
8. Other players are generally quite nice and helpful, someone gave my partner 18k when she went to the first town with a nice welcome message and players have been helpful in dungeons in the over world as well. 

Overall:
An immersive, beautiful world that rewards exploration, crafting and effort. Combat is satisfying, the classless system is great, UI is very clean and music suits the world very well. [strike]Fix the latency/server issues and hopefully this game sticks around for a long time.[/strike] My internet was the problem, it's better to hotspot my phone instead of run an Ethernet cord to my pc, got to love Australian internet.

New World: A Disappointing Odyssey - Don't Even Bother, Save Yourself the Regret

Embarking on the journey into "New World" is akin to setting sail on a ship with a hull full of hopes, only to find it dashed against the rocks of disappointment. Don't even bother, for the allure of uncharted territories quickly gives way to the realization that this game is a sinking ship of unmet promises, technical hiccups, and questionable design choices.

The initial excitement of exploring the pristine landscapes of Aeternum is swiftly overshadowed by a plethora of issues that plague "New World" like a relentless storm. The first and most glaring concern is the lack of meaningful content, leaving players to wander through beautiful yet barren landscapes with a distinct absence of engaging quests or activities. Don't even bother, for the game's potential quickly devolves into a monotonous grind with little reward.

Character progression, touted as a cornerstone feature, falls flat like a deflated lifeboat. The lack of class diversity, uninspiring abilities, and a general sense of imbalance leave players yearning for the depth and variety promised in the game's pre-launch hype. Don't even bother, as the progression system lacks the vibrancy and excitement that should accompany an MMO of this scale.

Technical issues further compound the sense of regret. Lag spikes, server instability, and long queues transform the prospect of exploration into an exercise in frustration. Don't even bother, as the game's infrastructure struggles to provide a smooth and enjoyable experience, turning what should be a seamless journey into a stop-and-start ordeal.

The PvP-centric nature of "New World" raises eyebrows and not in a good way. The lack of PvE endgame content and the emphasis on faction-based warfare often feel forced, as if the game is trying to shoehorn players into a playstyle that may not align with their preferences. Don't even bother, unless you have a penchant for the chaotic and sometimes unbalanced world of open-world PvP.

In conclusion, "New World" is a venture that promised uncharted wonders but delivers only a sea of disappointment. Don't even bother, as the potential for a truly groundbreaking MMO experience is drowned out by a chorus of unaddressed issues and unfulfilled expectations. Save yourself the regret, for the allure of Aeternum quickly fades into a sense of longing for a game that could have been so much more.

The game itself isn't horrible and I wish steam had a better way to rate titles.  It is the little details within the game that need to be addressed. From a far the game looks great, the world is fun to dive into and explore. However, once you start your grind you will notice that each and every area of the island feels the same, and the toons to fight are no different. Yes questing is repetitive its an MMO you new here? But with this game they seem to drag on these quests with endless bore of an empty world of enemies to fight and loot. 

The dungeons are fun. Only issue is unless they have a mutation, or you're lucky enough to have friends to play this game with you will be waiting ages for a lobby to fill to complete the dungeon. Huge turn off for me in this game. They cap the amount of dungeons you can do in a day, and there is no options to go in solo and clear it. 

The crafting is fun. For a casual player that just wants to come in and grind a little with levelling their skills I can see the positive aspects of this game. They do not limit you to what you can craft. It is just a huge grind to get there. Crafting and enhancing those skill can take multiple days to gather the needed materials to craft the simplest of gear. A few farm areas to gain the resources and with the servers being empty the majority of the time a casual player can easily farm away. 

Mounts are behind a pay wall. You get them unlocked with buying the angry earth DLC. You can get a free horse,wolf,and Lion once you grind through all the challenges. No options other than that to grind for mounts unfortunately but obviously you can buy within the gem store of the game like every other MMO. The fine detail in the mounts is horrific. Wolf needed horseshoes to run faster. Yes read that again. There is no sound difference when riding other than the sound the animal makes. So always hearing a horse clip glop away when on a wolf is just aggravating af. 

Lastly the graphics. They are terrible. Cut scenes just skip them. The close up rendering of graphics looks like something out of the early 00s and the mouth to voice do not sync. Trees from a far are blotchy no matter the setting you choose and the over all close up imagine is less than good for the amount you will need to spend on this game. It feels like rust or dayz at times with how poorly ran this game is at times. 

This game feels like a chore to play half of the time with little to no reward as to why you're investing the time and energy into it. But at the same time the game can be fun. If we were to be rating it on a star level I would place it right were it needs to be place. 3/5. No more no less. It is fun depending on what you are investing your time in. But for a game that was set out to replace all others...... No where close to it. Dead severs, dead game play. Hopefully the devs can actually address the random crashes in games and add some actual content behind this title or more people will go back to what they know and what they are used to.

so. im kinnda mixed on this game. the graphics are good, the combat is fine for an MMO, but ive played probably 10-15 hours (not including queue time) and it is literally all the same thing.... Go to location, kill # enemies, loot chests... like that is it... oh and harvesting, there is a lot of that. Crafting is a nice break from the monotony right until it gets monotonous itself, but is better implemented in some mmos. There are quests that tell you to be a certain level to do it and then you walk halfway across the map only to find out the quests in that zone cannot be picked up until you are at an even higher level. Honestly; It's an okay MMORPG. I've had something approximating fun. It's really just a way to waste my time. There's nothing incredibly unique about the game, and the lore/quests are mediocre if I'm being completely candid. The only thing that I really enjoy about the game is that its a well-rounded game that doesn't rely on Micro-transactions. That being said, the grind is bullshit. The experience rewards from quests make it absolutely mind-numbing to traverse the world. They have fast-travel, sure. But you rely on Azoth to travel around and it runs out FAST. You can purchase a house in any settlement, but then have to pay like... 500 gold every 4 days to be able to use it. 

IF they add mounts, buy the game. IF they do not; I would only recommend this game if you like spending 10 minutes moving from one quest objective to another. That's LITERALLY the only thing I dislike about the game. I don't mean figuratively. I mean literally, I have ONE complaint. Traveling around the map SUCKS.
