As of right now I have 270 hours log into this game. I would have to say I love it! Definitely one of the better mmos I have played in a long time. The game play is fun, the expedition’s a.k.a dungeons are so different at first gave me early ESO vibes. 

As you get to level 65 and start to really work on getting your artifact gear and open world raids you find yourself involved in a massive group chest runs and harder difficulty dungeons! To try to get the gear piece to make your room even better.

You can change up your weapons at any time if you choose to change up your play style it has different build slots so you can swap on the fly the down side is you need to respec if you go from let’s say two handed dps to a mage. 

The economy in the game is pretty trashed so it’s hard to get gold and you can spend a lot of gold after you get your artifact sadly.

The devs definitely have their issues with the game but I can’t knock them to hard because they are trying so hard on making the game better and better and run smoother for people they honestly are trying to bout their best foot forward. I think 2024 is goin to be an amazing year for New World. So if you plan on buying it this might be the year to start to get involved.

My wife was really into this game and I think she has 1000+ hours into this game. Unfortunately she ran into a bug with server transferring which costs money. Amazon Game Studios (AGS) asked her to keep trying and keep spending $16 over and over again and she kept getting the error. AGS then went completely dark and kept sending her the same automated email response with zero resolution. To be honest it's an mmorpg that has a different approach like most mmo's have. New World let's you level up trading skills, mastery skills and characteristic attributes. You get 1 free respec for each tree. You can choose to either follow the story or go on your own and focus on other things. It's an open world so there is a lot to do and a lot to offer. If you want a Mount you will need to get the DLC Angry of Earth to unlock them. Usually at character lvl 25 you can unlock the mount but you will need the DLC to get it. The Trading post I have to say is the one of the most useful thing in the game. If you don't feel like tracking over everywhere for resources you can go to the trading post and buy some. You get a lot of currency in the game. To be able to create a company you will need to join a faction then that company can help govern the settlement lands. You also get bonuses when doing stuff like activities, every time you get a point you can distribute it to 3 buffs for every point.

I dunno what to say anymore. The game is good, but then it's not. It's not so bad that a person doesn't return to play again, buy the DLC, etc and so forth. The devs are clearly trying to make it better... but there is just only so much you can do about some problems, like the community at times. Is it worth your money? Sure. Is it worth the full price? Eh... I want to say yes because they put a lot of work into it, but at the same time they have a problem in changing too much too often just to suit the whims of... others. Sometimes it's a good thing. Sometimes, not as much. A lot of it is middle of the road to be fair. 

For example, the Warhammer used to be a lot better, but it got nerfed in how it's specials operate. Not a deal breaker, since it's still plenty powerful. But when you used to really like a certain method of rotating those specials, only to have it taken away because people complained... feels bad man. When it's a glitchy thing, I understand. Hatchet glitch had to go, as awesome as it was. But hammer? Really? It wasn't even a glitch. 

And people will go on and on about balance, but ultimately player skill undoes a lot of the advantages in some form or another. Same can be said of some of the disadvantages as well, but to a lesser extent. 

Or the markets for example. Sure, being able to freely sell things back and forth as a global market is pretty nice. But part of creating a game with trade networks between companies and their towns is that you don't make instant transmission of items a thing between storage locations. Inclusion of this ability, as nice as it is as well for players I will admit, also removes an entire aspect of tactical planning and strategy in the game. Provided of course the game is meant to have the companies competing against each other. Which, unless something changed last I checked... heh... it was. Competition and cooperation as it were. Well, making items instant transferable basically ruins part of that element. Now there is no reason to level up your towns to attract more people to your faction or company. When a company does level up a town, people like that; but if they lose those levels to an invasion it's an instant RIP for them in chat. Why? Cause the community knows that the only way that town is levelling up again is if the company doesn't just give up and actually tries again... and succeeds without losing to invasions again in the meantime. 

Basically towns have become a place of convenience only now. A spot to teleport to, because apparently walking and running was too much for many. That's fair, I can understand that when there were no mounts in the game, and lore specified that there would be no mounts. But that changed. Now there are mounts, with a DLC purchase. And there are also teleport locations galore to the point where it's a chore to get them all whenever they reset because of some new addition or removal that caused the dev's to reset those locations as well. (Seriously... it becomes quite annoying after a while.)

But teleports are restricted to Azoth, right? 

Well, yeah... but also no. There are free teleports as well as your houses. Proper combination of use between these means you can hop around the map for free for the most part, if you do things in the proper order with a teleport here, a run there, another teleport here, and a run there. Convenient, yes. Game breaking... not quite. But it does remove from the immersion when you are constantly loading new areas from teleporting. Oh, and... just now... apparently teleporting can cause some sort of stack/buffer overflow that can allow an attacker to gain access to your system. Just got that warning from my computer as it shut down the game just a minute or so before writing this new review. 

So that's great. /sarcasm

Here's the deal. The game isn't a bad one. It's fun enough to be worth the money. But it has problems, and those problems might differ based on your perspective and mentality on certain things. But they do have problems, agreed upon mostly by nearly all the community as a general basis. But they are trying to fix those problems. But... sometimes those fixes create new problems. 

If you have patience for this sort of thing, like what will happen with Beta games in general, then go ahead and play it. You'll probably love it, even when you don't have the fondest feelings for it. But don't go in expecting perfection. Definitely not perfection. 

And make sure you have a thick skin too, because the moderators I think have learned at this point that the community can be pretty darn toxic at times, even when the person they don't like is completely in the right. 

I've been at the short end of the stick on that side of things a couple times; but eventually they figured things out and reverted their decision later on on the second time. Lucky me. 

So they are learning, in multiple ways, and so the game is getting better. 

But if I were you, I would wait for a sale first at least, because the sad fact is that you'll probably put in enough hours in the game first to not be able to get a refund if you decide later you wish you hadn't bought the game. This will be a thing for some. So be wary.

I bought New World on sale for myself, my wife, and 2 grown kids, initially skeptical and without the newly released DLC, Rise of the Angry Earth. Buying 4 copies of the Elysian Edition was untenable in the event we weren't hooked.

We were hooked. As someone with almost 1500 hours in Elder Scrolls Online, I very much appreciate AGS' buy-to-play model as opposed to ESO handicapping players who can't or won't pay for a subscription. Sure, there is a store and a paid Season Pass, but these are completely optional and don't give anything other than cosmetics that you can't otherwise obtain through playing the game -- and the free Season Pass is great. We don't feel in any way punished or deprived for not spending any money beyond the one-time purchases of the game and the DLC (which I also highly recommend, mounts are great).

Gameplay wise, it's like Elder Scrolls, Elden Ring, Diablo, Witcher, Minecraft, and Christopher Columbus had an orgy, and we're not sure who the father is, but they've all influenced Amazon's love child. It's one of the most beautiful games I've ever played and has a little of something for everyone--tactical combat, grinding, questing, crafting, fishing, home ownership and decorating, a fantastic loot and transmog system, dungeons, PvP--and it's all optional, as serious or as casual as you decide it will be. From what I understand, AGS has turned an initially terrible launch into a solid and feature-rich game.

It does have occasionally buggy updates, and it's very CPU demanding. Over 2 years in, AGS should have added a swimming mechanic, and there are quests and areas that feel unfinished. But their formula for fun and engaging gameplay, with a beautiful immersive world, is spot on.

Buy the game on sale, the DLC is worth it if you plan to put a lot of hours into it. 9/10 recommend.

Okay, so let me just break it down a little:
1. Combat system is superb. I'd play a singleplayer game with this combat system
2. I really like the traversal mechanics - you can climb, grab the ledge mid-jump, crouch, even fall on the ground and crawl. And this stuff is actually used in gameplay - there're fun jumping puzzles
3. Loot, crafting, interface and overall QoL is pretty good and fun
4. World is sorta victorian / colonial, similar to Greenfall somehow. It's not a classic fantasy, but I liked it - it feels fresh
5. there's a proper story and voiced dialogues
6. Also there's a complicated territorial system I couldn't wrap my head around yet

I haven't seen dungeons and raids yet, haven't seen PvP and endgame, haven't delved too deep into crafting as well. So I guess there's still much for me to see. But so far experience is great, and it's only getting better.

I am a veteran of WoW (/played a total of more than 35000h - yes more than 4 years online) I bought the game at launch. Due to the mass of bugs and endless queues, I put it on the shelf for 2 years. 

In December 2023, I wanted to give it another chance. I terribly regret that. I haven't seen a more boring character leveling. From lvl 1-45 I had only one interaction with the player. Seemingly someone running around out there, but no willing people for dungeons, monotonous quests often sending you back to the same place with a different goal. Zones 35+ empty, cities small (for comparison WoW Ironforge alone is larger than all the cities in the New World combined). Overall like a single player running simulator. Definitely do not recommend. ESO already does it better.

Fun pve. Devs don't seem to know how to balance pvp/arena/opr with regards to weapons and therefore new world is terrible in that regard. You are supposed to be able to play the way that you want and still be relevant in most if not all content available. This is not true. The last patch made pvp unplayable as there are items that completely outclass any others. Therefore there are really only a few builds and everything you think or want to try or play is trash which is wrong. Player skill doesn't win pvp. Numbers, gear, limited builds, and exploitation do. You play with overpowered and unbalanced items and a monkey see monkey do skill build, you can beat any skilled individual who doesn't have them.

The fact that they lock certain items behind pvp is also a piss poor design and way to do it.

Recommend the game for its pve, and subtle open world pvp. Do not recommend this game for its terrible balancing, and closed off pvp areas.

So many comments are false in here which proves that steam user reviews are getting out of control.

Saw a comment that says "mounts are promised way at the beginning, putting it under a paid expansion is not the way".
FALSE info. Mounts are not promised at the beggining, actually they insisted on "mounts are not coming and it's in the lore that in Aeternum, you can't tame any animals." Then they decided to flip from this, which was the right decision imo.

Saw a comment that says; After season 4 game became unplayable, servers are constantly crashing etc.
This is also a manipulative false information. Yeah, servers did crash at the first and second day of the beginning of season 4 due to the event they brought and whole server started farming it like there was 300 players attacking at the same boss at the same time so it did cause some crashes. Annoying, but saying that "game is unplayable now" is not a true information. They're all fixed after 2-3 days. Not being able to play the game for a day doesn't make the whole game is a "not recommended" one.

Saw a comment that says game is locked for casual players like they can't do territory wars etc. TOTALLY FALSE. 
This is the most casual friendly MMO i've ever played tbh. Territory Wars is a feature for organized clans BUT you can still join them as a casual player. You enlist yourself to a war and clans are picking players from the list for the war. If they can't fill the party with their clan's players, they will pick from the random enlisters (mercenaries). Even with a lower level and gear, you might find a spot in a war as a casual player. OFC it will not be frequent but you still gonna have the oppurtunity.

That's not fair.

The honey moon phase is over. The game was good for a couple months coming back to experience the expansion, but the end game is stale, repetitive, and boring at its core. The end game content revolves around doing the same exact content that has been in the game since launch.

The New World team has made significant progress over the years but it's still not enough given who their parent company is.

The main problems.

1) Client
There are A LOT of bugs and performance issues.

2) Gear
All end game crafted gear is locked behind artificial time syncs and insane "coin" cost. The system is inherently cumbersome and seems to be designed as a more of a method to waste the players time then to actually craft items. New and returning players will find it extremely challenging to craft best in slot items even after playing the game for months.

3) Balance
The game balance is probably one of the worst experiences I've ever had in an MMO. Ranged and light armor builds absolutely dominate in PvP be it open world, outpost rush, or the 3v3 arenas. There are so many problems with the core foundation of how combat works and what seems to be AGS' vision for the future that I would say to not even waste your time PvPing.

The Good: Visuals/Graphics, Crafting System, UI, Combat, Skill/Trees, Interesting quests/lore / The Bad: Little details throughout the game are just..off (no swimming for example), Minor bugs and quirks, hard to get explanations of some game systems/mechanics in game. Hate that there isn't an in game wiki or index or something learn about systems/lore more directly.   The Ugly:Minor bugs and quirks - little details, Example - switching from full screen to window works fine.  If you need to go back to full screen...doesn't work.  Game still feels partially complete or like it has two different personalities.  I'd still recommend the game though.  FFXIV is my main game followed by Guild Wars2 and BDO but this is quickly becoming one of my favorite games and may get pushed up to my #2 or #3 game.

New level scaling and the massive amounts of xp you recieve for character levels gets you to end game in 48 hours of playing, which is no where near ideal. All they had to do was release fresh start servers to eliminate the horrid economies after the bots nuked prices and people that were exploiting on release and they messed that up.

MMOs by design should be a grind from start to finish, that's literally the entire point of the game. Being able to hit level 60 with level 40 gear and barely any weapon levels is insanely unbalanced. Getting to "end game" in two days makes crafting useless when leveling far exceeds usefulness of crafted gear. 

I also expecting them to increase the level cap with each DLC to mimic WoW with the feel that there is more to do/progress, but when you are max level all the time, questing seems pointless, especially when you can game the market in it's current state to make loads of money, and then just spam raids to get higher gear score items. What is the point of playing when you hit 60 besides playing the same raids over and over, that is not an end game I am willing to soak time in to, EXCEEDINGLY SO when the time to grind end game far exceeds the time to get to 60. Why would I feel invested in the end game content when it takes me 2 days to get there, if that.

Overall same gripes as day 1 release, with new ones for making the game extremely casual.

I was a bit harsh on my first review. It's pretty good. Worth the on sale price for sure.

The combat is cool for these reasons:
- You don't just spam number keys
- Attacks actually have to hit you to register as hits
- The dodge mechanic is different based on three armor types (light,medium,heavy)
- Good selection of weapons to pick from but gota get dlc for the Flail

Everything you do in this game gives you exp for associated skills.

The environment is beautiful.

There's stuff to collect and do all over the map. Some resources are node while others are scattered by biome(as it were). Mining is node based but plant and hide harvesting is different. There's plants and animals everywhere.

Fishing is super cool. There's fresh and salt water. There's also different types of bait that are more of less rare and used in certain types of water or times of day. There's also fishing spot you have to find that'll give you better fish.

There are no junk merchants. You either hoard your stuff, salvage it(good idea), or sell it to other players.

I also suggest adding the ability to be different races. I'm a 'Furry' lover and would totally spend $ just to be a Cat dude in a video game...

This game is very fun at first and very addicting if you never played a mmo like this before but there are some serious things to consider now that I own the game and have played for 113 hours since I bought it.

1. This game is not worth full price and neither would the DLC considering the base game.( I dont own the DLC but it looks like a free money grab with very little content and just is there to block you from certain content such as mounts and other things)

2. There are still many bugs such as resource nodes not being able to be mined and the points of interest  not showing up on your compass after you do the first dungeon which is a 2021 BUG BTW.

3. You level up too quick here and it is next to pointless to create your own companies if the server is already established with players(which it always will be)

4. For people who use EU and ASIA servers the invasions and faction pvp events happen at times that are not realistically playable for most people so it becomes a dead event or an event where a few sweats can just dominate because everyone else dropped the game because of lack of content.

5. PvP and PvE is very fun especially the way how you assign attributes and weapon play and such but it is still rare for real pvp fights with people your own level if you just started so you will just get broken by max level players when taking points during territory wars.

6. Making in game currency in the game is easy as long as you do all the quests but looks like it falls off after the quests are done so you should use gold sparingly  because it is not an easy grind for end level stuff since they cap you at 10 crafts a day for certain items needed. 

Overall the game is OK at best  but very beautiful and has some cool lore and cut-scenes however all in all it is a game that doesnt really give you the  feel of you can play this for years as an MMO but is instead a like AAA game like COD that has a year lifespan in terms of gameplay and i mean that at the very best if I give them benefit of the doubt.

I've played this game a lot and had a lot of fun with friends, however i would say that this game is 80% grind and pure boredom in its current iteration, it is also immensely anti-casual and the PvP scene is almost entirely dead.

Economy and crafting are so inaccessible that anyone other than a sweatlord living in the game will have absolutely 0 chance of crafting themselves viable equipment. Example; a crafting trophy which is required to craft viable equipment can be 35k+ gold and you need 3 of these. The average 20-40 minute game activity will give you around 350 gold if you reach a maximum score threshold.

Balance and PvP balance in particular are always in a sorry state and rotate around 1 or 2 particular playstyles being immensely overtuned.

Open world PvP is dead due to there being no reason to partake in it, even influence races boil down to entire companies running quests and avoiding combat due to this being the most effective route to victory. Devs promised to fix this in maybe 6 months lmao.

Next expansion in summer 2024 may bring the experience closer to where it should be/used to be but right now its dogwater. 3/10

Talk about the best game that never was. Has all the things to make it the best MMO. 
What it needs asap:

New multiplayer modes. How long can you play the same map over and over again? Who knows I guess we will see. It would be simple to repurpose assets that exist currently, say like Myrkguard. Make an instanced version and bam, new map.

More detailed events. Bro why is this not a thing? Its the most cliched gameplay when it comes to events. Kill X and obtain X trade it in for X, unless you already did it last year then do what youve been doing already because the event doesnt really give you much more.

The dungeons are nice and very thought out. They are challenging where they should be and have the right elements. But the pve is lacking. But It would be simple to update some of the older content to be at level with current level cap. Each week feels empty once you are geared. SImplest patch to gear for btw.

They are trying with the story but bro come on. Story matters, Flesh it out. Lore is a requirement to world building. Even after going through main questline I felt like a bystander helping rather than an adventurer conquering the obstacle.

I think AGS has a pretty steady release schedule when it comes to patches and whatnot but some things need hotfixes. Like some weapons are overpowered and tend to stay that way for far too long. A good for instance is in  the current comp a firestaff user can wear heavy armor and still be ridiculously effective whereas other classes become mediocre when put into heavy armor making them far too strong and almost forcing others to play the same broken class to compete. 

War loggers have ruined wars for everyone. The folks who run in wars rarely log on for any other content and basically pidgeonhold the experience. They play on multiple servers and only log on to play the wars. Winning the wars are extremely profitable leaving them with excess amounts of gold to gear their war parties making the gap between a new war company and their company immense. The entire process seems intimidating since it is players that hold the keys to this content. Some companies are able to hold multiple zones due to the use of shell companies that funnel the gold back to one company. This is broken. I have no idea what AGS can do to fix it but it needs a hard rework. 

Thats it. ITs a good game so Ill still give it the recommend, but I wish there was more to it.

[h3]TL;DR: Games good, give it a whirl[/h3] 

[b]Pros[/b] 
Early Game: The levelling process has been refined and improved since the release of ‘New World’. It’s far more satisfying and streamlined – albeit I tend to skip dialogue.

Combat: The combat is probably my favourite part of the game, it feels more rewarding and skill based than your typical ‘Tab Target’ games. The weapon selection is quite generous and fun to use, all of which feel unique and different. There are some slight balancing issues which don’t seem to be addressed timely.

Visuals: The visuals in the game are stunning, and generally really help with immersion in the game.

PvP: The PvP, hand in hand with the combat is really fun and rewarding as well, positioning, and knowledge regarding abilities and loadouts add another layer.

Endgame*: I think the current endgame content is great, with some selection to make the game more enjoyable:
a)	PvP: 3v3 option / Large scale / and encouraged open world PvP (Races)
b)	Expeditions: Plenty of these to do, with enhanced versions
c)	Chest Runs: Doing chest runs with loads of other people is good fun
d)	Artifact Farms

Trade Skills: All the trade skills are useful and play a part in the game.

[b]Cons[/b] 
Armour: Armour balancing needs adjusting, if you get someone knowledgeable enough with the gear, they can tank about 5 people, with a healer, they’re able to tank half an Outpost Rush team.

[i]Suggestion: Change damage increase from light armour to armour bypass/penetration, or potentially add mods into gear – where other mods are sacrificed, this obviously won’t be as effective on light – medium armour, but vs heavy armour could provide a reasonable counter.[/i] 

*Endgame: While the quality of the content is enjoyable and good, I think there are opportunities for improvement.

[i]Suggestion: Introduction of (a) raid(s) (Not just killing a giant worm) that require a 10 – 20 player team.[/i]

I first played this game in 2021 and quit around level 30 because it was just too grindy.  The level of player customization was impressive, but It took too long to level up (player rank, skills, weapons, everything).  It also felt like the game play was made up of running all the way to one end of a territory and back just to get another quest running all the way back to the location you just left.  SO. MUCH. RUNNING.

I recently started playing again, and the experience in 2023 is MUCH better. The game is no longer just a running simulator. There are more quests and a better developed story.  Leveling is much more balanced. 
 They've also implemented some quality of life changes like allowing access to player goods in storage sheds no matter where on the map you are.  This is a game I can tell I'll be happy devoting my time to.

Review in progress:

At 40 hours admittedly I haven't reached end-game, nor have I purchased the expansion.  I've really enjoyed running around the zones exploring and harvesting, and what I've seen of the crafting is good.

Combat is ok, but not mind-blowing.  Quests are a mixed bag and the main plot is...somewhere between muddled and forgettable.  

With no required sub, is it worth $15 on sale? If you like exploring and mining/gathering, absolutely.  Thus the thumbs up.

Will I put 1,000 hours into this game compared to other MMO/survival alternatives? Probably not, but perhaps that's actually healthier, IDK.

As an MMO veteran that yearns for the good ol' days, this game is a good time. Not all what I want in an MMO, but it does a lot right. Crafting and gathering are meaningful, it rewards exploration, the combat is mostly pretty tight. The endgame is very much based around gathering your Best In Slot from various sources and then conquering all of the content. If you're tired of the usual grind, this is a good game to get into. The community is mostly pretty supportive (at least on Lilith) and you're bound to meet some interesting characters; as the party finder is pretty archaic and forces you to get involved with the community (I'm the rare sort that thinks that's a good thing). The combat is simple, and has great action components but not necessarily easy to master; you'll find some fairly challenging solo content as well as group content. My biggest gripe is that the quests are very standard fetch and "kill x amount of mob" quests. If you have some cash laying around and are interested to try something a little unique, it's worth a go.

Don't worry, I still hate Bezos, but the dev team is on to something here.

The game COULD be fun, but there are so many glitched quests, bad level designs, and zero storyline. This game felt super rushed from day 1 and every update and patch since then has been to try and fix the hundreds of game breaking issues that were in the game during beta, that they didnt have time to fix. Here we are 3mo later, and many of the glitches and broken questlines are still in the game.

I was really curious about how the the company system was going to work. In theory, it sounds like a cool, interesting idea. But it doesnt take into account how entitled/selfish humans are. Companies have a lot of power, and there are no checks or counters to things the company leaders decide. It was a cool idea that doesnt work in execution.

***Updated 12/29/2023***
Well figured it was time to update this review (Steam kept asking me to) What can I say, the game still suffers from the same problems it always has.  In addition now it feels like nothing you do has any true meaning or reward.  BIS gear is simple to get now, Gold is easy to get, crafting is still bad, PVP is a joke, PVE is redundant. Companies are pointless as there is nothing to work towards togetherv(wars are a joke and usually just win traded or merc'ed out).  Was the original game and xpac worth the money, yes, do they have any staying power, HARD NO.

Played the game since initial launch. It's been a real mess and continues to be so.  I am currently on one of the most populated servers (EDEN), level 60, farmed my GS and Expertise to 590 and have good gear/weps (597 avg) with the right combo of stats and perks also have a full crafted Voidbent set (600 GS) for general content. I have basically participated in just about everything the game has to offer (outside of the new "Mutations") which are basically just a rehashing of current expeditions marketed as new content with the only real new mechanic being fire on the ground....

I have maybe played 30 minutes the past week because, well the game is just boring and still very broken.  They refuse to fix basic issues like desync and weapon imbalance.  When 30-40 out of 50 people in wars are running VG/IG, well there might be a problem.  They ask what the community wants and do the exact opposite.  As a player, I was able to weather all the various bugs and exploits and nonsense that came with this game the first few months, but at this point it's clear that the general direction of this game is moving away from what its player base wants.  Based on that fact, I simply am not able to recommend this game to anyone.

I love this game. Easily my most played game on Steam. Over 2200 hours so far and I play every day. Always something to do whether running around and gathering materials and crafting or doing 40 v 40 outpost rush battles at 3am. The game is less than a year old and gets better with each patch.  It's much better than when I started in November of 2021 and it was already great then.  

Best of all? Unlike WoW or ESO no classes! You can be a mage one fight and a heavy armor tank the next or a nimble bowman after that by quickly changing your gear and moving your points around. 

And it is gorgeous. I highly recommend it.

Only have about 5-6 hours in and it seems well enough. I never jumped in when it first came out because I knew there was a TON of bugs and issues. Seems to have all worked itself out. For the most part. I did have a HARD crash at about the 3 hour mark. Still, other than that, no issues. Game play is the same MMO grind in any other game. Combat is about the same. There doesn't seem to be a "lock-on" ability so that's kind of annoying. Especially since they advertise the combat as "fluid" and it's anything but that. Sure, you can dodge and roll and block but other than that it doesn't serve any big purpose. I guess if you get much higher levels that block may help. Or not. I don't know. It's still decent enough. No MMO has ever made it into territory that combat is aces. Not a single one. 

Crafting really seems to be the heart of this game though. Pretty much every single starting quest is to familiarize yourself with crafting and collecting basics. Helpful enough I guess. Crafting does seem to be very deep and involved so that's a plus. On the downside there's hardly any gear made for people 0-35. It's all top tier stuff and level based, so, meh. 

It isn't breaking any ground in the graphical department either. Many other MMOs LOOK and play much nicer. Even with everything cranked to the highest my 3080 looked at the game sideways and was wondering if it was gonna start something. It didn't. Still, it isn't ugly and it doesn have some really good level and set design happening in the earlier areas. 

If you are thinking about jumping on board it is FUN. It's EASILY worth the $15 asking price on sale right now. If you (or me) can't get that amount of enjoyment out of it we should probably quit MMOs in general. Just sayin. LOL.

I was pretty positive about this game at the start and like everything that I came across. I just simply don't understand why so many other players are so negative about this game and now I know why. 

This game has alot of design that is toxic on the players. Those design punish the players for no reason.

Take for example, the artifact. You have to kill many strong mobs/bosses to unlock the perks on the artifact. After that, you have to use a lot of money to upgrade the artifact. And if you don't upgrade it (because you love all the default perks and don't want to spend tonnes of $ to upgrade to a perk that you don't like compared to the default one), and you abandon the quest (to upgrade it), you lost all the perks on the artifact you work so hard for. And you just lost tonnes of hardwork with a single click without any warning. There is no in-game warning that you gonna lost a lot of hardwork and to double confirm you click. No warning at all. 

Why then you need to abandon those artifact quest? Because there is cap of 5 such quests. And if you already reach the max cap, you cannot unlock the perks for the 6th artifact you collected. So you are forced to upgrade your first 5 artifacts whether you like it or not. 

There a lot of other games that make you feel good and powerful in-game. This game is not one of those. In fact it do the opposite to make you feel sad. The more you play, the more you suffer. This game makes you feel small. I am already at max gear score of 700 and there are many difficult quests and mobs that I still cannot defeat. It is not about group play. There are many difficult soul trials fighting difficult boss that are part of the main quest line that you have to complete solo without any grouping. So what do you want me to do? I already reach the max BIS slot gear on every slots and I still feel difficult to play this game and cannot progress the main quest line. BTW I eventually cleared those soul trial but with a lot of tries and frustration and suffering along the way. I feel so frustrated playing this game than feeling challenged and entertained.

There are a lot of other games that will make you happier and entertained. Not this one. This game inflict more suffering than entertainment and enjoyment. Therefore I don't recommend it unless you are a self-sadist yourself.

Steve Swink, the author of the seminal book "Game Feel: a Game Designer's Guide to Virtual Sensation", would approve this game. Visual artists would appreciate the World and its lush environments too (and the Crytek devs might learn a thing or two about optimisation from it). MMORPG.com rated highly the game after its DLC release, so I decided to give it a go. It's a pleasing and relaxing game to the point of feeling like a holiday (especially my main high-octane MP competitive game). The gathering and crafting are the best I have encountered so far - no button smashing for half an hour or anything, just press a button and wait a few seconds. Fighting requires some skill but it's on the easier side. The critique of mounts and other "nice things" being behind the paywall are not entirely fair because it doesn't have subscription (unlike FFXIV or EVE) but still needs funds for the further development. And no GOTCHAs like in other popular MMOs these days - all fair and square. Do I recommend it? Yes, because I am also betting on this game's future - I believe it will progress from "very good" to "great" (keeping my fingers crossed).
[EDIT] I went ahead and learned about [url=https://www.aboutamazon.com/news/entertainment/meet-the-developers-behind-the-amazon-games-hit-new-world]the NW developers[/url] - they are young, they are learning, they are listening to critique, and they are adapting fast. I think, that's the reason why the game evolved from "meh" to "real good" relatively quickly, and it has the real potential of becoming a great long-lived game.

While the game shows promising potential, its management by Amazon leaves much to be desired. Despite numerous assurances, the execution falls short consistently. If you enjoy games where specific specifications are paramount, leading to occasional exclusion from parties due to not adhering to the latest meta, then perhaps this game aligns with your preferences. Additionally, if you have a penchant for exhaustive grinding without tangible rewards, coupled with a season pass that leans heavily towards a pay-to-win model, this game could catch your interest. Furthermore, investing significant time in crafting might seem enticing initially, but you'll soon realize the limited utility of your creations, especially when sharing with friends becomes a challenge. 

Proceed with caution when considering New Worlds.

I recently ventured into the world of New World, and to my surprise, the experience has been nothing short of addictive. As a dedicated console player, the transition back to PC gaming has often felt cumbersome, but New World has effortlessly drawn me back into the realm of mouse and keyboard.
While I initially hesitated to dive back into PC gaming, New World has not only reignited my interest but also set a high standard for what an MMORPG can achieve. The addictive blend of exploration, combat, and social interaction makes it a standout title in the genre. If you're on the fence about trying New World, take the plunge – you might find, as I did, that it's a gaming experience worth getting hooked on.

Initially I gave this a thumbs down and I still think the reasons are valid but at 40(now 300+ at edit) hours of game play not including alpha time after waiting for it to mature for a year. Then I give it a hesitant thumbs up.

It's still a soulless game that breaks no new ground. The combat is immensely satisfying. They made a beautiful world. The soundscape is really good. The atmosphere is middling-good. The ambiance is great. The questing system is a baked turd and the story is annoying(Get outta my head lady)). If you are looking for a time sink in between the next great mmorpg then getting this on sale is worth it.

Sure i had to pay an extra 40$ to make it an enjoyable experience, but it is indeed more enjoyable now. The mount physics and speed are done well enough once you upgrade the mount system thru in game quests.
There are still imbalances to weapons but i can overlook that for now. Probably bothers max lvl people entrenched in endgame progression/pvp alot. It'll get changed eventually. Updates seem to be a bit of a slow progressing along but they do come (sometimes making things worse....to be honest).

And the new appearance system is actually quite good. You can get cpl transmog tokens each season for free or drop a few bucks for extra. There isnt alot of choices that are good appearance-wise so you wont be needing many. Unlocking one is account wide and added to wardrobe same as outfits were before.
But now you can look the way you want....forever.

RO
Grafica de înaltă calitate: New World impresionează cu peisaje uimitoare și detalii grafice remarcabile, creând o experiență vizuală captivantă.

Sunet ambiental deosebit: Sunetul jocului contribuie semnificativ la atmosfera sa. Sunetele plăcute și bine adaptate completează perfect experiența de joc.

Sistem de gathering captivant: Procesul de adunare a resurselor devine o parte integrală a experienței de joc, aducând o dimensiune suplimentară și un sentiment de implicare în lumea virtuală.

Comunitate activă: Datorită popularității sale, New World oferă o comunitate activă. Pentru misiuni dificile, se poate forma rapid un grup de jucători, încurajând cooperarea și interacțiunea socială.

Sistem de luptă captivant: Sistemul de luptă oferă un echilibru între provocare și accesibilitate. Nu este ușor să înfrunți monștri, dar nici imposibil. O schimbare binevenită pentru cei obișnuiți cu stilul de joc "1-hit, kill".


Concluzie:

New World oferă o experiență de joc captivantă, cu o grafică remarcabilă și un sunet ambiental de calitate. Sistemul de gathering și lupta echilibrată adaugă elemente de strategie și implicare, iar comunitatea activă contribuie la atmosfera vibrantă a jocului. Cu îmbunătățiri continue și expansiuni de conținut, New World promite să rămână o destinație atractivă pentru pasionații de MMORPG-uri.

EN
High-Quality Graphics: New World impresses with stunning landscapes and remarkable graphic details, creating a captivating visual experience.

Exceptional Ambient Sound: The game's sound significantly contributes to its atmosphere. Pleasant and well-adapted sounds seamlessly complement the gaming experience.

Engaging Gathering System: The process of resource gathering becomes an integral part of the gaming experience, adding an extra dimension and a sense of involvement in the virtual world.

Active Community: Due to its popularity, New World boasts an active community. For challenging missions, a group of players can quickly form, encouraging cooperation and social interaction.

Captivating Combat System: The combat system strikes a balance between challenge and accessibility. It's not easy to face monsters, but it's not impossible either—a welcome change for those accustomed to the "1-hit, kill" gameplay style.

Conclusion:

New World offers a captivating gaming experience with remarkable graphics and high-quality ambient sound. The gathering system and balanced combat add elements of strategy and involvement, while the active community contributes to the game's vibrant atmosphere. With ongoing improvements and content expansions, New World promises to remain an attractive destination for MMORPG enthusiasts.

The game itself is a lot of fun...a lot of room to grow, yes, but fun.

The queues? Those are inexcusably bad. You would sincerely think that a company that manages IT infrastructure via AWS and is one of the most resource-rich companies on the planet...and which has had a very long time to stress test and plan...would have a better answer than they have. Being stuck in queues for hours and not able to play with your friends, getting randomly booted from the queue hours in and having to go to the back of the line? Those are definitely reasons why I've completely reversed my opinion of the game for the time being. 

I cannot recommend the game in the state it is in today.

---

UPDATE: This game has seen VAST improvements. Lots of quality of life improvements: mounts, cheaper fast travel, improved queues, fewer client-authoritative decisions, etc.. Moreover, they have added a lot of story and season pass content which gives daily activities to complete, both of which instill more sense of "purpose" in playing the game.

My main remaining complaints are: 

1) You really need to play this game on an SSD, otherwise you will notice massive disk activity leading to lag spikes when you enter towns.

2) If you want certain pieces of gear, expect to run the same instance ad nauseum. We've repeated the same instance 10x and still not seen a piece I wanted drop. They really need to have some kind of "mercy" system in play. I'm all for replayability, but 10x starts to become a slog.

3) We need more dynamic open world content: more open world boss spawns, or even just things for color.

4) Some of the bugs that crop up are perplexing for a big player like Amazon. For instance, my entire access to the expansion zone was inexplicably reset with an update and I had to redo the quest that opens it back up and reaquire all the POIs. It wasn't a massive inconvenience, but it's annoying when things like this happen.

5) Maybe I'm just doing it wrong, but PvP seems pretty unbalanced. Certain weapon and gear combos absolutely dominate others and it's not a paper-rock-scissors sort of thing. Fortunately, you don't have to participate in PvP if you don't want to.

Let me start off by saying that mounts being paid was not the best. I have owned this game since the beginning (yeah the hours are low, but I'm starting more now) and the devs promised mounts from pretty early on. Paywalling it was not the move.

Besides that, I think in its current state, NW is a good MMO to buy. The game looks good, it feels good, the combat is very solid. Story is fun, the sound design is terrific. I could spend hours chopping trees because it is just so satisfying. Idk, but it just scratches the right itch for me when it comes to an MMO. 

I do think the lands are a bit barren, not enough POIs besides the same cookie cutter settlements. There needs to be matchmaking for dungeons as it just does not exist, you have to message in chat and wait. 

Its solid, and with updates and improvements, this game could be the best MMO.

Previous review: 
I LOVED this game, but now I feel like I wasted my time. This game is fun garbage. Levels 1-60 is a fun grind. After 60, nothing makes sense. 

I was hoping for this game to bring me back to my WoW days...and it did for a time. Levels 1-60 are that boring grind that I absolutely love. Questing is weird because you can't share quests, so making friends and questing is out of the question.

Then there are the bugs. So many bugs and weird glitches. One thing is fixed, another breaks.

Then there is the PVP. This is why I wanted an mmo. I want to play the pvp games. The pvp game is called outpost rush and it is the worst thing I've ever played. Again things happen that don't make sense. For example, you have to kill a powerful ghost on the island to "lock" out the other team from scoring points for several minutes. first team to damage the ghost most and kill it gets the perk. Our team runs in, kills the other team attacking the ghost (who only damaged it 25%), finished killing the ghost, and somehow our point bar gets locked instead of theirs. NOTHING IN THIS GAME MAKES SENSE.

Don't waste your time. It was a fun idea...an MMO without a subscription, but this is the definition of "you get what you pay for".
Dont buy it!!  has ZERO anti cheat .tons .aimbotters . exploits.. all day.  ZERO pvp content added from launch well over a year almost 2.

SO... We are now in S4, little background story to this. I played this game on release and it has made an improvement over the years. Adding mounts (must pay), more content, etc. Here is my unbiased critique. This game has had the potential to be good, unfortunately it gives no alternative  to middle ground resources.. its a ladder, must get that to make that to make this to make that but oh you need this resource you can get on the market or farm from chest around the map that will take hours... I spent a lot of time on life skills and it is just not worth it. 

PVP; I love pvp and well this is the thing you give you option slots to load your build, which is really nice. Though if you playing anything but an overpowered build, your screwed. You have to have heartgems, you have to have certain perks or people will just live forever. Combat takes a very long time, and thats because even in this new update healers are overpowered. Healers in my maybe biased opinion are just ovoerpowered. I had 10 guys on a healer, they just soak it up because they heal so much, instant healing with pots, skills, and perks. Its crazy that they are a light build soaking up damage. Healers do dedicate alot of time to just healing but on the side also have to potential to put out damage. 

In short, dont waste your time this game keeps updating and "" BALANCING "". PVP is broken, life skill takes foreverr with really little positive return. Mounts I believe are pay wall locked and SEASON PASS IS PAY TO WIN. If you got money in your pocket you can just out right buy the whole season, get over 20k gold and unlock better items, potions, gypsum for gear, etc.. I would rather play BDO and thats a hard pill to even swallow. At least with that P2W I can get better benefits. The P2W is more like faster progression in this game nothing ground breaking. Besides the potential of just out right buying your gear or better gear.

This is a fun casual MMO best enjoyed as a comfortable, low-stakes grind while you consume other media on a second screen.

The combat is fairly engaging, having an active style that feels like a mix of Elder Scrolls Online and a Souls game (without the difficulty). I appreciate the inclusion of trade skills, as it makes my lizard brain happy to watch numbers go up while cutting trees, mining ores, etc.

I personally find the lore uninteresting and mash through all quest dialogue, simply following the objectives, and I enjoy it well enough that way. I also play Final Fantasy XIV so all my "reading and caring about story" effort goes there.

There's not really an area where New World stands out as exceptional, it's just comfort food gaming and I appreciate it on that level. The dumbest thing is that they locked being able to use a mount behind the most recent expansion, which is way overpriced for what it adds.

The absence of growth extends beyond the incomplete state of the game and its reliance on DLC. In particular, the PvP sections exhibit zero progress, with the same three game modes persisting long after the game's release. This stagnant PvP landscape further highlights the shortcomings of the development team. The focus on lore and thematic elements, to the detriment of content execution, is evident not only in PvE  but also in PvP, where innovation and expansion are notably lacking.

Sadly, this deficiency in evolving PvP content adds another layer to the overall disappointment. The developers' reluctance to draw inspiration from successful MMOs like World of Warcraft extends to both PvE and PvP, leaving players yearning for a more dynamic and engaging gaming experience. As the game leans heavily on its initial promises of uniqueness, it falls short in delivering a comprehensive and satisfying gaming environment, both in terms of player-driven narratives and competitive gameplay.

Buy this game and the expansion in a sale. It is worth it.
It probably was one of the better game purchases I have done in a very long time. 
I bought games that were more expensive but played for less time. I still have not started the expansions quests by this time, plenty of stuff that keeps me busy for now. Take your time and enjoy the game from the beginning, don't rush through it.

The game is not perfect, but there probably aren't many perfect games out there these days.
The sound and graphics quality is amazing. The combat is great. The classless system is great. 
The story is ok, but do not buy this for this story is what I would say.

Will the game still be entertaining after 500 or 1000 hours? Maybe not, but by then the purchase price was well worth it.

Will you be able to keep playing this forever without purchasing more expansions? No, if they want to keep this game running for 10years they need some form of income to maintain it. But if you still like the game, why not buy the next expansion and keep playing it? If not, well then enjoy what you purchased now.

I am deeply troubled by the current direction of the game's monetization strategy. Not only does the game already cost 40 Euros, but now essential gameplay features such as mounts, max level gear, and specific quests are locked behind an additional 30 Euro DLC. This approach feels particularly unfair given the game's declining player base. It seems like these paywalls are being implemented at a time when the game is struggling, which only exacerbates the problem and further alienates the remaining players. It's disappointing to witness a game with so much potential resorting to such exploitative monetization practices, especially when it is already suffering from a decreasing popularity

The worst game I've bought in a long long time. 
Let's see here:
1. Became unresponsive and crashed on FIRST LOADING, even before opening main menu of the game. 
2. Commands like dash-right wouldn't work during the tutorial boss fight.
3. After beating tutorial, the first spawn place - my commands/keys just became unresponsive. All except enter, at which point I could chat with fellows around me at least since when in chat, my keys worked just fine. 
4. After restarting the game, waiting another queue, I started playing finally. What happened next will shock you - I was getting stuck behind stuff in game, just cause I wanted to explore the world, seems like jump wouldn't trigger at correct times and would be severely laggy, but not in the server way just as in command for jump wasn't being received even. 
5. Hitboxes were shit, if enemy is at even a slight height from me - no way I can hit that with any sword. 
6. Even on sale, ain't worth the price, because for final complaint - the graphics, which I don't really mind all that much if the trees looked even slightly better. But no. On very high settings I'd expect lights, shadows, particles - none of that. 

Overall, very very negative experience. And this is the first time I've ever been pissed while writing a review. So, my advice - go play something that works honestly.

New World is the first real prospect you enjoy after getting out of your long term commitment to WoW or GW2. New World is better looking, and has much more potential. It is ambitious, and redefines your idea of this type of fun. It feels great. But after a little while, the fact that they're a bit young starts to cause problems. At first it wasn't a big deal, but as time goes on you notice them making mistakes and while its clear they're in a period of discovery and growth, you can't help but compare them to your previous commitment which is long past this phase of trial and error. 

You take some time apart from New World, but there's not much else out there that can compete. You have a whirlwind romance with ESO or some Warhammer Fantasy CoOp, and a couple years later New World looks good. They say they've grown. You give it another try. And while its clear they're a little better, they've grown in a direction you don't particularly enjoy. Its different from what you hoped for, not quite what you two originally talked about. 

You keep things going a bit longer, but its probably not going to work out long term. You start searching online for something new behind its back; it feels like both of you are just waiting to really give up on this.

Search all reviews and you'll find many with similar time in-game have a similar negative recommendation, for a whole host of reasons.

My two top reasons: 
1) Every update seems to introduce new issues and that takes a number of patches to iron out. 

2) Paid updates also introduce significant headaches. They are relatively expensive and I expect better performance and functionality. But almost without fail, those updates change the overall strategy, regardless of play style and add significant technical issues.

Editing my review because it's pretty disappointing once you get to "end game". A lot of this stuff is on google, but I kind of figured "eh, it can't be that bad". 

The PvP part of this game is just... bad. If you want to only PvE, then this review is not for you. But if you want to only PvE, idk why would play this game either, when ESO and WoW have way more PvE content than NW. 

I'm here to say that I wouldn't recommend this game, because of the state of PvP. 

There 5 ways to PvP: OPR, Arenas, Wars, overworld while flagged for it, and Influence races.

Wars don't matter for what seems to be at least 90% of players. Only 50 people participate in a war on each side at a time, and a lot of good war players have multiple accounts, and do wars across regions, even. Just assume you won't get into a War. 

Influence races are technically PvP, but they are only at specific times. Not great for people who plan their game time around their lives in my opinion. 

Overworld while flagged is just what it sounds like, pretty meh. Most people won't flag, it's not worth the effort usually. Flagging gives PvE bonuses, so I'm guessing that most flagged people, aren't really interested in PvPing anyways. 

There are 2 Arena maps, and only one in circulation at a time. So you get 1 3v3 Arena map for weeks at a time. 

There is only 1 OPR map! 1! Who cares if you're good at PvP when the primary mode only has 1 map?

Just don't buy this game or the expansion imo. I got time into it, sure, but if you have $70 to spend, there are other titles out there worth the money more. 

The devs could fix all of this by balancing certain weapons/armors, and by adding PvP maps. This game should have a lot more maps for how big it is.

Reviewing mmorpgs is always a hard task.
now i'm over a hundred hours in and feel like i can write at least a halfway informed one.

I like the gathering a lot even if it's quite hard to farm sometimes.

the action combat feels amazing and some perks for your weapons improve these skills aswell (like applying weakness on top of poison through the poison cloud arrow)

the story isn't the best i have ever seen or anything but the characters were likable and well voiced

the pvp has a level system and there are faction races for controll of an area and guild can take controll of citys and start town missions that improve crafting stations.

crafting is ok. you have the resources and you craft the objects. there are some objects with which you can apply buffs or define perks

overall i like the game and would recommend it.

New World: Aeternum's Unintentional Hero. In my attempt to become a legendary warrior, I've discovered a knack for inadvertently befriending every dangerous creature in sight. From accidentally taming a bear to negotiating a truce with a rival faction through interpretive dance, my journey is a comedy of unintended alliances. Who knew that mistaking a boss for a dance instructor could lead to a server-wide conga line? New World, where the path to greatness is paved with unintentional heroics, and the real adventure is the laughter along the way.

I enjoyed World of Warcraft the first time around.

The *real* content is the PvP, but it's numerically unplayable until you hit max level, and now that max level is behind a $30 paywall.

Most servers end up with everyone jumping on the bandwagon of whichever faction with the most land, because when you're not in your faction's territory, you pay more for basic utility services.

New World's creation is a case study in Sunk Cost fallacy. Amazon Game Studios went through a rotating door of massively overpaid creative directors and design leads and it shows.
It's original story line (the heart of any RPG) was ripped out and replaced with a forgettable grind of kill/collect quests.
If you want what the original vision/story, go play Greedfall. 
It's shameful that they want $30 for the Rise of the Angry Earth expansion, when it's just $30 of polish on a turd.
Basic quality of life improvements like mounts and a new weapon class, should have been added in a update,but the base game map is too small for mounts.
How are they still charging $40 for the base game?

New World is what lowest common denominator design looks like.
Enemies are cut, paste, and recolor. That was normal back in 2004, but not 20 years later.
The most exciting moment I've had recently, was the other day I ran into a "new" enemy. It turned out to be a re-skinned wolf with the same 3 attacks.
The player animations are weird. I dare a reasonable person to watch any of the video's and tell me the running animation looks like it was created after 2005.   
It's a game about sailors, but they can't swim.
It's a game about colonists, but they have no one to colonize.
It has 3 warring factions, but every player has the same backstory and tutorial, so there's no reason for 3 factions.
As of Dec 2023, still no mail system.
It's a Skinner Box designed to keep you mindlessly grinding.
As of Dec 2023, NW is now a 75GB, which makes it larger than Black Desert. How does NW have 1/10 the content and still be a larger file?

NW is Amazon's gateway to Prime Gaming and Twitch.

New World invites players into a breathtaking, ever-evolving world ripe for exploration and adventure. Set in the lush and mysterious land of Aeternum, the game captivates with its stunning visuals and a richly detailed environment that encourages discovery at every turn.

What sets New World apart is its dynamic gameplay, offering a diverse range of activities. From harvesting resources and crafting items to engaging in epic battles against both supernatural threats and other players in PvP combat, the game caters to various playstyles. The compelling blend of traditional MMO elements and a focus on player agency, where individual choices impact the world around them, creates an immersive and engaging experience.

The game's emphasis on territorial control and faction-based conflicts in a player-driven economy adds depth and excitement, fostering a sense of camaraderie and competition among players. Furthermore, the continuous updates and developer support demonstrate a commitment to refining and expanding the game, ensuring that the world of Aeternum remains vibrant and full of opportunities.

New World's promise of adventure, exploration, and dynamic player interactions make it a compelling choice for MMO enthusiasts seeking a captivating and evolving virtual world to immerse themselves in.

I have played this game nearly everyday since launch. I really wanted to start a game from its infancy and see it evolve into a popular game and be one of the "OG" players. At the start there were a LOT of bugs, and gold/item duping. This is the first MMO I have ever played that shut down the trading between players and auction house, and they have done so on multiple occasions. After about a year and a half, things started to improve a little at a time. Season 1 and 2 were mostly enjoyable. 

However, Seasons 3 and 4 are getting significantly worse. Season 3 wiped the gear from all the prior gameplay. They made it significantly easier to get BiS gear, but significantly more difficult to make any money in the game unless you own territory which generates cash. Regular players struggled to make ends meet, the about of farming needed for materials for end-game crafting was exceeding 10 hours a day, and there was a daily money sink to get the items needed to craft necessary gear for end-game activities. On top of that, the best method of making money previously was selling gear drops from mutated expeditions, but they nerfed this so that almost every drop is now bound to the player and there is nothing to sell. It became a money sink to also do mutations because of the consumables required to do them. 

They also introduced races and have nearly wiped out invasions as they used to be done. The day-to-day gameplay is forced into specific 2-4 hour sections of the evening and you are no longer able to play how you want, when you want. If you want to push a territory, you can only do so for 45 minutes every 3 days at a specific time. Are you in Europe, Asia, etc? Too bad, you never get to do this content now. Want to do invasions? We only do them in large bulk 3 days on 3 days off, and half the time they are being reset or cancelled. As a strong company you can easily hold 6 territories and milk money from the server with this system as AGS has set a schedule for everything so you are never threatened by over exerting yourself. 

With the introduction of Season 4, not only was this the buggiest patch I think they never introduced, it had the least content of any major releases. They released new artifacts, which are just gear items that have additional perks. They released a new dungeon that is 10 minutes long, has the most boring end-game boss which is a re-skin of a previous boss, and features 2 extra bosses that also are just re-skins of previous bosses. The dungeon mechanics are just to run through, pull mobs into a clump, and kill them. It is brain dead, and boring. 

The only savior for Season 4 was the winter event, that they then nerfed so that players will have to log in every day to be able to get enough credit to be able to afford the rewards. This is their version of creating content and making their numbers appear higher. Many of my friends have stopped playing as the meta for pvp is absolute dogwater - everyone is in heavy and has infinite healing and/or CC so it is just a slap fest with no killing. 

Then they post a video of their roadmap for the next 6 months that has almost nothing on it that would be considered new content. There is nothing to encourage you to continue to play. This is like attending a school field trip where AGS holds your hand through all content, everything is strictly scheduled and there is no freedom of play.
nice good

I see a lot of "good" reviews for this game. I also see some have more playtime, and some less. I have approximately 330 Hours played. 
  Over the years i've come to realize that it doesn't matter how "good" or "bad" a game is, if the the "support" sucks, you're going to run into that as a big issues at some point, inevitably, and it will affect your gaming experience with that game. 
  I enjoyed (past-tense for a reason) the game, for the most part, though there were quite a few things about it that I had issues with, but they aren't my main source of annoyance in this review, nor my main point. 
 Support. I had, on several occasions, items simply disappear form my inventory. I contacted support, and the responses I received in return first off showed that they didn't even read my message. As a matter of fact, having dealt with MANY companies whom always seem to send some sort of "cookie-cutter" and pre-formatted response to your first message, I learned to TRY to prevent the first waste of time of their response, which makes me have to then tell them to "Go back, and RE-READ what I said, you obviously DID NOT," by adding in my email: "Please read carefully, and don't suggest the things i've already preemptively told you I have ALREADY tried, to solve the issue, Thank you." Does it help...?...Not really, and not often, but I try.  Back to the point. The first message was literally suggesting things like "check again," and "are you sure," and other such moronic suggestions, AND suggestions I LITERALLY added to my first message to tell them I ALREADY TRIED. 
  Then, I had to respond, point out that i've already attempted their suggestions, and that I explained that in my last message to them which is clearly documented, & then respectfully requesting that they go read it again. Then I get a response, essentially accusing me of lying. They didn't say I "lied," but their every comment was essentially telling me I must have lied. I don't need to say "You're a liar," to call you a "liar." So, I respond, by pointing out that i'm not fabricating, and actually have better things to do, and that it's not like i'm asking for money, I just want the items back that disappeared. 
  They respond confirming the items were in my possession, & that they are no longer there (well NO S%$T, Sherlock, that's why I contacted YOU, ffs. Wow.). I thought..."Good, so now we are getting somewhere." Nope. They at that point told me it must have been my fault, in some way, and that was essentially their final comment to me. 
  I responded, again explaining, and asking them to look into it. 
  At that point, all communication ceased, and they essentially told me to "Go F yourself." Not only the above, but it was as if each email ignored a large majority of what I had ALREADY explained, and as such required re-explaining, and re-typing, and trying, in vain, to get them to understand basic statements made. They either don't speak English in any meaningful and efficient way, OR they just don't care to deal with the issues their player encounter. 
  At that point, I uninstalled the game, and decided i'd not waste more of my time, & especially not any more money, on such horrible, useless, and trash "support." 
  You experience may vary, but this WAS my experience. Trying to get them to even understands, or read and acknowledge, was tantamount to trying to get a mentally-retarded, blind, deaf chimpanzee who was also just hit on the head with a hammer...to understand Astrophysics. It just didn't happen, and the end result was predictable. It's not the items, nor the game, it's the lack of logical, reasonable comprehension, communication, and acknowledgment in any meaningful way, followed by being called a liar, ignoring what I actually had thoroughly documented as what I had done to seek a resolution, then just silence and no responses. I've dealt with "burger-flippers" at McDonalds who had more investment in good customer support, than the people I dealt with in this game's "support" department. 
   If you have other games to play, or you don't mind HORRIBLE alleged "support," and possibly being called a liar repeatedly, then being ignored...buy this game. Otherwise, i'd suggest, strenuously, that you avoid the game, because at the end of the day, "good game" is pointless if when an inevitable issue arises, you have no chance to get to a successful "fix," because those responsible for such couldn't care less about your issue, and will do everything in their power to ignore, deny, insult, and then cease any attempt to help fix the issue. The issue was NOT on my end. It was with their game. Even if it were, their communication, and approach, was worthless, and horrible.
Edited to Add: There are MANY bugs, in this game. That happens, but it's the "Support" that makes the difference when it comes to whether the game bugs are able to be dealt with. Their "support" is almost non-existent, and what "support" they offer is nothing short of annoying, frustrating, and useless. If you're thinking about buying this game, just go to the nearest bridge, throw the amount of money you would have spent over the side, then hit yourself in the pubic are at least twice, and save yourself the pain and aggravation. Up to you...that's my suggestion. To each their own though...

I played a bit when it was originally released and quit due to issues at the time. Started playing again a couple of weeks ago and the game has changed a lot for the better.

I am enjoying it so far, the scenery is fantastic, graphics are beautiful. I love how you can chop most trees, mine most rocks, etc. in the game.

Combat is awesome, no classes, just equipped weapons. No restrictions on what kind of gear to use - light, medium, or heavy which changes combat style, but is viable with any weapon.

The game story is fantastic and almost fully voice-acted which is a huge plus as I hate reading quest logs.

There are a few negatives I've come across:
- while 90% of quests are voiced, some are missing. Some don't match with written text, some are missing a sentence...
- movement is quite scuffed at times
- no swimming
- snowing INSIDE buildings in the Great Cleave zone! (perhaps others too...)
- sometimes you get in-game cut-scenes or voiced dialogue without warning, with no option to replay or see subtitles. I've had this several times in the middle of combat, with no idea what the voice-over narrator said because they were drowned out by other noises.
- you can get attacked while speaking to NPCs. I like to listen for voiced narration, suddenly get interrupted because some NPC spawned...
- The Map can be very busy, with so many icons. Filters exist, but you need to toggle every type one by one... 
- Gear and their set bonuses are super unclear and confusing what said bonuses even do or what weapon peace of gear is for...

In conclusion the game is absolutely worth the money, I've had lot of fun and met amazing people in game. Really enjoying it so far.

Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me 3 times in 2 years, shame on me...

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Its pretty.
The sound is fantastic.
Gameplay is what you would expect.
Progression feels satisfying.   You get gear often, you get crafting materials often.  You FEEL like you're progressing.   The market is saturated enough for decent levelling gear to be cheap, unlike another mmo where it is the exact opposite.

The game could be great.  Unfortunately, I still can't recommend this game.

The problems I am encountering: 
In-game bugs that stop you from progressing the main story quest line.  Do understand that the MSQ opens up things to the player they're going to need at later levels.  You can go screw around doing other things, hit max level, and not discovered dungeons or actual equipment you need.   And these are self-inflicted bugs.   I also see people saying the house (the game has instanced housing, people decorate their house, etc.) they have been working on for years is now Empty.   Everything is gone.    On my second or third day playing, the server crashed 4 times in an hour.    Nothing like being in the middle of a big fight and...  dumped to character select.

Finding/Discovering Dungeons (or encoutners as they're called) - could be related to above?  Ive heard there is six or seven (surprisingly low number there) and people are saying one is broken.. I wouldn't know.   I can't seem to find them, get instructions on finding them, or progress the MSQ to the point of finding them.   That's pretty game-breaking.

The help channel shouldn't even exist, no one uses it or answers questions (and you will have plenty)

As with any MMO, the population will have a certain amount of toxicity - that is the nature of the beast.   With some the toxicity is low (BDO) and with some the toxicity is high (Rust).   This one lands in the middle, but leans more towards the high end..  I'd say 6.5 on a Ten Scale.   That is not to say there aren't helpful people.   You can find help outside of the game...  but you really shouldn't have to.  It should be explained better inside the game, and I shouldn't have to go to a Discord Channel for someone to explain the game to me.   That is the game's job, and it is pretty poor at it.

At the end of the day, the game is "okay" - It could be a LOT better, and with the big bank behind it (Amazon) you would think it would be supported better and not have as many bugs created by the developers and missed by QA (if QA Exists, I'm not sure it does).

My original review was a "no" because of stability and lack of any instruction on progression.  The stability (for me anyway) has been fixed.   The servers crashing has slowed quite a bit, but still happens once in awhile.  

But, I cannot being myself to say "yes" to this game, even now..  and it is a damn shame..  because this game could be so, so much better.

Also:

- Trash RNG loot system

- Movement is goofy
- Range hit registration is sometimes random 
- The game has platforming, couple that with the clunky movement... yeah
- Offroad mounting speed is frustratingly slow, why is that even a thing?
- Sooo much material gathering that is very irritating and gets in the way of the core gameplay
- Changing your attributes (for when you want to play different roles) costs in-game currency
- In general, the game is extremely repetitive
- For those who care about immersion breaking; the game heavily leans towards a "progressive" political tune. Examples like: 90% of the quest givers/important NPCs are all women, armor is not gender locked, you can literally wear a dress as a male character, and there's also a personal pronoun option that isn't visible to other players, not sure why that's even there.

There is no way a game like this survives back when the MMO genre was booming.
