I have nearly 1000 hours in this game, so this isn't a newb review, and it will be exhaustive, the good the bad and the ugly. This game is full of great ideas, poorly executed and then habitually destroyed. I will explain piece by piece.

Character Customization – it is better than some, but not by much. If you are looking for deep customization look elsewhere.

World - It is gorgeous with great attention to detail. The variety of plants and animals is extensive at first and then you will notice a theme. I do not know if they got lazy, rushed, or ran out of funding. But there is SO MUCH copy and pasting of structures with new paint slapped on throughout the world. Same houses in different cities, same structures and layouts in Elite Areas and Dungeons. Then NEW city they released in the paid expansion did not even bother to have different houses in the same city they are just the exact same house painted differently. Just pathetic.

Town Management - The idea of having to work to upgrade and maintain stations has the possibility of being cool and worthwhile. But they made it too easy and there are basically no penalties for losing control of the town and there is no point to even really fighting for it. Even most things you craft do not even need to crafted in high level benches. Great thought but poor implementation.

Housing - Coolish on the personal level, except the variety sucks from most cities to cities. With 10 cities only 6 different styles the other 4 are just recycles. Plus, they really need company housing or at minimum a company chest.

Questing/Dungeons/Soul Trials - The game started out rather good to be honest. The story was eh, but you had to team up to go through dungeons like a regular MMO. Later they added to the story and added Brimstone and when they did that, they gave an option to either go through a solo quest line or team up and go through the dungeons. This was an awesome idea, and it was implemented well. Then for some stupid reason when they released the newest expansion, they thought it was a good idea to completely make dungeons irrelevant to the main story line. The story side and main story only brings you through the first two dungeons and then one to complete the base games msq. It completely ignores 4+ dungeons the main story used to bring you through, now they are completely disjointed from the game. The main story and side story don't even bring you into half of the world’s zones. Then to top it off there are mini dungeons that they call soul trials that you must do solo. It is as if they tried to change all of the story into a solo player game. Bring back the options keep the solo soul trials for the people who want to play alone, but also give the option for a group dungeon.
Gathering - Some things are easy to get others, at times, feel impossible because of bots and lack of nodes.
Crafting - Too many worthless things to craft that nobody wants or buys. Some things take forever to level, and it seems like the developers want to force every crafter to max every type of crafting skill to be an effective crafter, for no reason. You can literally farm almost everything you could ever want in the entire with the exception of specific furniture, foods, and potions. Everything else you can get better, or good enough from farming mobs, mini bosses, or dungeons, everything drops. IMO crafting for the most part is worthless. 

Music – It is fun, the different songs are great, but the buffs don’t scale with difficulty. Great Idea – poor implementation

Mounts – Fun, well built. Races are fun till you complete them once, and then you are done. Races should be repeatable with tracked completion times. And speaking of races, they had difficult long races to complete at first, but nerfed them and made them for the newbs. No challenges left. 

The Expansion - Great, in concept, horrible execution. You can tell and see them make changes that show they intended the area to be a much higher difficulty than what it is now, and they constantly nerf the difficulty across the board. It could be a fun, challenging, group required mmo, that they turned into a novice difficulty solo player game in a mmo setting.

So, in summary – I can tell, this game is built on and has a bunch of great, poorly implemented ideas, often broken things that shouldn’t be broken, chests with no rewards, the random un-completable quest lines, randomly broken mechanics, disappearing furnishings and pointless foundational MMO game functions, i.e. crafting. It has the possibility of being great, but they keep breaking things that shouldn’t be broken and nerfing things that shouldn’t be nerfed. 

Can I recommend it, in its current, constantly degrading stage - Unfortunately no

[b]New World, Amazon's MMORPG, offers a fascinating yet divisive experience that comes with its set of advantages and disadvantages:[/b]
[list]
[*]Captivating World Design: The game boasts stunning visuals and immersive environments, creating a visually appealing open-world experience. (Pro)
[*]Intriguing Crafting and Economy: A robust crafting system and player-driven economy provide depth and engagement beyond combat mechanics. (Pro)
[*]Dynamic Combat Mechanics: Real-time action combat feels fluid and offers strategic depth, adding an engaging layer to the gameplay. (Pro)
[*]Territory Control and Factions: The territorial warfare and faction system offer a dynamic and competitive multiplayer experience. (Pro)
[*]Exploration and Quests: Exploring the vast world and undertaking quests initially feel engaging, though they may become repetitive over time. (Con)
[*]Grind and Progression: The grind-heavy progression and repetitive tasks might deter some players seeking a more casual experience. (Con)
[*]Server Queues and Stability: Periodic server queues and stability issues at launch have impacted the overall gameplay experience. (Con)
[*]PvP Balance Concerns: Some players have voiced concerns about the balance issues in PvP encounters, affecting fairness. (Con)
[/list]
[b][i]In summary, New World presents an enchanting world design, engaging crafting mechanics, and dynamic combat systems. However, it faces challenges in repetitive quests, grind-heavy progression, server queues, and PvP balance concerns, making it a divisive experience for players seeking a polished and less grind-centric MMORPG.[/i][/b]

This game has all the hallmarks of a great MMO. Great combat, great crafting, great objectives, great rewards. Despite this, the developers, time and time again, fail to release content on time, completely or otherwise. It is absolutely mind boggling that a game with so much potential is so hampered by failed or delayed content on such a consistent basis especially given the competition. I don't really have words for how disappointing it is to keep coming back and hoping it will be different but to be met with the same dogshit. 

I am going to continue playing, not because of the game, but because of the community I am in that makes it playable. DO NOT purchase this game if you are looking for a quasi-competive MMO, it is not worth it. 

I will say, however, it is a good game for the weekend gamer. If you only have so much time and aren't interested in getting BiS or doing high end content the game can be fun. Just be prepared for the fact that you will often times have to restart your game, google quest objectives to figure out how they can be done through their bugs, or deal with other inconveniences along the way. 

If it's not clear I care deeply for the game, not because of it, but despite it. I really just want it to be functional.

I hit lvl 65 at ~105 hours of playtime during leisurely play completing quests by zone. I found spending 10-20 coin every couple levels to buy weapons near my level (paying attention to deeps output) kept me killing in pve very satisfactory. Keeping armor and trinkets within 5 levels is still cheap at 10-50 coin per piece.  Now that I have hit max lvl ( with ~20k coin) my biggest expenditure has been lvl 65 cheapo gear from top to bottom ~4k coin. Bags for additional carry weight were an extra expense along the way. I have not partaken in PVP which I am saving for endgame content (getting my ass kicked and learning to kick their asses while talking to others about gear specs is endgame to me).  Meanwhile, having done all the above solo, I shall look for a company.

New World," developed by Amazon Games, invites players into a sprawling and visually stunning open-world MMO that combines exploration, crafting, and intense player-versus-player (PvP) battles. Set in the mysterious and supernatural land of Aeternum, this game offers a fresh take on the MMO genre, providing a dynamic and immersive experience for both solo and group adventurers.

One of the standout features of "New World" is its meticulously crafted game world. Aeternum is a diverse and breathtaking landscape, ranging from lush forests and towering mountains to eerie swamps and mystical ruins. The attention to detail in the environmental design creates a sense of wonder and discovery, encouraging players to explore every nook and cranny.

The game's emphasis on player agency is evident in its robust crafting and gathering systems. "New World" allows players to harvest resources, craft gear, and even build settlements. The economy is driven by player-driven markets, adding a layer of depth to the virtual society. The crafting system is intuitive, and the variety of available professions provides ample opportunities for specialization.

Combat in "New World" is action-oriented and engaging. Players can choose from a variety of weapons, each with its unique playstyle, and the real-time combat requires strategic thinking and skillful execution. The inclusion of a dynamic territory control system introduces large-scale PvP battles, where factions compete for dominance over key regions, adding a political layer to the game.

The game's character progression system offers flexibility, allowing players to mix and match skills from different weapon trees and specializations. This flexibility caters to various playstyles and encourages experimentation, ensuring that players can tailor their characters to suit their preferences.

"New World" also succeeds in fostering a sense of community. Joining a faction, participating in wars, and engaging in large-scale expeditions with fellow players contribute to a vibrant and social gaming experience. The inclusion of PvE content, such as corrupted breaches and powerful world bosses, adds variety to the gameplay and provides challenges for both solo and group play.

However, it's important to note that "New World" had a few issues at launch, including server queues and balancing concerns. Amazon Games has demonstrated a commitment to addressing these issues through regular updates and communication with the player base.

In conclusion, "New World" is a captivating and ambitious entry into the MMO genre. Its combination of stunning visuals, dynamic gameplay systems, and a player-driven world creates an immersive and engaging experience. While it faced some challenges at launch, the ongoing commitment to improvement and the potential for future content updates make "New World" a promising and exciting frontier for MMO enthusiasts looking to embark on a grand adventure.

OG:
Grindy, but not fun grind.

- Movement is brutal slow
- Animations are slow and clunky
- The jump is pointless
- Mantling is hit and miss and annoying
- Trade skill is a grind hidden inside a grind, sprinkled with grind with a side of grind
- PvP is annoying at best... If PvE is clunky, imagine PvP.
- Group combat is as previously stated by other reviewers a left click fest seasoned with occasional abilities...
- Want to grind a group dungeon for phat lewts or crafting mats?!... Well that means you'll need to grind harvesting, trade skills, faction quests and then corruptions for uncommon drops.  If you don't want to do all of that, you'll be like half the server population and stand by the dungeon entrance spamming "LF someone with key to [insert dungeon] then GTG!"
- Rare drop crafting mats from dungeons create worse gear than the random drop gear from the dungeon.  So you grind harvesting, grind trade skill, faction grind, and corruption grind... in order to grind dungeons for rare drops for crappier loot?  What in the actual f...

Healing, cause that's what i like to play...
- Aggro management for tanks is a mess and sketchy at best.  Abilities to reliably control mob aggro are severely lacking.
- DPS generally have no idea how to control aggro as everyone just spams max deeps all the time
- Healing aggro is too high for the healing rates even with aggro reduction gems
- Single target heals is a nightmare.  You have to use the scr.oll wheel to target party members.  Sure you can try to use the visual cue out on the battlefield, but its not easy to distinguish if you have the right person targeted in the melee ball at the mob's feet.  Its easier to use the party window for single heal targeting... However, The party member window is a tiny little list off to the far left of your screen so you're forced to take your eyes off of combat which means your not re-positioning mobs that have aggroed on you back into the tank's range, watching for boss big move tells, etc...

I'm still somewhat new to the game and I do not do PvP, but here's my opinion of the game so far.

Character creation: Agree with the others who say it's too basic and doesn't have enough options.  It feels like character creation from the 90's.  There definitely needs to be more options in order to make your character feel more unique rather than just another cookie cutter avatar among all the rest that practically all look the same.

Tutorial: Wish there was an option to skip the tutorial after the first time through.  It's feels more like a delay to letting you play the game than an actual tutorial.

Leveling: Doing the main story quest and other quests to level 40 feels a little grindy but overall it keeps your attention and is fun.  I did find that after lvl 40, it becomes ridiculously more difficult to survive.  I'll admit to not being a very good player when it comes to combat, which is why I avoid PvP, but having to play on maps that are 10 levels lower than your character level just to not die every fight gets annoying.  Just an assumption, but it seems the difficulty intentionally jumps drastically at lvl 40 in an effort to force players to group?  I have found myself discarding my beloved musket, hatchet and medium armor for heavy armor, sword and shield just in order to feel like I have a chance at completing quests at my level.

Resource Gathering and Crafting: I've enjoyed the gathering side of the game, lots of nodes available.  Unfortunately the game economy is a bit unusual.  Most materials are currently only selling for what amounts to pennies (fraction of a coin) each, while armor, weapons, etc. sell for hundreds or thousands of coins.  Gathering doesn't really seem to be a viable source of income at the moment.  I am still learning the crafting, but so far it seems pretty straight forward and not too difficult.  Though most of the beginner level crafting items aren't worth trying to sell on the market, pennies again.  They really should do away with the pennies, even selling something for 1 coin would feel better than .01 coin.

Housing:  There is a free house available in the early area, but after that it'll cost you 5k, 10k, or 20k coins to buy a house on each map.  So far I haven't really found a reason to waste my coin on buying one.  Especially when you move to different maps as you level up, essentially making the house you bought in a lower level map no longer useful.

Chat: Don't kid yourself into thinking you'll get a non-toxic response to a question in World Chat, but isn't that how most games are these days?  There are helpful players who will DM you to help if they see you need it in World Chat.  But the good news is, you can mute any chat channel you chose to.  World Chat was the first one I muted.  Lol.

Overall:  I have and still am enjoying the game and recommend it to others.  Like all games it has it's issues and downsides.  I have been lucky enough not to experience any bugs yet, other than an occasional having to kill something twice to get quest credit.

If you've had this game in your wish list wondering if you should, do it. You wont regret it.

Like many other games these days, New World was released about 1-2 years too early. It was unfinished and felt more like a beta than a complete game. However, I played on launch and loved it. I put about 200 hours into the game in the first four weeks. I ended up quitting the game for about a year due to the repetitiveness. A lot of the mobs were the same back then and the game lacked depth. 

I am writing this review at the end of 2023 going into 2024. The game is very different and much improved since its launch. The developers clearly listened to the criticism it got from its community and has churned out a well polished, wonderful MMORPG. I highly encourage any person who enjoyed New World on launch to come back to the game now. 

Some of my favorite things about New World are the combat mechanics, difficulty level of open world solo leveling, gathering & crafting materials, liveliness of the environment, soundtrack, visuals, and the overall ambiance of the world. If you're someone who enjoys getting lost in a beautiful game and challenging yourself with fighting monsters/demons, you will enjoy New World.

Things New World could improve on: Raids, Dungeons/Expeditions, Towns/Cities/Settlements, and the addition of aerial foes such as dragons, wyverns, hawks, eagles, vultures, wraiths, etc. 

New World is a unique game that has the potential to be one of the best MMORPGs on the market. A lot will hinge on their next major expansion. I hope we see another large zone added with diverse terrain and mobs as well as a unique settlement and endgame character to fight. Crossing my fingers.

New World is a fun MMO with real long term gaming potential, which is great, because I like dedicating myself to one MMO for many years at a time. Many features of the game are well thought out. My favorite feature is the housing with its useful trophy and storage attributes. I also enjoy the mounts. Seasonal and special events keep the game play fresh. While I tend to play PVE, I like that there are plenty of PVP options to try. Population density is managed well, which helps with PVP and in-game commerce. I usually play by myself, but I also play with friends and family. I hope this games last a long time and get even more popular. I look foreword to seeing how it develops. Game on!

I waited for a few years before jumping into New World and from what I've read, I'm glad I did.  Turns out there have been many changes to the game, most notably quality of life improvements, that have made the game much more fun to play.  I'm only 47 hours in to playing, but what I have played so far has been quite enjoyable.  The game can be quite difficult at times, especially if you play solo, but it's not impossibly hard. I have discovered in my experience when I have run into a difficult spot that I just couldn't beat as a solo player, I asked for help people were happy to comply.  

There is one thing in particular I feel I need to mention to those players that are not a fan of game focused on PVP.  While yes there is much end game content focused on PVP, you can play this game PVE and never have to touch PVP once, and still have a ton to do!

All in all I am glad I finally gave this game a try now, especially after the horrible launch it had.  I would recommend buying it when it's on sale and since it is a buy to play game with no monthly fee, you have nothing to lose except your initial purchase price.  I have seen the base game as low as $15, although I did choose to purchase the expansion as well which was not on sale at additional $40.  It seems to be well worth it, especially with the addition of mounts.  Back to the game!

Amazon is focusing on a lord of the rings MMO, which means there will be less or no more resources invested in this game.

Do not buy as there is a high chance of it being abandoned.

It is fun at first. 

Environment is pretty. There's a lot going on, and a lot to do. You can follow the story or explore. Multitudes of possibilities. 

The shine is lost quickly. The map is huge, like Fallout 76 huge, and you get XP for 95% of anything done. That's weird, because the level cap is 60 or 65 with DLC, and you can easily hit level 20-30 just messing around in the start zone. You pick up a lot of gear, but it's all junk. This becomes evident when you learn the route, head to the nearest town, and craft your own stuff with scant materials and no experience-you get weapons and armor that you won't receive as a reward for 15 or 20 levels. It's OP as hell but why not? There are ranged weapons! Muskets are cool looking AF, but they all suck. Except for some limited utility (game hunting) you will find that using them in combat is a frustrating slog. Every single melee weapon works-faster, more effectively, at much lower gear levels.

There are no passive skills I'm aware of. Weapons require skills to use effectively. You'll see "something cool" in every category, but it's surrounded by useless fluff. There are augments to skills-almost all of them are tied to the skill itself and do nothing, otherwise.

The respawn rate is bananas. The cool wildlife you see at the beginning becomes annoying AF quickly. God damn, spazzy wolves...you'll soon wish you could invest in animal repellent. There are at least 3 missions early on with crappy objective markers, tons of visual distractions, and constant respawning enemies. You are required to complete these missions, and you will not enjoy them.

Bought my copy for $15.99. I'd argue it's fair at $9.99, otherwise a horrible investment.

This game is good, but it probably has the dumbest MMO community of them all, and thats seriously saying something. 
I want to preface that this isn't coming off the backs of some salty sessions or a rage-out review, this is just honest thoughts after 1400 hours and talking to other players who've come to the same conclusion. 

I don't know what it is exactly about new world, but a huge swathe of the community are just complete lobotomites. They don't understand basic systems like threat or how to even build their character. 
Its genuinely jarring and weird how players can spend 20 hours playing the game to reach lvl 65, and have 0 grasp of the systems they've been interfacing with. 

The end game public PVE experience half the time, will consist of tanks wont run tank setups, healers who pull aggro before a fights even started, and DPS players blaming the other two roles for xyz, when in reality they die in 1 hit because they don't have the appropriate prerequisite gear.  

half the time an M3 dungeon will be easier than an M2 or M1 because these aforementioned swamp creatures actually need to clear M2 and M1 to apply for it 

The only staying power the game has is crafting and PVP, and thats mostly because you get to absolutely pulp these hopeless players for fun.

UPDATED AFTER 1000 HOURS:

[The Good]
- Beautiful game
- Good backing music
- Satisfying PVE combat
- Very relaxing and therapeutic if you just want to switch off and farm

[The Bad]
- Unbalanced PVP 
- Repetitive and boring quests
- No meaningful endgame loop 
- New content takes way too long to come out
- Lack of transparency around how perks *actually* work (no stats page, no damage meters, no awareness around perk caps etc)
- Unnecessarily over-complicated crafting system. You can grind out the trade skill to max, but then still can't make worthwhile gear without trade skill clothing, trade skill food, trade skill town buffs etc. It's super soul-crushing. Oh, and if you don't have the required items in your inventory, you wont even see the recipe and therefore wont even know it exists!!

I enjoyed my overall experience but updating review to 'not recommended' due to the terrible game systems (the cracks really start to show after you've hit max level) and too many fundamental issues with the game to name, of which the devs continue to ignore because it'd involve too much work to fix.

It's the only game I've been playing recently. I really like that there's no classes and you can basically just do whatever you want. And the fact that you can harvest basically everything you can see (chop trees hit rocks ect.) is really cool and makes the world feel really interactive. I haven't done much PVP but that's been a blast the few times I've done it. Crafting is also neat and easy to understand. Also I really like the instruments in game cuz when you play them you play this little rhythm game minigame that I find a lot of fun. You can also add people to your performance and have a little band.

However I do have a small gripe about how sometimes if you're in a populated lobby and there's a lot of people in town your FPS can tank pretty hard. Also PVP has a very high level of entry. in order to be competitive in PVP you've basically got to buy the expansion and be max level (65 as of time of writing review).

But season 4 is coming soon and I'm really looking forward to that. If you're thinking about buying New World I'd definitely go ahead. In my opinion it's worth the $40 but if you're gonna get the expansion alongside the game I'd probably wait for a small sale just so you don't break the bank.

Fancy Graphics and amazing PVE

This game confuses me because it feels like an MMORPG created by people who know nothing about what people actually enjoy about the genre. Some random thoughts on the game:
The combat is actually somewhat enjoyable, I describe it as what ESO combat should have been (except for the fire and life staff, staff weapon animations+VFX look and feel just as bad to use in this game as they do in ESO). The gathering system is very RuneScape which I enjoy, minus having proper mining locations which just make it a bigger pain than it has to be if you want ore or rocks. The faction/openworld PvP system was not well thought out at all, it's like they didn't consider the long-term effects one faction dominating an entire server would have on the games population. The questing is terrible, there is backtracking left and right since one NPC cannot give you more than a single quest at a time. The fishing and music skills are fun, probably the only things I have nothing bad to say about. And now my rant about what I find most baffling about this game....

People go on and on about how good the game looks, and while I agree it can have some nice visuals if you have a really great PC rig.... character models look like they stepped out of Fable 2 (saying this is me being generous), the majority of armor looks goofy beyond belief, and character creation is worse than games that came out 10+ years ago and it's options are simply terrible. Amazon really seemed to make the odd choice to dump all their funding/resources into making the plants abundant and the trees sway in the wind.
Then the art direction. The one thing that did pull my interest to this game was the more realistic, colonial aesthetic.... only for Amazon to release weird, Disney looking pastel armors left and right. Then with the Rise of the Angry Earth update it's gone even farther away from the original concept.

Unless you're in it for some well done foliage, I'd say don't bother.

I personally have a hard time getting into MMO's. Most that I have tried are usually very wordy at the beginning of the game to explain the story, which is fine! Just for me, I usually have a hard time getting into a game that feel like they info dump on you then send you on your way. 

New World, however, doesn't overwhelm you. It's super simple at the beginning and doesn't force a lot of story down your throat. If you desire more story, it is your choice if you wish to seek it out, which is not hard to find at all.

It is also very forgiving with changing up your stats. As of the moment I do only have 3 hours in, BUT I can say it is very beginner friendly and easy to enjoy especially if you are trying to get into the MMO world.

I have enough hours now to make a good judgment, and here's what I can tell you:

(1) There is no endgame. It's a long climb to nothing. Level the farming/trade skills? That'll cost a ton of time/gold yet top-level crafting is barely even profitable. Level your char and play PvE? You'll get sick of the same 6 dungeons in about 3 days, no matter how many mutations they create (which are no value added). Want to PvP? Unless you're a full sweat tryhard you can't do Wars; OPR and Arena are niche build sweaties; and open world PvP is majorly under-represented.

(2) The game is too PvE heavy. It started as an open sandbox. Not anymore. All I hear from positive reviews is "it looks good." Well, for those of us who don't live for pixel sunsets, it's about gameplay, and the PvP elements are severely lackluster. The arena and outpost matches are dog water. AGS shows zero interest in improving them (even in simple ways). The open world PvP is pretty great but literally the last priority of the developers.

(3) It's Amazon. So if you're into mega-corporation woke nonsense, this is your developer. I just got my first significant ban in any game ever during decades of gaming. Why? Because, very much in context, I quoted a guy as saying "ching chong" in global chat. Apparently that hit a ban filter because I didn't get a warning, didn't get a 24-hour ban, I caught a 7-day ban. It doesn't bother me much because of #1 and #2 above, and I'm already bored with the expansion, but this is typical Amazon corporate trash server moderation.

I literally said one "no-no" word as a quote, one time, and I got a 7-day. Despite the supremely toxic stuff that happens in-game with no consequences. Despite the incredible bug problems in-game that AGS can't fix. They can find one guy saying one word they don't like and immediately over-punish.

So, yeah, don't waste your time/money. Good luck. Eat it, AGS.

As of 2023, New World has undergone significant transformations with the latest expansion, 'Rise of the Angry Earth,' and various updates in between. The graphics and visuals are a standout masterpiece, offering a captivating blend of modern realism and enchanting vibrancy, accompanied by a superb sound quality that enhances the immersive experience.

The beginner experience has improved with a revamped levelling system and more engaging narratives. Character progression has seen a comprehensive overhaul, with the removal of gear expertise and an expanded level cap to 65. Crafting and gathering, a pivotal aspect of progression, has extended to max levels 250, with notable improvements and added depth.

The combat system is high-speed and action-packed, requiring strategic planning and skilful execution. The PvE content has seen significant updates and expansions, including seasonal content, but in-game events have become somewhat repetitive. The recent expansion brought refinements to the expedition system, although difficulties in group formation persist.

On the PvP front, the introduction of influence races adds a refreshing addition, and endgame content now includes 10-player and 20-player raids, with leaderboards for healthy competition. However, there's still a noticeable gap in supplementary activities and content.

The community dynamics show a solid core player base but carry a seasonal undertone, with occasional spikes in activity and subsequent declines. The developers have maintained effective communication, and the monetization strategy has evolved with the introduction of a seasonal battle pass and expansion purchases.

In conclusion, New World offers an enjoyable initial experience with captivating visuals, engaging combat, and immersive crafting. However, its long-term engagement falls short compared to established MMOs, lacking substantial content for sustained play. The endgame experience leaves room for improvement, with the emphasis on joining a company and engaging in PvP for continued engagement. Despite its shortcomings, the initial purchase is justified for ample hours of content, but the game feels more like a seasonal MMO, drawing players back only for updates or expansions. The potential for a more extensive, lore-rich experience could be realized in future iterations from Amazon Games.

Pros:
Promising concept and initial appeal.
Cons:
Economic Imbalance: The game suffers from a poorly managed economy that severely disrupts gameplay and player progression.
Lack of Server Support in Asia: As an Asian player, the absence of dedicated servers in the region results in subpar gaming experiences, highlighting a regional bias.
Deviation from MMORPG Elements: The game strays from core MMORPG mechanics, diminishing the overall experience.

New World is a blast to play, You can join up with a party to take on a dungeon or engage in several different pvp game modes  and even roam the open world to find unique hidden bosses with unique loot drops or even high tier chests to loot! the wide variety of activities you can engage will keep you engaged and entertained for a long time. While i enjoy the game a ton there are a few cons to know about before picking it up.

-(Movement) The games base movement feels very basic and with the lack of a sprint mechanic you will find yourself running around at what feels like a snails pace quite a bit. They recently added mounts to help speed up travel around the map but it does require you to purchase the expansion they are locked behind.

-(Navigation) Navigating around the map is fairly easy and its fun discovering new locations to search for secrets. There are a ton of fast travel locations scattered around the map to make travel easier, But in the early game it can be quite difficult to accumulate enough of the fast travel currency to afford multiple travels. The world also feels alive with the countless  players you will come across to either engage in spontaneous battles, Group up to fight enemies together, Or just to chat or trade with.

-(Combat) The combat is engaging and all the abilities with the different weapon classes feel impact full and unique, Unfortunately there are a few weapons the feel designed for pvp and don't feel good to use in pve activities and there are some weapon abilities that are bugged and just don't work.

-(Enemies) While it may feel like there are a ton of enemy types in the game once you play enough you will start to notice that a lot of the "different" enemy types are actually just re-skins of previous enemy types you faced, But the developers have been adding more unique enemies to the game to prevent the pve from feeling repetitive.

-(Mechanics) There's quite a few mechanics in New world such as  a carry weight system that changes your move speed and effectiveness of your dodging, Each piece of gear you obtain will have multiple perks that makes build crafting fun, And a perk system that makes spending your level up points feel impact full to your play style. The map also includes territory control for each faction that gives the controlling faction of a territory bonuses while in the territory such as free fast traveling, Reduced taxes for crafting and selling items, And exclusive chests that can only be opened by members of the faction that currently controls the territory.

-(Economy) The economy in New World is completely player driven which makes you feel immersed in the world. the only complaint i would have with the economy is due to excessive amounts of bots and gold duplicating depending on the server you decide to join the prices will be inflated and certain items will cost insane amounts of gold to purchase. If you want to avoid playing on a server with a inflated market due to gold duplicating then the recently added fresh start servers are for you.

-(Crafting and Gathering) Gathering resources and crafting gear in New world can be fun when starting out but if you choose to try and max your crafting and gathering skills you will notice how long and grindy the process is. For gathering you will end up spending hours an hours just running around mining the same few ore nodes, Chopping the same few higher tier trees that are clustered near each other, Or running back and forth in the same field picking the same 10 Hemp bushes just to level your gathering skills to a decent level. When it comes to leveling the crafting skills its unfortunately worse, In order to max your crafting skills you will end up finding yourself gathering thousands of the same resource or spending tens of thousands of coin on the resources to craft hundreds of the same item just to get the most crafting experience per craft.

Overall i really enjoyed my time spent in New World, While the game does have some major flaws here and there the developers have been regularly updating the game with bug fixes and quality of life updates. It's a ton of fun to play and has a ton of engaging content but it also has a bunch of bugs and some content that is locked behind having to mindlessly grind the same activity over and over hundreds or even thousands of times, Or even inaccessible without a huge group to play with.

Overall i would rate the game a 7/10.

This is a negative review purely from the perspective of a guy who wanted to main Bow in PvP, a majority of the game is alright and it's definitely become more accessible for new players in the last year. On the MMORPG scale I'd give it about a 6.5/10, it's not revolutionary, it's not even trying anything new, but it's a decent game especially for it's large casual audience. Economically it has some massive issues, there's not really a lot of traditional Raid and Dungeon content to get invested in, and I'm at the point where I wholeheartedly believe the developers spend 20 minutes fishing or decorating their house for every 1 minute they spend PvPing.

New World makes dramatic changes to PvP balance on a whim after people complain about something, your favorite build is never safe unless you're on Fire Staff it seems. More than likely you'll have entire seasons where what you play is nerfed by a percentage that completely negates any empowering or bonuses you can stack on your gear, i.e +7% damage on your jewelry, +5 stacks of +2% damage on your main gear, nearly negated by a 14% damage nerf specifically for your weapon that's applied before you even consider what kind of Damage Resistance the other player has on their armor. They added INT scaling to weapon Archetypes that have historically been pure STR and STR scaling to Archetypes that have historically been pure INT and then people run things like Abyss Great Axe / Fire Staff because Axe has the best AoE Crowd Control and one of the best gap closers in the game, and Fire Staff has the uncontested best gapcloser/escape in the game combined with the absolute best ranged damage in the game, let alone the fact that it's all magic damage with AoE splash or cleave attatched to it. It's like the old weapon balancing and development team left and the new team came in to try to spice the game up which is cool and dandy, but they opened the floodgates for perfect builds to exist. No downsides, no flaws, no quirks that make it difficult and no way any build that doesn't have AoE stapled to everything could possibly be considered as-valuable outside of 3v3s, specifically and in the hands of a really great player with a healer and a serious melee within their composition. They dunked on muskets and bows and then turned around to develop functional access to weapon compositions that never existed before, and completely counter setups that were already struggling, struggling not just with damage output in general but struggling with visibility in large fights, struggling to do damage to targets that, you did as a matter of fact hit, as you can see by the big blue "Dodged" notification that flies out of their character mid roll, but unfortunately immunity-frames are immunity-frames and it doesn't matter that you're actually aiming, predicting your shots and connecting a slow moving projectile with someone frantically sprinting towards you while bobbing and weaving back and forth. He pressed his dodge button and he's immune to your damage.

Straight up would not recommend this to anyone who wanted to play a Musket or a Bow at this point, I'm not sure they'll ever ease up on these weapon archetypes at this stage considering a majority of the best Archers gave up and if they didn't they're not even bringing their bows to Wars. It sucks when you really have a specific playstyle you enjoy and the developers at a company allow for changes so dramatic that you're not able to feel safe investing time into something you enjoy, even if it's not Bows or Muskets, because the reality is we're just a few too many complaints away from Great Axe or Greatsword being on the chopping block. What's worse is knowing they'll let you sit there for entire seasons being completely out of competition with the meta. You could hire a pocket healer and try to stay competitive or bully one of your friends into being your healer, but the fact is you'll probably still die to weapon pairings that seem like an oversight because of what they can be built to do (that they've never been able to do effectively until the recent addition of specific artifacts that break down the dichotomy that's always existed: Heavy Weapons = Strength, Magic Weapons = Intelligence, snappy fast Reflex Weapons = Dexterity.) Even with a healer hitting all their heals, you're probably going to be combo'd to death unless you sacrificed a very useful and very desirable extra source of damage or Crowd Control in the form of a Heartrune like Bile Bomb, Grasping Vines or Detonate, to run what basically amounts to World of Warcraft's Crowd Control Trinket with 10% fortify on it for 5 seconds, and consider, this requires the Heartrune to be available for use in the first place and realistically even the heal from Stalwart Heartrune of Stoneskin isn't going to save you by itself, it's going to give you enough space to run away, back into the backline where you get to chug potions and fire off pitiful amounts of damage once again. 

In my opinion if such a large percentage of the community was trying out Bows and Muskets in OPR/World Content that they had to completely annihilate musket, and tone Bow down to a pea shooter against everyone besides people that can't dodge and are simultaneously in a light-load, it seems like the nerfs cut out two skill weapons that people were having fun on. I understand the issue with allowing ranged weapons to become too strong in a game where melee exists but at this point I don't think you can kill a heavy that's aware that you're shooting him even if he only uses potions. I'm pretty sure a guy standing still in a heavy build would be able to loop potions on you forever, it's crazy that when you headshot these guys from ungodly distances, your reward for hitting such difficult to land shots is less than 10% of their total health, even when taking advantage of all the empowering bonuses of the entire Bow tree against full health targets, against targets you haven't hit recently and from heavy attack opening shots. It gets worse after the first shot as well, because more than half of your sources of empowering disappear after that first shot. It's tragic watching your damage not even be a factor in a team fight after spending time putting a character together, and honestly it's a big "fuck you" to everyone who mains these builds because what they want from you is to not only hit for you to hit 100% of your shots, but to hit 100% of your shots as headshots, through dodges, through rolls, through a slow projectile, through either a giant blob of nameplates that block out the sun when you have Visible Nameplates set high, or through nearly no nameplates unless you're looking directly at a target hiding in the bushes when you turn Visible Nameplates down. 

They have a really great idea, an MMORPG that has aim requirements if you seek them out, an MMORPG that blends shooters and RPGs together for a game that's beautiful in a lot of ways if I'm being honest, but in practice it leaves you feeling like you need to join the guys on Fire Staff or Great Axe/Warhammer/Spear/Rapier if you don't just become a healer so you're universally useful. 

People who want to aim, maybe reconsider, maybe this is their way of saying they don't want us here.

I love this world. Levelling was actually fun for me. I normally have a painful levelling experience, as I often get distracted by professions and all the little extras along the way. I must admit, when I first purchased New World, I had no idea it was an MMO. Had I done a bit more research beforehand, I would have quickly discovered its MMO nature, a genre I typically shy away from due to its notorious grindiness. However, much to my surprise, New World managed to captivate me in ways I hadn't anticipated.

Despite my initial reservations about MMOs and their tendency to be excessively grindy, New World presented a refreshing experience that kept me engaged for a surprising 80 hours—quite a feat considering my usual reservations about the genre. The multiplayer aspect of the game, in particular, stood out as a fascinating gameplay element. The way it was implemented added a layer of enjoyment that I hadn't encountered in other MMOs.

I find myself in a peculiar position of recommending this game wholeheartedly, especially to those who have an affinity for MMOs. If you're a fan of the genre, you're likely to have a rewarding and immersive experience with New World. Despite my initial misjudgment and lack of research, the game managed to win me over with its unique multiplayer dynamics and overall gameplay.

However, it's essential to acknowledge that my perspective is based on the 80 hours I invested in the game, and it's been a while since I last played. While my positive experiences linger in memory, the potential for changes and updates in the game could alter the experience for newcomers. It's always advisable to stay informed and updated before making a purchase decision.

In conclusion, if you're contemplating buying New World and have an appreciation for MMOs, I would recommend it. Just make sure you do the necessary research to avoid the initial misstep I made, diving headfirst into a new game without understanding its genre. With the right expectations and an open mind, New World might surprise you, as it did for me.

I have played almost all "popular" mmos out there and this one sadly is a big no for me.

The Good:
-Nice environments, the art direction is good, locations can feel believable.

-Nice sound design, lots of small little sounds accompany your character, like the scraping of armour plates or the little clicking of metal and wood on your gun.

-The UI is nice and simple and pretty straight forward.

-The fighting is somewhat decent, with headshots, dodging and blocking mechanics.

-I have enjoyed the classless character build style, even if I would have preferred a class based style.

-I have encountered no bugs or performance issues.

The Bad:
-The gameplay feels so outdated. Talk to an NPC about a very generic problem that requires you to hear/read a wall of text, then kill x mobs or collect x pointless items. There are other poorer mmos like Elder Scroll that at least varies its quests design.

-There is nothing gripping about the story, it just feels like an excuse to cover up generic quest design.

-The voice acting is just awful, seriously, morning cartoon of the late 80's had similar or better voice overs.

-Poor to terrible character art style with almost no customization, and almost no haircut options  for African descendant people except for 2. Maybe you might not care, but some of us enjoy playing a non-white character.

-The writing is  terrible, every character sounds written by an old dude trying to guess what edgy teenagers sounds like in order to appeal to a younger audience. They even mention the accuracy of the real world people/faiths at the start of the game, but it is absolutely moronic to believe that all of these cultures from all over the world would somehow coexist in this time period, especially if your skin tone did not match another, but guess what? They are all great pals! Racism and religious hatred never existed don't you know?

-If you want to play a ranged build, forget it, even though the game has free aim, it uses the outdated kite mechanic in which if you manage to find a safe spot where to damage your enemy without them being able to damage you back, it will regenerate health and give you a big middle finger. This is just utterly ridiculous in a modern mmo. Do you understand the actually concept of ranged? The advantage being that you can hit your enemies and they cannot hit you if you outsmart them? Imagine if a bunch of barbarians during a fight with the Romans put themselves on the edges of a river, and the roman smartly put themselves at the top of the ravine, shooting them all down, but then the chief barbarian goes "nope, not a fair fight, fuck you" and regenerates. Even if you disagree with this, sometimes enemies regenerates just because a tiny pebble stands between them and you and fail to find the obvious path around it. The kiting mechanic is a lazy work-around to poor level design. Crap all you want on Fallout 76 but it doesn't have this dumb mechanic.

-The world feels "dead" as in everyone is an NPC for your convenience, there are no people walking around, living their lives. Taverns are empty, stalls for you to craft weapons or cook have no blacksmiths or chefs. It feels that only players and quest givers exists.

-Not a big deal for everyone but on a personal note, the lack of an RP support, like server tags or even communities which usually gives me purpose to stick around long after the game has lost its appeal are non-existent.

I bought this game on sale not knowing what to expect, and have been very impressed. I've been looking for a lasting MMORPG for a while now, and I think this is it. I love the no-class system, leveling isn't too grindy and feels good, the skills are all fun as well. The world is huge, with tons of quests everywhere. I've barely been able to make it out of the couple starting zones because I've been enjoying everything. The environment is also beautiful too, and sometimes I find myself just looking around! I would highly recommend anyone check this out, especially now, as I heard it didn't launch in the greatest state. This game is well worth it!

In 2023, "New World" from Amazon Games stands out as a refreshingly unique MMORPG. Set in the visually stunning Aeternum, the game combines survival elements with a player-driven economy, offering an immersive experience. It breaks the traditional MMO mold with a classless, real-time action combat system that emphasizes skill and precision. Character development is deeply engaging, with a focus on leveling up personal attributes, weapon, and trade skills. The game's first major expansion, "Rise of the Angry Earth," introduced in October 2023, added new content and story elements, reflecting the developers' commitment to evolving the game's world.

Despite its strengths, "New World" initially faced criticism for its grindy progression system, but significant improvements have made it more engaging. It's particularly commendable for solo players, offering opportunities to forge in-game friendships and collaborate to achieve goals. Overall, "New World" in 2023 is more than just an MMO; it's a dynamic, evolving game that captivates with its combination of innovative gameplay, compelling narrative, and continuous development -chatGPT

Pros: 
1.) Best combat system in an MMO ive seen.
2.) Leveling is an all around enjoyable experience 
3.) Great Graphics for an MMO

Cons: 
1.) Economy is straight trash. If you like making money in MMO's then this game is not for you.
2.) Outpost Rush Game Mode. This game has been out for over 2 years now. Why is there still only 1 map for this game mode. 
3.) Company System (Guilds). I cannot edit rank privileges, rank names, or anything about the company except for the MotD, Icon, and the guild name. Its just a place to park your money and that's it. 
4.) Faction Wars. Unless you're in the top pvp companies with best in slot gear you will not be participating in this game mode. 
5.) End Game Content. With the economy being trash, war's being gate-guarded, and very little expeditions (dungeons) available the game feels as if there is nothing to do once you hit max level. 

This game has the makings to be great, but is lacking in so many core areas for me. For that, i cannot recommend this game until these issues are addressed.

5/10

An online game that has pretty graphics, beautiful open world scenery and a few features from mmoRPGs. 

P2w: Not officialy but the RMT in this game is crazy.

You need a good computer with Nvm.e SSD and a good processor, or you're gonna experience lag spikes, bad fps and freezing. This game is not very well optimized, ping can be high for no reason and you can get disconnected out of nothing. Game crashes a lot, even if you have a good computer.

- Character creation: awful, not many options for face and you cannot customize the body at all. Most of faces and hairs are ugly. Cannot change your character appearance neither the name after you create it, so keep that in mind.

- Leveling: fun! The open world has lots of areas to explore, tons of resources to gather (gathering system is the best!!). Quests won't give you good gear, better to buy something on the trading post if you need. Choose DPS weapons to lvl even if you pretend to be a healer or it's gonna be annoying to progress. The story is a bit silly imo, needs improvement still (it was way worse).

- Factions: 3 factions you can choose by lvl 20 ish, but factions won't affect much of your game in this early stage. But it's good to level up your faction rank by doing pve or pvp quests everyday. Later on, factions will be needed to buy faction exclusive items for crafting, lvl your pvp rank, join a guild and if you desire, try the wars.

- Crafting: useful and require lots of resources to max lvl. Can b a pain on end game as well and a way to make gold.

- Gear: now on season 3/4 it's pretty easy to get gear, so easy that became boring.

- Mounts: you need to be lvl 25 and need the DLC Rise of the Angry Earth to be able to ride mounts. Mounts does not fly or swim. This is a very simple feature. Only one type of mount with a few skins available. Most of the time it glitches and looks like it's riding a skate.

- Transmog: you can drop transmog token from Elite chests all over the open world or dungeons (1 per week), or even buy in the cash shop. You're gonna need 1 token per item you need to transmog, then you can use that item as much as you want after that, so for a whole set you're gonna need 7 tokens (included weapons). Not many skins are good tho, most characters looks like clowns.

- Dyes: you can craft dyes, but the pretty ones are in the cash shop with a long rotation that takes months to come back. So if you love white dye you need to stock up, which end up being very expensive.

- Community: very toxic in general, specially with new players. No one wants to teach you anything. This game does NOT have MMORPG community. Most of its players came from all other kind of game genre, so it's pretty hard to create that feeling of a long lasting community I've had on other MMOrpg. 

- PvP modes: Opr 20v20 (1 map), Arena 3v3 (2 maps), wars (50v50). Influence races (all factions 50v50v50). Wars looks more like a Guild v Guild thing it's schedule between guilds and the leaders pick up the members they want for the board. Ofc only the most skilled ones will be picked. 
Influence races happens in the evening and anyone can join, but if there's a lot of people you're gonna be teleported back to town. Opr and Arena you can join anytime once you're max lvl.

- PvE endgame: Elite chest runs (big crowds of players together to loot special chests in areas with elite mobs), organized by players in different times. Mutated dungeons (only 2 dungeons get a different mutation per week, so it might take a while for the dungeon you desire to come back in rotation). Mutations has 3 lvls, but m1 and m2 are very very very easy. So yes that means you need to keep repeating only 1 or 2 dungeons the whole week, and can only do it 35 times. Sometimes Amazon repeats the dungeons and makes a mess with it and the same dungeon stays mutated for 2 or 3 weeks, which means you can do only the same dungeon (that usually takes 20 minutes more or less for 2 whoel weeks or more).
There are no raids. There's 1 trial, a sandworm, with 20 people that only a few groups does it (usually guilds, extremely rare to find pugs).

- Bugs: YES! All kinds that can drive you nuts sometimes. They fix one bug and other 10 MAJOR bugs appears

- Storage: a pain to manage it.

- QoL features: missing a bunch of those. Not gonna lie, the game has improved a lot on this aspect but still missing many others.

- Housing: Fun, with many nice items, but the ones from cash shop takes forever to come back (a whole year), and some doesn't even come back. Many items can be dropped or crafted. It's not very customizable like ffxiv or ESO, but you can have some fun with it if you like this feature.

- Gear set (load outs): changes your gear easily, but does not change skill sets or attributes, which is bad, very bad. You can buy up to 9 in the cash shop.

- War System: as I've mentioned above, the war system is for a small group of people, mostly a GvG. A guild that wins a war can control a territory for some time (until some other guild takes it), and they receive all the tax money from the trading post, housing and crafting from that territory, so they can make tons of gold, they also control the lvl from the craft stations and the town buffs for better gathering and crafting quality for the whole server. However, many guilds only takes control of the territory and couldn't care less about craft stations or buffs, which affects ALL players in the server and it's a PAIN in the A S S.
New players won't be picked for wars, specially in legacy servers. Most servers has 2 guilds controlling everything which makes hard for new or not skilled players to join and play this part of the game.

- Game does not have API open, so no mods or good features are allowed. No dps meter, no way to measure if your weapon is bad or good or if you did well. No chat log either.

- RANGED WEAPONS: If you love to be mage or a bard just forget about it, unless you only pvp. Players won't allow you to use ranged weapons in end game dungeons (mutated m3). 

- Rare items: no. not much grinding nowadays for anything.

- PvP open world: you can find pvp usually near the forts from each territory.

- They add new content every new season (every 3 months). But when that season ends they remove the content. This is so bad imo, feels like the game never has enough for a good long lasting end game, which makes it feels empty and boring pretty fast.

- BOTS AND RMT: YES, TONS! Remember those guild that wins wars I've mentioned above? They make enough to sell the gold for dollars. It's way less gold nowadays, but still a lot compared to normal players.

- Healers: if you love to play as a healer in other MMORPG you need to know that in New World healers are very different, at least for me, a person that played Aion, Gw2 and FFXIV for many years. It's annoying to select a group member in the group list, you don't have many skills, and I trully dislike all healers skills. But that's me, you probably should check gameplay on youtube or twitch.

- If you say or do something to someone from a big guild they mass report you and you get banned. Amazon won't even check it.

- In the end: it's a game to spend a month playing. It's online so you can meet some people. The combat is action, not so good IMO, but people seems to love it. There are no swimming or boats even tho it's kind of a pirate ish game. 

 It has an official discord community moderated by Amazon/AGS but it's very strict and you're gonna get banned just by saying words like "i'm noob in this game" or "not many people in my server now, feels empty". All the bug reports and announcements are made on their discord, so if you get banned for those silly reasons you're dammed.
Been rolling solo except for a group one time. I like it because there is so much to do and no subscription.

Leveling has been pretty fun and the world has so much cool stuff to explore if you like that aspect. I haven't done any PvP so I can't speak to that but it looks engaging enough. I'm sure once I hit max level and start to do endgame stuff that more irritating things will come to light but right now it's pretty good.

Visuals/Aesthetic - 9/10

World Exploration - 8/10

Crafting - not too tedious so far, will likely also change with endgame, 7/10

Skills Training - Definitely grindy, getting to 50 of anything isn't that hard and that unlocks new ores, plants, etc. But getting to 100 is already grindy enough so I'd imagine that getting to 250 is going to be a nightmare.  For the leveling experience so far I'd say 8/10, but I can see that dropping to a 3 or 4 by endgame.

Combat - kinda clunky but you get used to cancelling and combos pretty quickly, and once you do everything kinda flows into place and feels a lot better, 8/10

Questing/Story - Story is okay nothing to ride home about, typical of what you would find in any MMORPG, questing is about as generic as you can get, 6/10

Dungeons - I've only done 1 dungeon so far and got carried by high level players so I can't speak to the difficulty/matchmaking/overall legitimacy of how dungeons work

Overall, would definitely recommend if you just want to get into an MMORPG while not having to go full send to enjoy it

If you like fair PVP don't play this game. 

1. The matchmaking of the Arena 3v3 is broken. You constantly get premades with healer on the oposit team, when you don't even have a healer in your group. 
Also 3 range vs 3 melee is usually easy win for range players. Just because range is so OP.

2. Outpost Rush is just a gambling. You don't have any impact there alone. Premades with tanks and healers win. 
Outpost Rush is usually boring onesided game with no balance in it. 

3. War is boring long fights on one spot with no tactics and skill required.

4. Melee DPS is not viable in PVP at all. You can try it and even do damage. But any range DPS will just do it better from safe distance. So in large scale, while you trying to get closer to enemies, you will be just deleted. 
Even in smallscale range will just run away with lots of mobility. No balance and trade offs for range. 
So, you can tryhard as light melee DPS or just chill and win everything as a fire staff/ Abyss Axe for example.

5. There are only few viable (meta) builds in the game for PVP. The rest is just useless.

6. The game is constantly has somethig broken in it (bugs, exploits, etc)

7. Seems like developers just don't care about broken balance. They simply make OP things more OP, because they can. 
For example, they are adding Boltcaster artifact bow to the game, when bow is already OP. 
And PTR tests show that you can delete people with 2 shots keeping enemy under CC while doing it,

8. PVP community is toxic 

9. Your gear is very impactfull in PVP. So, if you don't have correct one - you will be just useless. And it is super hard to get good gear as a new player. 

10. The combat system is clunky and has a lot of bugs and glitches. 

11. The game has very bad optimization and consumes alot of resources. So it can be laggy in large scale PVP, which is not playable. 

12. Some artifacts (type of gear) that are really important in your PVP build are far away in PVP track which force you burn your nerves getting them playing PVP with a poor build and gear against people with top gear and meta builds. 

13. Range builds have to much mobility. Combined with huge burst they outperform any melee light DPS. 

If you like competitive PVP - New World is definitely not for you.


On the other side: PVE , gathering and crafting is really nice.
Unfortunately for me PVP is more important.

I begin this review with a disclaimer: I am not an avid MMO player, but my journey through various titles has led me to New World, a game that has pleasantly surprised me. My MMO history includes early experiences with Wizard101 and Pirate101, followed by a recent exploration of well-known titles like World of Warcraft, Elder Scrolls Online, and Final Fantasy XIV, all of which failed to captivate me in the long run.

World of Warcraft, with its vast universe and ties to Hearthstone, initially drew me in. However, the repetitive nature of combat and gathering resources quickly dampened my enthusiasm. Elder Scrolls Online offered a more engaging combat system but felt sluggish, especially in terms of movement. Final Fantasy XIV, while distinctive in its fantasy setting, couldn't sustain my interest, leaving me questioning if the MMO genre was simply not my cup of tea.

Enter Guild Wars 2, praised for its beginner-friendly approach and flexibility in playtime. Despite its positive reception, the slow pace and lack of challenge at lower levels left me disinterested. Seeking a change, I delved into New World, and it has turned out to be the MMO I've been searching for.

New World's combat system is a standout feature, striking a balance between traditional MMO abilities and more skill-based interactions. Every encounter, even with basic foes, demands attention, providing a dynamic and engaging experience. The open-world design is another highlight, where traversing the vast landscapes remains interesting due to the high level of interactivity. Gathering resources along the way feels like a natural part of the journey, keeping the exploration engaging.

While other MMOs employ various methods to speed up travel, New World relies on the interactive environment to make the journey enjoyable. Although the game has introduced mounts with the expansion, I haven't experienced this feature yet. The potential downside could be the monotony of travel once all professions are maxed out, diminishing the need for resource gathering.

Though I acknowledge the possibility of the honeymoon phase influencing my positive impressions, my increased MMO experience allows me to appreciate New World's unique qualities. While it may not be a flawless game, it has found a place in my library and gaming rotation, offering a refreshing experience in the MMO landscape. Time will tell if it can maintain its allure, but for now, New World stands out as a game that suits my taste in this expansive genre.

After that you will know how to do again if it happens another time, which i heard it will. find the C:\Users\(you)\AppData\roaming\AGS\NewWorld remove savedata and user_preload_settings.cfg, you will have to do that over and over again everytime and don't try to find the folders manually. type it in in the search bar. If that doesn't work go to local files find easyanti cheat folder click that then click on easyanticheat_setup, click Uninstall then the big blue button. you could also go to bin64 in the local files and find the new world icon, in which you right click go to properties and make administer under compatibility. No your character isn't gone, you just have to press back once you get to character creator or pick the region you were playing in.

TL;DR - New World feels like a refreshing MMO that made me actually enjoy playing an MMO again, while I do still skip MOST the quest dialogue, I am loving that I don't feel like I need to grind to max level - since there is so much more to the game than being max level. 

I waited because I saw so many mixed reviews on the game, despite being somewhat excited about the release. With the new DLC, my wife spotted the mounts and was ready to give it a try.

Overall, I'm pretty pleased with the game. There are a few things that feel oddly clunky and not very intuitive for a game released in 2021. 

The graphics are pretty good, nothing feels over the top or bland, though I did have to adjust my settings up because all of the NPCs in town looked like playdough with the defaults.

The audio is very immersive and enjoyable, we even noticed how the sound effects carry in the world (ex chopping a tree can be heard 20-30 meters away, though faint).

I love how nice it feels to no be class locked, which I REALLY enjoyed when playing Elden Ring. I started with basic gear, tried different weapons to see if I liked the play... Had a BLAST with the hammer (STR) and Ice Gauntlet (INT), but now am using the flail (STR/FOC) and life staff (FOCUS). 
The reason that's cool? I didn't have to make a new character to do it.

I love how the cosmetics work, though I dislike that the cash shop is the main source for the tokens and most the cosmetics are sold in bundles or bundles of bundles... I would easily spend $2-$5 on a helmet, chest, or weapon cosmetic. While I simply won't spend $100 to get the bundles that has 3 bundles in it for a chest that I like.

The crafting systems... are... Amazing. It's so fun to be able to harvest pretty much anything and then turn around and use it to make, cook, and build (like a survival game, without the risk of losing it all)!

My only gripes so far is my screen can get REALLY cluttered in towns and sometimes I lose track of party member or objectives when there's an elevation involved. Some of the crafting was confusing - as I had steel bars, but couldn't use them to make STEEL armor or weapons (only voidsteel, for example), which didn't make sense. I later discovered I needed to further level that skill.
Lastly, I don't have a potato system but for some reason the game simply crashed (multiple times) while my wife didn't experience this - it's EXTRA strange since I have a slightly better rig than her. 🤷

Like I said, I'm not really into this sort of game but this one really surprised me. It's easy to play, easy to learn and not a sweat fest. I can relax after work and grind some levels. The game does a wonderful job of keeping you engaged (there is always something to do). Leveling up is also very satisfying. 

If you prefer more realistic, first person, open world, shooter, survival games then you might also enjoy this game. The third person perspective also helps and I'm glad it's not a top down style game like many others in this category.

Overall I have enjoyed it and will continue to grind it out. I would recommend anyone try this if you are on the fence, but only if it's on sale.

Alright, so Amidst the other reviews here i felt it would be remiss if I did not give a comprehensive one since most seem to be simply complaining about the game. 

Yes I play the game. Yes I like it for various reasons. Mainly that unfortunately this piece of garbage is one of the better MMORPGs out there currently. So the game play and mechanics are good. So why the bad review? Read on my friends Read on.


Let's start with the obvious:

1. ~ The Que Times have been resolved, however the server connection/performance is completely subpar for a company with the largest cloud server system in the world.

Let me Clarify: When you are selecting a Server/Region, you will notice all servers from all regions have 1 red bar and an error next to them which says "All Regions have poor connections, You may experience issues". 

This has been widely reported for months, and Amazon refuses to fix it. You would think this would be a priority since bad server issues causes all kinds of in game problems. But apparently maintaining their servers is not as important as Updating and Maintaining the cash shop (Which receives regular updates and fixes).

This is 100% unacceptable for obvious reasons.

Personally I have long held that the people at Amazon are lazy incompetent twits, but that was an opinion, however they have proven it correct repeatedly. 


2. ~ The next issue is the abysmally lazy no effort craptastical piece of garbage they call the character creator.

I mean I've seen E slot Mobile games with better Character creators for Christs sakes... Your a 1.8 Trillion dollar company, you couldn't pay your devs an extra 100k to create something worth a damn?.

Let me explain:

You want a male character? too bad you get an androgynous or ugly character with NO way to edit it beyond prefabed hideous looking faces and traits.

You want a female character? Too bad, hope you like Ugly women or Masculin Trannies because that's what your gonna get, again with 0 way to edit the prefabed presets garbage.

You get to pick skin color, Hair do, and facial hair, and some facial tattoos and scars.

You CAN NOT edit the characters body, at all in fact the Char creator doesn't even show it.


3. Clothing/Armor:  Clips like a MFer. And Hoods are hideous. Also most of the armor in the game looks like garbage. I understand the style they were going for was renaissance/conquestidorial style. But really.... Maybe you should have consulted with an actual expert before designing stuff.... And then realized that most people hate that time period and the way the clothing/armor looked during it. Some might like it it's true and it's definitely Unique. But Unique is not always better. And more traditional fantasy type stuff should have been added. Specifically fixes for the Hoods so they actually fit the body and armor of your characters instead of looking like hovering pieces of crap.


4. As far as the game play and mechanics..... It's actually not that bad, It's a good "Game", but the server issues and Character creation ruin the entire package.


Pros:

- Good game itself. (Once your actually playing if you can get in)


Cons:

- Servers are Borked.

- The simplest of character creators with almost no options for customization. Take your cookie cutter character and go play. Clothing and armor options suck.

- Nameing conventions Every name is locked across the board as they lock the names by the actual entirety of the world (as in Earth), rather then by server or region. In other words if someone in china names their character Bangjingadong. If your playing on US west you can't name your character anything even similar to it. (Yea thats right it blocks "Similar" names also.)

Anyway, My advice is to play the game at your own risk, its free to play once you buy it so there is that. If you just bought it and then read this, don't worry if you can get past the above you'll like the game.

All of that being said,

You have been warned.

"New World: A Phenomenal Adventure - 5000 Hours and Counting!" If there's a testament to the immersive and addictive nature of a game, it's my extensive playtime of 5000 hours in New World. From the moment I stepped foot into Aeternum, Amazon Game Studios' creation has captivated me with its sheer brilliance and enthralling game play. New World isn't just a game; it's an experience that unfolds as you traverse its beautifully crafted landscapes, battle mythical creatures, forge alliances, and compete in a persistent, evolving world. The immersive environment, rich lore, and engaging combat mechanics are unparalleled. One of the game's most compelling aspects is its attention to detail in crafting a breathtaking world. The diverse biomes, ranging from lush forests to desolate wastelands, showcase the developers' commitment to creating an expansive and visually stunning universe. Combat in New World is dynamic and skill-based. Whether engaging in PvP battles, tackling challenging PvE content, or participating in massive wars between factions, the combat mechanics offer depth and satisfaction. The weapon variety and skill trees allow for diverse playstyles, ensuring every encounter feels fresh and exciting. The social aspect of New World is equally enticing. The game encourages cooperation and camaraderie through its company system, fostering teamwork and strategic planning for territory control and conquest. Despite its numerous strengths, New World isn't without flaws. Early on, there were concerns about server stability and balancing issues. However, the developers have shown dedication in addressing these concerns, consistently rolling out updates and improvements to refine the gaming experience. What truly sets New World apart is its ability to keep me invested, even after thousands of hours. The constant updates, events, and new content additions ensure there's always something to discover or achieve, making each session as thrilling as the first. In conclusion, New World isn't just a game; it's a world I've immersed myself in for an astounding 5000 hours. Its captivating world-building, engaging combat, and evolving game play make it an absolute gem in the realm of MMOs. For anyone seeking an immersive and enduring gaming experience, New World is an absolute must-play.

I love the open world of this game.  The gathering and crafting are interesting.  They are starting to make it a solo game, when it is called an MMO.  The dungeons and fortress taking are fun, but the open world can be laggy.  The OPR is fun but unbalanced, not really laggy, you can make the points easily in different ways, from tanking large groups, healing, and pve style fort build up, to killing npcs for points and taking forts on the point.  They have not put out a new OPR style since launch.  Fishing is the best in any MMO, and can make you money from the Trading Post.  Housing is nice but could be improved.  The last houses added are huge one room huts, which I felt was lame.  

If they don't improve the game, they will have this bad reputation going into the new LOTR game they are building, which will make people hesitant to play it.

Bought this during Autumn Sales, pretty fun game & very solo PVE friendly. Players here (played in AP Southeast) are generally very friendly and helpful. (I have not reached to raiding yet as I'm only lv30 now so no comment on that.) There's crafting and gathering skills which are pretty similar to FFXIV.

Graphics (especially on scenery) are similar to Horizon Zero Dawn. (Which I think it's extremely beautiful to take a break some times and just enjoy the scenery) I got the game at the right timing as they'd launched mount feature in their latest DLC and was very amazed by how pretty & fluid the mounts animation are. For characters, it's just average, I've seen better in other MMOs.

Gameplay (attack animation) feels a bit clunky for me (maybe I'm just new to this style of combat) but can definitely get used to it over time. The style reminds me of Dragon Nest (includes the FOV & crosshair). 

No classes tied so you can build whichever weapons fancies you, which I think it's very cool too :)
Overall definitely a recommendation, 8/10!
