I've only had the game a little over a week, but I've already hit level 60 and so far- I'm a fan. After 130+ hours in game over the last week or so, I've only found one "bug" so far (the map marker not showing on my compass, which took a hard reset of my computer to fix) and can honestly say I'm impressed with the work and progress that Amazon has made with New World, because I have heard some nightmare stories!

Lesser game developers have given up and abandoned games, that had struggles like this one did at launch, so it's refreshing to see a developer stick it out to fix and deliver what was promised to their customers [here's looking at you Starbreeze / Pay Day 3 ] -_- 

The graphics are stunning & beautifully rendered. The quests are well done, with the perfect level of "option to skip" and "cut scene" (where you aren't constantly inundated with nonstop movies, but you can still skip NPC dialogue if you want to). The journals and maps make it super easy to track, abandon, restart and follow all of your quests (Amazon did a good job making FextraLife less useful here XD ). The crafting system is pretty complex, but simple to figure out and most of the items have 'hover-able' descriptions, that tell you where to go to use them.

I've never been a fan of PVP- to me, it's just a small peen measuring competition that gets in the way of my grind to end game. Too many games have let the joy of PVP for a few, ruin the rest of the game for everyone else- so I LOVE that Amazon made PVP fully optional. Those who want to PVP can PVP with themselves and those who don't, can play the entire game without enabling PVP once, if they so chose. I wish more games would take note on this.

I love that I can group with friends, even if they're in other factions and we can quest together and explore the world. New World is truly one of the better coded MMO's out there atm. Which I guess shows in my game time, having only had the game for over a week, and already played over 130+ hours ^.^'

If I were pressed for a complaint, I would say I wish the dungeon "group" requirements were reduced to 2, or it would be nice if they'd add a "2-player Challenge" option to dungeons, for higher level players who want more arduous game play. My bf and I play at odd hours, so most of our friends are asleep. We don't always have a third or fourth member, so waiting for randoms to saunter by and hoping they'll join us for the dungeon can get a bit tedious, but we're "souls" players, so we're always up for the difficulty of running the dungeons without the full group - give us the option to run it without 3! XD

After playing about 16 hours my thoughts. The game is a great MMO and has the makings to be one of the best. Yes, there are queuing issues, mostly due to the buy once nature of the game, and hype that the game got. This happens and will resolve over time. But once in the game the graphics, sound and design are wonderful. Combat takes a bit to get use to since it is not tab targeting but I like that. Quests are repetitive, go here and kill x mobs but that ever MMO out there. Over all it’s a great game with a rocky start that will get better, just like every start of a new, hyped MMO.

[h1] Its Better Now [/h1]
New World is a game where you can explore a vast open world, fight monsters, craft items, join factions, and make friends. Sounds fun, right? Well, it is, until you encounter some of the hilarious bugs and glitches that plague the game.
Of course, these bugs and glitches can also be a source of amusement and entertainment, as long as you don’t take the game too seriously. You can laugh at the absurdity of the situations, share your stories and screenshots with other players, and hope that the developers will fix them soon. New World is a game that has a lot of potential, but also a lot of problems. It is a game that can be frustrating and fun at the same time. It is a game that will make you say: “Wow, this is amazing!” and “What the hell is going on?” in the same breath. It is a game that you will love and hate, but never forget.

- Every time I try to move the fastmove system to the capital the game crashes.
- The Eu new player server has max -1 green ping box at about -60 I think, and I live in Norway.
These two major issues leaves me to belive that they were not prepared for the rush of new players that the 60% discount on steam would bring. 

I have a relatively new PC and I have a beast of an internet connection and every other mmorpg among others Eve online, Guildwars 2, Final Fantasy 14 etc etc runs silky smooth on max settings yet New world is barely playable on minimum settings with locked framerates, But.....
This game is perhaps the most fun I have had in a very long time. The gameplay loop is addictive and the world they have created is magical and spite these major issues that would have made me abandon any other game, it makes me comming back again when the game crashes.and I have cooled down.

New World is like stepping into a time machine set to the 17th century, with jaw-dropping graphics that make you feel like you're in the midst of a historical epic. The game's got a killer combo of PvE adventures, crafting escapades, and intense PvP showdowns for territorial dominance. Dive into the immersive world where player-driven economies rule, and character progression is the name of the game. Whether you're into hunting monsters, forging alliances, or just soaking in the stunning landscapes, this game serves up a gaming experience that's as diverse as the player community itself.
good game

The game is good, but the security system is working in an unclear manner. I received a ban in this game after a year of playing it, and I did not use any cheat programs. The technical support responded that they would not answer my messages. There are plenty of bots in the game that gather resources, and they are not being blocked.

Two years ago, I was really impressed with the game – the music, storyline, and world decorations were amazing. However, I stopped playing New World because it seemed like the game didn't respect players due to bugs and system issues. Now, I'm playing again with a friend, and we've been talking about why these things weren't done from the beginning: a mount system, more warp points, a better questline, and beautiful cutscenes. Thank you for continuing to improve. I hope you all keep getting better.

[Edit after another year]
I have recently returned to New World, to see what has changed with the expansion they added.
Mounts, new weapon, new area.
They have actually improved on many areas of the game.
I still think some fundamental aspects are flawed, particularly around their server technology limiting just how "massively" an MMO can be (which is ironic given this is Amazon we are talking about). 
But that said, the combat itself is fun and engaging.
There are negatives and positives, but I am just generally updating my review again from Negative to Positive, in recognition of improvements they have made.

[Edit with patch 1.1 today]
Well, I look back at my earlier review, and note the promise I saw there.
In that time, I've come to see just how buggy and flawed this development team is.
So many many bugs.   All I overlooked, or worked around.  Just trying to enjoy the core gameplay, and not dwell on those aspects.

Then, 1.1 patch came along.  Lots of new fixes. 
But, with it, just wide ranging unbalancing changes that have thrown the entire game into chaos.   Whole gameplay loops broken, weapons and healing nerfed, end game areas insanely buffed to make it impossible to play through successfully with your mates.  

Created a have and have not divide.  Those who no-lifed the grind to begin with now far advanced, and able to possibly handle the new 'norm'.
Everyone else, good luck.  You'll need it. 

Just disappointing...

Oh well.. I got my moneys worth I guess.  Was fun while it lasted.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I grew up on MMOs but in recent years have found myself unable to stay engaged with the game due to the fact that I often play them solo; New World is actually a great game to play solo. 

The story is okay, but nothing to rave about. The premise of the game is interesting, though. Where this game really shines for me is in its combat(more enjoyable as a solo player, imo) and its crafting and gathering mechanisms. It's actually fun to try finding resources and crafting your own gear as you level up, and the combat feels similar to playing a single player title. When a bunch of people group up, the combat gets a bit more bland I think, just because it's hard to determine who is being attacked and the animations of everyone on top of each other become a bit overwhelming.

The community seems to be pretty active, and it is nice to actually see players coming and going, as well as hanging out in town. The ability to actually play instruments via mini games in a sort of "Guitar Hero" type way is also pretty fun, and a unique addition to an MMO. 

Lastly, the game is probably the prettiest MMO I have played in recent years, but I don't play a whole lot of them these days so take that with a grain of salt. I genuinely enjoy walking around the world in this game, though. Speaking of the world, it's persistent, and I am seldom met with a loading screen outside of fast traveling. 

As someone who used to play Elder Scrolls Online quite a bit, this game is actually a bit more fun to play for me. The story in ESO is much better than New World, but in terms of game play, New World has so far won me over. 

If you can get this on sale for $15 as I did, then I encourage it. It would even be worth $30 I think, given then there is no sub and the game is genuinely fun to play.

This game is like a mix of GW2 and BDO, except the developers took the worst of both games, mix it together, throwed the dumbest game mechanics, sprinkled a lot of small annoying bugs that could be easily fixed, spit in your face, priced the game at 40$, spit in your face again, priced a mandatory DLC at 30$ without which you are basically stuck moving by foot in a game without speed buffs and also you will have areas lock and be forever lvl 60 as to reach lvl 65 you need the DLC. 

There is no minimap in the game, the compass is a sad f*cking joke, possible one of the worst in game chat UI and the HUD is not doing any better

You can't use global chat for 72 hours, so exactly the most important time frame for you as a new player to gather information and ask question, you will not be able to do so. You will also won't be able to form a dungeon lobby for 72 hours. This makes no sense at all, I would understand if it was a f2p game so you can limit spam from bots and fake accounts but why implement such mechanics in a game that costs 40$ ?!

On top of that the games feels incredibly boring, running from one point to another all the time, the monsters are super basic, every now and then you will find a monster with some extra abilities that are basically just a variant of the same abilities from a lower lvl monster. Same goes for the animals in the game, you have 1 billion variants of wolfs and pigs and bears with a slightly different skin, there is no novelty what so ever. The quests rewards you with a lot of items that are basically junk tier or you won't use them ever as you aim to play with certain weapons and armor sets. Hands down the worst combat system in a MMORPG, it feels more rewarding getting a full row in Solitaire.

“New World” is a PC game developed by Amazon Games. It’s an MMO (Massively Multiplayer Online) game that has been described as having a colonial aesthetic and a theme of old-world pioneers exploring a magical island. However, the themes of colonialism aren’t really explored in depth, and it’s mostly cosmetic.

The game has been praised for its impressive ability to make tasks like chopping down 100 trees at 2 am seem like a reasonable, even entertaining, prospect. 

It also has a player-driven economy and a beefy crafting system. The combat system is action-oriented and requires you to aim each of your attacks, which can make the battles feel slick and engaging.

However, the game has been criticized for its lack of variety and novelty. Players often find themselves running through the same forests and facing the same enemies over and over again. The quests are described as dire, with the same handful of mindless objectives repeated ad nauseum. 

The game’s character customization and combat are held back by its limited attributes system.

In conclusion, “New World” is a game that tries to do a lot of things but stumbles frequently. 

It has some interesting features and ideas, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired. The game feels like it’s been algorithmically designed to ensnare anyone craving a big MMO, but the reality is a lot less scintillating.

I was admittedly surprised with how thoroughly I enjoyed my time with New World. From the freeform character and weapon progression to the resource gathering and faction dynamics, there’s a lot to explore and experience. That said, New World very much feels like an MMO in a very early state. There’s not a ton of Expeditions, there’s no mounts, and there’s an obvious need for balancing with features like Siege. Luckily, MMOs often get better as they age, and if Amazon Games can build upon this great foundation, they’ll have a surefire hit on their hands.

Got this game just under a year of it coming out. Not ever been an MMO fan but there was something about this game that kept me coming back to play. Stunning environments, range of ways to play and plenty to do.

Edit: Well played an additional 1500 hours since this review and the same is still true. There were a few large kinks when the expansion dropped however my review still stays positive about this game as they've been largely ironed out

Game starts off very well. Then after you hit mid level things change. Without the expansion you'd have to run horrible distances if you die to return to your last location. Mob density is decent but the aggro range is bad. They over populate the travel paths with enemies. The weapons are decent but the system punishes you if you don't keep to two types. Problem is they never let you pick reward weapons to keep the same types. Factions are lame, pvp only and gear looks differ. The faction quests are repetitive kill and fetch.  The resource gathering is ok, but people can steal your animal kills. 
The community in my region was pretty toxic for a non free to play game. Voice chat was disabled immediately in beginner town when you hear people thinking they are in a porn show. 
For $80 total with expansion you would be better off investing in something else.

While it's way to early to give a definitive review, I will say I'm glad I waited to give this a try, and really glad I decided to pick it up on the black friday sale. As a 17-year WoW player, New World is a breath of fresh air and ticks a lot of boxes for me. Graphics are more than acceptable for an MMO, combat feels good, plenty of gear with an easy to understand system, so far it feels very well-rounded and feature rich, although not without it's short comings. 

The main reason I'd recommend this game to any MMO fan, is the absence of a monthly subscription. It's insane to me that at fully fledged MMO is available for a single fee, you're welcome to play as much or as little as you'd like, and come back whenever without any additional commitment. Sure they charge for expansions, but so do the competitors-along with a monthly subscription fee.

I'd highly recommend the game so far, especially for casuals, or people who don't have 100 hours a week to devote to an MMO without the commitment of a monthly sub fee. Hopefully it continues to be a great experience, I'll sink a few hundred hours into this easy.

In 2021 Amazon tried to expand to the MMORPG market, with a Fantasy RPG called New World. The game would focus on crafting and PvP, with three major factions fighting for territory influence. The game wouldn't require subscription, which could encourage new players to move from subscription based games like World of Warcraft, Elder Scrolls Online, Final Fantasy Online. As players generaly hate the "Pay-to-win" games, all in the game should be available for free, and the microtransactions should be mostly around cosmetic elements. 

The game was released, there was a quick influx of players, and a very quick decline few months after. Unfortunately the game had a lot of bugs, common errors in translations, PvP balance issues and poor PvE layer, so after initial interest people started dropping (you can check the historical stats for example on mmo-population website).

However, Amazon didn't abandon the game and reallyfocused on improving it. After two years of their work I can confidently say that New World is finaly great! (It's a pretty similar case like the story of "No Man's Sky"). The game is finally a lot of fun! The PvE is exciting, there is a lot of interesing quests. The crafting is definitely the best comparing to all the other MMOs (I think Final Fantasy Online is pretty close though). The graphics are really pleasant, all characters are nicely voiced (also in different language versions), and the PvP seems to be finally balanced! 

The first expansion was recently released, which added new territories, increased the level cap and introduced mounts (with interesting leveling approach to the riding skill), There is a lot of fun with houses, cool instrument playing minigames providing buffs, and again the whole crafting layer which is simply amazing. The community is generally friendly 
(but please expect that there will be always someone who will race you to that sweet  harvesting node and "steal it" just from under your nose ;-) ). 

It's pretty obvious the game is for the international audience, as you can see people in chat speaking in different languages, but actually it is very nicely fitting the game story - people from different countries in our "Old World" are trying to colonize the "New World". And generally the story there seems pretty reasonable! 

The PvP is now fully optional and you can completely skip it, same as group content (major quest plot even gives you an option to select a "solo" or "group" path whenever it matters).
 
One thing that could be made better is definitely the complexity of quests, or maybe richer descriptions for the quest stages - but I suppose there is a lot of folks, who hate reading, so maybe developers tried to make stuff more casual and inteded for diverse audience. There are also supposedly still some bugs in quests (I encountered a single one after ~160 hours of play time), but fortunately the bugfixing is quite frequent. There are also still some random missing translations, but of course it matters only if you switch to other language version than the original English one. There are also sometimes login queues (that last for few minutes), but so far I encountered them maybe three times (while I logged to the game hundreds of times and actually mostly during the peak periods: evenings and weekends).

What surprises me the most is that there are still "haters"  complaining about the game both in the chat and on Internet forums (while still playing it of course). Especially focusing on expansion "price to content" ratio. I really don't get it - there is no subscription here, and all the microtransactions are fully optional. The game is constantly actively maintained. The price of the main game plus expansion is approximately around 6 monthly subscriptions for other MMORPGs. And you have to still pay in them for the game and expansions as well, don't you? But I suppose there would always be trolls.

Summarizing - great game, lot of fun, definitely worth the price (even non-discounted one). I definitely recommend it!

I loved the crafting and gathering and the PvP was fun. The dungeons and end game PvE needed some more work but as a PvP player I had plenty of stuff to do. HOWEVER, coming back to New World after more than 1 year later and realizing that half the game was behind a paywall is not okey. Using mounts in a MMO where traveling is a big part should NOT be behind a DLC, using a new weapon with a new skill line should also NOT be behind a paywall. Atleast not now. I can't give New World a positive review when I have to buy the game twice to be able to feel like I am playing the same game as everyone else in the world. If you like grinding (and I mean a lot of grinding!), now it's the perfect time to jump on in!

UPDATE 24/11: I know this game had its up & downs, however I still play to this date and I love it! With the addition of artifacts you can create lots of crazy builds, eg. I have a tank and a mage (with firestaff and greataxe) builds and they both work ^^

With the expansion many things became simpler (dungeon mutations, travel times etc) and the new area is amazing! However, they did lock down an area that was on the original version of New world and in order to access it you'll need the expansion. Minor thing to be honest, especially since the Burning Sands was a free expansion.

On the next update they will add a global-ish dungeon finder too, which is great!

The only major issue I have is that the developers haven't updated their Steam achievements with the launch of the expansion. Come on devs!

TL;DR Verdict: I highly recommend the game but ONLY with the expansion.

This game will suck you in and refuse to spit you out. It feels so simple at first, like playing a childhood game for the first time. But it pulls you in with its many weapon options, compelling storyline, wide array of skills and trades to learn, and its focus on making YOU THE PLAYER feel like THE player instead of A player. This isn't your run of the mill, ad infested MMO with a pay to win structure. The work you put in here will have results, and you won't feel like it's a chore to do so either. Exploration feels rewarding. Taking the time to hunt down a rare beast or even a lowly turkey has its rewards, and you'll find yourself doing it of your own volition with how rewarding it feels.

Overall? This feels like a full AAA title and deserves more publicity than it gets. I look forward to playing this for years to come.

Update 23/11/23 - This game feels great since the expansion came out. Approaching around 2,300 hours in game. The mounts are now available and completely add a new feel for moving around the map. Raid Groups of up to 20 people has been a fantastic change. I recently did the entire 0 - 65 journey on a 3rd character and the main story line feels great with the additional cut scenes, voiced characters and quest givers who follow you around the map. The running simulator has mainly gone. The new areas, towns and enemy types have been fun. Artifact weapons have been a good edition as well. Season 4 is shaping up to be interesting.

Update: 26/06/23 - I standby everything in my original review. I now have over 1,800+ hours into this game and every update, the devs are taking more and more positive steps. Very soon we will have crossworld OPR, 10 man trials, 20 man raids, raid groups, new 3v3 map, refreshed OPR map, searchable inventories in settlements (by name and perks), UI refreshes, and more. In season 3 we know now the wards/bane gear is being removed, the gearscore will increase, armour will get an overhaul, mounts will be a thing, a new expansion, new expiditions, new heartrune gems, fishing is getting overhauled. etc. There is a lot coming this year and a lot already delivered. If you're thinking about coming back to the game, perhaps wait until the big expansion release or dive in early now to see what you've missed. Season 2 launches in about 10 days.


Original Review: 
1,000+ hours in the game so far. Played since launch. Seen massive improvements with each new patch. Devs listen to community feedback. Since launch there are several new dungeons, a large new zone, 3v3 arenas, plenty QoL improvements, several new weapons, early levelling and story revamped, new mobs and creatures, fresh servers, new crafting materials and lots of twitch drops. All the while this game has remained with zero pay to win mechanics. Still to come but confirmed by devs: Raids and Mounts. 

There is still room for improvements here and there throughout the game, including some more QoL improvements but as it is right now, I'd happily recommend this game for someone looking for a new MMO to experience.

This is going to be a detailed review so bear with me please. There will be lots of similar reviews that say bits and maybe more of what I'm going to say and I believe this also proves my point.

At first glance when they announced that Amazon is developing an mmorpg, I was skeptical. But the other games that I was looking forward to didn't release yet and my friends decided to play it. Since New World wasn't such an expensive game for me, I warned my friends that this game doesn't seem to offer anything unique. Everything is so duplicated and reused that even without playing the game you can spot them through streams or videos.

For example:

From lv 1 to 40 zones (there are like 6-7 of them, afaik), all the critters and animals (boar, wolves, turkey etc.) are the same with a new name.

Other than that, all the monsters are the same with different names. Skeletons, Dead Pirates, Ghosts. Only at 45+ level zones, you get just a LITTLE bit diversity which is the Angry Earth enemies and corruption monsters. (Which are made for dungeons initially and released in open world with same abilities but different name)

Lootboxes are just duplicated all over the place and there are floating mines/collectibles across the map for days now.

Storage and market system is designed to make the game unique as you have to compete with other LOCAL sellers but it doesn't work that way. Storages are inaccessible after an enemy faction takes over (Worst part is yet to come about this, keep reading please)

 and Storages fill up really easily if you want to play different weapons/stats. Not to mention a feather weighing 0.1 so basically 5 iron ingots are as heavy as 12 feathers. (https://www.reddit.com/r/newworldgame/comments/qszonv/a_single_feather_is_01_kg/)

Game has no player base, and open world pvp is so boring. Here is my perspective: Unless people have more numbers, people just kept running away from me majority of the game. Even when i pmed them or tried to aggrevate them, they gave me excuses like "My pvp set is in my bank" or "I have my gathering set on" or "I'm a tank player doing this for the quest rewards, cant pvp now". I had to chase tanks with axes and greataxes across the map...

Playing together with your friends is another big problem in my eyes. You can't do quests together if you have a level gap between you and your friends because it's not effective. Also traveling back to zones you already cleared and wasting your azoth to help your friends is also inefficient. There is not much co-op in this game. Even if you want to give your friends your crafting mats, it poses a problem. The storage system makes it so hard to do so.

I've hit lv 60, did EVERY single map quest while waiting for my friends to catch up except a few: Shattered Mountain quests and Fishing quests. I also couldn't progress with my main story because some of them cant be done without a group of players and entrance is limited only to people who ALSO HAVE that same main quest ( which is utterly stupid because I literally cant do anything about it except spam global chat and hope someone else has proper class, gear etc to do the boss quest with me where you kill the Well Guardian after doing Dynasty Shipyard dungeon main quest, i believe someone can confirm this as well)

Also reekwater quests were bugged, Multiple instances of enemies spawned in same place, oneshotting anyone who walks by because of a bug so my reekwater questline is halfway done.

Now this part is where game becomes unplayable for me:

Skill trees not working as intended, my personal builds that I create can not be used.. (2 basic examples: Gravity passive in Great Axe skill tree stops Reap ability from dealing any damage there for Reap's passives also don't work which are supposed to heal you for %30 of the damage done. Also Sword and Shield's heavy attacks remove debuff on hit doesn't work, I've tried countless times. Might be patched now but Honestly, I dont care after i played the game for 280 hours with these bugs that I swapped to Dexterity and played bow/rapier)

After all the exploits about the game (food glitch, axe/greataxe/staff exploits where they deal so much extra damage for no reason) was shared on social media like reddit etc, suddenly game turned upside down. Some dude hits me 2k per hit with axe in Outpost rush I thought damn he really got really great gear. Then i realized after hitting lv 60 and Gear score level 580, my axes only hit up to 1k with 300 str/dex per hit? That was eye opening for me. Then we suddenly started losing territory that we didn't lose before and had highest upgrades across the server. 

This is where game makes me utmost angry and intolerant because every time we lost a territory or Outpost rush I cant help but think "Did i lose fair and square or did they abuse another glitch, hack, whatever". Then I started doing some more research and here are a few of the things I found out:

https://prnt.sc/207gu06 - Duplicated azoth... (Traveling and crafting material)
https://prnt.sc/207gwmo - Duplicated expensive crafting materials...
People duplicated so much gold during server transfers, I sadly dont have Screenshots to prove this.
High respawn rate zones that people just agro from distance and kill as groups to level up faster instead of playing the game.

Then my clan leaders also trying to "lecture" members on how they have to abuse the weapon bugs because we are losing to much territory... I believe other factions thought the same. Trust is destroyed between players. I don't blame company leaders for this but that's off topic. People opposed to abusing bugs anyway. But losing territory and having to move our storages with low amount of azoth wasn't so fun.

So I decided to quit the game and I advice anyone to quit it as well. This game was at best a failed attempt to make an mmorpg and rushed to get it out to players. All these major glitches, exploits, bugs whatever should've been dealt with during beta period. If the game is not ready to be played, you don't launch it and expect people to be okay with it. MMOs are fun because the environment is interactive and competitive. And it also is a fair battleground. 

This is all I can share, I hope you've seen my point of view. Take care!

As of the date of this review, many negative ratings were solely for the long queue times.  They will eventually be resolved since this is a new, highly anticipated, game and long queues are not unexpected.  So I will not comment further on that.

New World is a beautifully crafted game that should satisfy many gamers itch for something new.  The game's many delays have paid off.   Optimization is good, with an RTX 2060 Super I am 60+ fps even with dozens of players in an area. 

The cash shop (as of now) is cosmetics only, so no P2W here.   There is no subscription required either.

Crafting here is, by far, the best of any MMO I've played.   You are not limited to what you can do, the only thing you need is the time to do it.  Need lumber?  Well leave, go find a tree nearby and start chopping.  Kill an animal?  Feel free to skin it for leather and meat.  Crafting system is intuitive, easy to learn and anything you don't need can be either sold on the Trading Post or salvaged for materials.

There are no classes in the game.  Want to tank?  Equip heavy armor and a 1h+shield.  Prefer casting?  Go for light armor and a fire or life staff.   Kills earn you XP towards your level and the weapon used.  Even if you change weapons, progress on the other is not lost.   Your stats do affect how good you are with weapons, so plan that accordingly.  A good thing is that respeccing the weapon skills and your attributes is free until level 20.  Play around with builds til then to see what you enjoy the most.

Combat is action based, in that there is no tab targeting.  Tap left mouse to light attack, hold for a heavy.  The latter can break a block FYI.  As your weapons skill up you can have 3 active skills equipped with a lot of passives.  As you level you can hold more than 1 weapon, and switching is easy (primary weapon is default numeral key 1, secondary is 2).   

PvP is by consent.  You must manually flag in a town, then you will gain more XP but can be attacked by others of the other 2 opposing factions while out in the world.  Territory battles for what faction controls what part of the island can be quite large.   Often around 100 players or so will be fighting for control.

EDIT:

The devs still doing good work updating and improving the game.  More weapons have been added since launch.   The new DLC reworked First Light zone and added mounts, plus an increase in the level cap.  All in all, I've been pleased with how Amazon is continuing to support this game.

100/10

-Unfortunately, being a player there is no real way to influence direction, so this review is in hopes AGS sees and takes action. -  
AGS needs to hit the drawing board hard. The MMO is still in its infancy so it's not too late but as it is this game is a try at best for most and if you don't have the coin for more than one game pass try something else. I care about this game; this is not a bash, but it needs to be addressed and adjusted for it to succeed. 

The game needs some serious foundational attention, if this is your first MMO you'll have a great time for a couple hundred hours. A few of the bones are great but what the devs lean into is out of touch and seemingly done on a whim with little consideration for longevity. Mind you the game has come a long way, but they are still in the same vein they started in, and the player base shows it. The game's skill ceiling is the lowest you could possibly find in an MMO which is great for new players but leaves a lot to be desired if you're a fan of min/maxing.  

Of all the issues New World is currently facing and the backlash it is receiving the following immediate changes would correct the trajectory of the game.  

- Faction Vendor: Only charge faction tokens, do not adjust prices with gold removal.  

- Remove PvP Track and uncap Salt: In place of the track add a Vendor that players can use their Salt and only Salt to purchase the crafting components, attribute food & potions (give them a name like Salt Infused Health potion or Salt Infused Biscuit something to differentiate them from crafted or dropped items) and put the PvP armor transmogs in there.  

- Add a weekend PvP Vendor (that arrives at the same place and same time frame every weekend): this vendor will sell all of the Artifacts on rotation up the Azoth Salt prices to 100k - 150k. 

These changes allow PvPers to do what they like PvP. Use their resources to fund their builds and makes that part of the game special. This also allows players to take the rng out of the game a bit and replace it with content and effort in regard to the components and artifacts. 



- Add Merchants and a stall to the towns and wilds: a place where players can sell anything they want for a price. No tax, no fees, just a raw number range 20 - 100 depending on items. This will allow those with limited time to be able to accumulate funds to potentially use in the TP.  

- Allow Companies to bid on Merchants weekly: this will enable PvE or mercurial focus groups to claim ownership in Aeternum. They collect a tax based on the income the merchant receives. Players using this merchant do not pay this tax, but a percentage of the item sold value is sent to the company owning the merchant. One merchant per town and merchants in the wild allowing even a small company a chance to own and earn. 

- New town ownership opportunity: allow companies to engage the incumbent in a bidding war for town ownership. This adds a new layer to the ownership in New World and allows PvE companies a chance to own an entire town if they can outbid the current owners. They then are at a potentially greater risk for war and invasion failure due to the nature of the company. A company cannot own a merchant while owning a town. Have the merchants building start the night before reset and winners placed at reset.  

- Allow the deconstruction of gear: Different from salvaging, players can take any items to a corresponding bench and decon/salvage the item for a few of the main components in the item. No gold again just materials, set the base to 2 or 3 with a chance for 1 or 2 more. Crafting tax still applies.  

- Greatly reduce resource node cooldowns: this allows all players to harvest and have access to crafting materials. The market price will drop but there are players (like the PvPers) or those without time to fight others for real-estate or even stay up until the server's population drops, who are not inclined to farm but need the materials to craft.  

- Change teleport costs from azoth to gold (75 -100) and allow teleports from anywhere: this will help with the increased of gold in players pockets. Also allow players to teleport from anywhere as long as they are not in combat or flagged. Make the teleport from a shrine free.  

These economic changes will have a resounding impact on players' enjoyment and progress.  



- Uncap the number of dungeons per week: Allow PvEers to do the content they like without punishment. 

- Increase gold gained from mobs and guarantee drop chance of crafting components: this will allow those who just want to just play overland to be able to sell and make gold via PvE combat and selling of components in the TP ensuring a healthy economy.  

- Remove mount speed reduction off road: allow players to move as they desire, to maintain interest and ability to arrive at events timelier.  



These changes will allow players to play how they when they want regardless of the time available to them. This will also foster a community able to make and try more builds with the increased availability of materials and not be punished for making a mistake in crafting or being stuck to playing one style due to drops. While simultaneously making PvP and PvE feel special and appreciated. This I feel will greatly restore player happiness and increase population. Allowing AGS to continue to make changes and content with less blow back

Two hundred and seventy four plus hours of game-play so far, and I truly enjoy this game. I am a LONG time participant in so many MMORPG's. This one brings many of my favorite elements of some of the great predecessors. 
I am a quest grind machine. I can lose a lot of time just running around knocking out quests. New World feeds my insatiable appetite. End game can be a bit challenging, but there are lots of fellow Aeternumites who are willing to stop and pull you up from a near death experience. What to say about New Worlds. Honestly, when this game came out I thought it was gonna be a the MMORPG that people where looking for, that people had been asking for for years. I played it, and sure it had issues, it had problems, but with friends it was fine. Had it's own way of doing things, and remained interactive enough to where I enjoyed myself, until level 35. The grind was ungodly real. So I stopped, and then they updated the game a bunch. I came back, I played more, enjoyed myself, until level 35. The grind was still just so much, it had gotten better in some areas and worse in others. I stopped, they updated the game, released some DLC, so I came back. Now the game feels pretty good, other than the now awful stuttering and continual crashing that I and my entire group of game buddies feel. Do I wish there was another game I could play that was better? Yes. Have I found that game yet? Nope, not even close. 

All in all, this game scratches the itch, at least long enough for you to find something else. Just know what your getting into before you buy.

I will preface my review on what I was wanting out of this game before I give my opinion: I wanted a game I could enter into without needing a degree to understand, that isn't particularly deep to start with but has more complexity if I wish to get more involved and that provides me a mindless relaxing grind to waste some hours and a plot I can pretty much ignore. 

New World meets ALL these requirements I had for a relaxing casual time killer. The game is mid at best but it is so easy to understand and immediately start playing it is ideal for a casual like me who really isn't that invested or expecting to be playing this game in a years time. 

I watch content on YouTube while playing this, I ignore every bit of dialogue and only do what I feel like doing and it all works perfectly well and I do appreciate that. As I said, the game is actually pretty mid and dare I say a bit soulless but it also doesn't ask a lot of the player and is ideal for a casual who just wants to MMO without constantly having to go online to figure out how to do basic things. I actually wanted to try ESO again but when I started it up a few months ago I had totally forgotten just about everything and I could not muster up the energy to bother doing it all over again but I feel I could stop playing this game for a year and pick it up again with no real issue. 

The game runs fine for me, it looks pretty nice at times but not amazing which is expected as they obviously want to have it playable on even the lowest end PC. I encountered a few minor bugs here and there but nothing that re-loading into the server didn't fix. 

I am no MMO expert so I wont even pretend to be an authority on these games but for what I wanted out of this game it is perfectly adequate and mediocre and so far I have enjoyed it, even if I cant say I love it.

UPDATE Nov 23.
The "optional" DLC costing €29 turns out to be more a relaunch of the game than additional content. If you don't purchase the DLC you are locked out of core game items such as character level progression and skill level progression. So if you don't buy it, you can sit and stagnant while being rejected from group content because you are not lvl 65. 
For a new player I still think the base game is worth it. You will get many hours of fun following the MSQ and completing Brimstone Sands. After that it's just the same old grind, except you have to pay extra for the privilege to take part.

I downloaded this game with high hopes and expectations. I though to myself "this game could be a WoW smasher, a game changer"......but boy was I ever let down. I'll list the pro's and con's and you guys can decide on whether or not to purchase it. 

Pro's
-Amazing sound!! Best effects I've ever heard in my life
-Amazing Graphics
-Lots of stuff to do if your a completionist
-13 Weapons to date to master and get good with
-Lots of armor and look cool cosmetics
-Super forgivable!!! If you're new to the MMO genre this game is a nice starter.....till you hit the new content 

Con's
-Every time AGS does an update, they break 3 mechanics in the game.....minimum
-AGS loves to eliminate simple exploits that just allow you to either cheese a boss or at least make it easier
-Painfully frustrating when the mechanics are ruined by a past update
-Every new release to the game requires you to be at max GS in order to play it and enjoy your time doing it
-Toxic community! The level of fanboys in this game is unreal! You can never have an open discussion with anyone in this game, it will always result in at least 5 people either just calling you names like an adolescent boy or they will just say "if you don't like it, don't play". That argument alone screams "I'm going to accept the game for broken, and you can't change my mind"
-The pvp system is janky to be nice. OPR is quite terrible truth be told. The latency in most OPR's is insane. The new "perks" they added to the game like "freedom" make it so CC is almost null and void. Playing anything other then the "META" is almost pointless
-Referbished enemies throughout the entire game. 0 changes, same enemies, same moves, they just hit harder as you go through the levels
-3 Factions in game with the most lack luster story ever....if at all. Factions hold 0 to the game what so ever unless you're looking to get into the open world pvp. Faction races are about as much fun as watching paint dry. You get quests from the faction vendor, run out in pvp status and do the quests, you return to the faction vendor and rinse and repeat. This will get your "influence" up and thus allow you to war with said town. Yay!!!
-Most lack luster story I've ever played. Convoluded quests mixed with alliances that make 0 sense, mixed with antagonists with 0 backround. It felt like dry wall puddy, just filling in the holes so that no one questions what was behind the actual motives
-Agro table makes 0 sense. Tanks can lose agro in the middle of the fight to a dps or a healer thats stood still the entire match
-Dungeon's are super lame. Everything feels like a figure 8, feels like a lazy designer
-Bots, bots gallore!!! Good luck getting resources as the bots in this game are in full spread.

All of these are my opinion's on the game. Take them for what it is. I've invested 700 hours into the game with my fingers crossed that it was going to get progressively better and I've been let down by the presentation of whats come thus far. I still have high hopes but its going to take alot of work to get there.

Thank you for reading

Edit:

I have put alot more man hours into the game recently and I modestly must say that it is getting better.....slowly, but surely.

The new upcoming roadmap shows a bit of actual end game content and this is exactly what we needed. I am afraid to say though that it may or may not be enough to save the game. 

The community has become super toxic and the new "meta" has the new player base suffering incredibly. The skill set you need to have to run the late game content in this new "meta" form is something only hours of playtime will give you. The community has become elitist and unforgiving. 1 mistake and you're either booted from the group or flamed. Its become pretty toxic.

The average player may enjoy this if they don't have their hearts set on doing the mutations every week or completing the season's pass but the die hards of this game, the completionists, struggle more now than ever. 

I don't revoke my original statement where the game is bad, but I will say that it is getting slowly better.....very slowly. I respect that now they test out every patch in the PTR and most if not all the content that finally goes to live is patched and ready for play. 

I for the most part enjoy my time in New World but it definitely has its "I'm ready to uninstall" moments. If it isn't the community, then its the server lag. If you're patient and want to see this game flourish like the rest of us do then by all means buy it and try it out. If you find you don't like it or its not your niche then you can close the doors to it and try something else.

The pvp in this game is incredibad! The servers can't keep up with what you're doing. You'll be fighting a player who's taking 0 damage and then half a second later he's across the map. 

3v3 arena matchmaking is like league of legends bronze hell. The team comps make 0 sense, the average team is just terrible, and then allowing players to potion and run is super defeating. This whole experience needs a rework something fierce

2nd Edit - Expansion:

So I purchased the expansion and it started out really good......for an entire day! The "expansion" content can be completed in an afternoon leaving you wanting more for your money. That being said, they have released alot of content for free so I can't judge too harshly.

Mounts - integral part of the game. I honestly didn't know what I was missing out on till I tried them out. Moving between areas feels soooooo much better. That being said, they are still not glitch free and pretty janky. I know that they'll get better over time but atm its painful.

Flail - Flail feels really good, the animations are crisp and the skill tree is fantastic, all in all....however, it does have its own glitches as well. The agro table when using a flail is so mangled that tanking with it is a chore and not very fun....and this is coming from someone who genuinely tanks with it.

New Zone - Elyssian Wilds is crisp and clean. It looks pretty good for a rewrite of an area. They made sure to keep the old look but just "spice" it up a bit. The old nostalgic areas are still around, they're just wrapped in Angry Earth. 

Story - The story for the expansion is kinda lack luster truth be told. It feels almost rushed. It started out really strong and really gets you into the lore of the area quick but by the end you just feel like it was rinse and repeat from a Brimstone quest chain. I enjoyed the story when I was running with a pack of allies and we were all storming objectives but as I roam around the new area more and more its barren, desolate, and still unfriendly. The only thing that truly intrigued players were the 2 new chest runs

Chest Runs - They added 2 new areas for the Epic Chests to spawn in. 1 of the 2 areas is a genuine chest run with a boss farm and even artifacts that drop. The 2nd chest run is a jumping puzzle of lag and frustration. Half the puzzles don't work, the enemies knock you off and there's less epic chests there than Mines in shattered mountains.

Artifacts - The artifacts either make or break the game. Some of them are so incredible that using them almost feels like a cheat code. Some of them are so lack luster that when you do finally acquire them you want to dismantle. Artifacts drop few and far between, and I mean every syllable!! You get 35 mutations a week and you'll easily burn through those and still leave empty handed. The "drop rate" is abysmal! It feels more like a farming simulator than an MMO. Now, I do agree that acquiring them should take a level of skill or time but jesus christ 35 mutations in and still no sight of it.....horrible decision AGS!!!

Good MMO for 1st time leveling, but once I reach max level I feel like there's nothing to do, but technically there are tons of. I hope they have an update on the future where exp is not wasted on max level if it makes sense.

Pay to Continue..

I absolutely love this game. The crafting system is one of the best I've ever experienced. The gathering system is even better. The vast majority of things you see in the wild from rocks to trees and plants etc is gather-able. The player base is large enough to find people to do stuff with and the economy seems to be doing alright. At first things may seem expensive as gold gain starts slow but you easily catch up enough to realize it feels okay. The new expansion (although it was small considering the game has been out for so long and this is the first expansion) added some really great content. What really draws me to this game as my new main MMORPG is the classless system. I absolutely love the idea of freely switching your class because the skills are tied to the weapons themselves. Each weapon boasts 2 specs, each with 3 unique skills, and you can wield 2 weapons at a time. This game feels so unrestricted that it seems like you can do whatever you want. Player housing, costumes, factions, and a huge PVP focus (although you can play the game entirely without touching PVP) are all bonuses. I definitely recommend this game. I think the price is worth it at full price, even better when it's on sale. EDIT: i'm only adding this portion for the task for updating my review for a game i nominated

I'm pretty conflicted with this game. On one hand, it does a lot of things right. The actual mechanics for combat and pvp are fantastic. The implementation and balance of them? Not so much. But, my god, it does so much wrong.

I've given it 3 legitimate tries. Release, return to aeternum, and now elysian wilds. It seems like they just don't learn from any of their previous failures. Leveled each time fresh.

Perks and pvp traits are just TERRIBLY balanced. You can really tell they don't have any sort of team dedicated to balancing and implementing pvp and perks. Perks that are so overpowered that if you don't have them and you are fighting someone that does, you just lose. When you have to balance pvp by nerfing and buffing ANYTHING by 50-75% that just reeks of having absolutely no idea how your own game plays and the numbers work. Its awful and just terrible to deal with if you are anywhere near a casual player just trying to gear up. The meta shifts, you finally put together a PVP set with the OP perks and then BAM! It's nerfed into oblivion.

The economy is in shambles. There's too much money going out for upgrades which are being rendered obsolete through nerfs and not enough being generated. There's not enough materials in the world to sustain more than a handful of crafters at any given time. Of course- if you already have the trophies, 250 skill, a full crafter set then yes, you can still pull some profit. You just need a small loan of 300k from someone to get you there.

The mounts are great. The races are a bit ...much. They get extremely tedious after the 2nd tour set.

They still havent solved the issues revolving around mutations requiring specific gems/resists just to get into a group. They make it very difficult to have a use for any of the high level runeglass gems. They still cycle and if you miss the one that has one of your artifacts, youre SOL for another month.

Quests are still buggy and janky as hell. They seemed to have fixed a majority of the story quests but it should not take 3 weeks to fix a MAIN STORY QUEST that unlocks your Heartgem slot.

End game doesnt seem to have changed at all. Bunch of people just war log. You can do Mutations and ECR 

Influence races were pretty fun when the numbers were close but quickly get expensive and unfun when outnumbered. Grinding pvp levels hoping for an artifact got old pretty quick.

Dark matter doesnt drop enough and you need a shitload.

Unfortunate, really. I really hoped the balance and tweaks would improve with time but it is just as bad as ever.

This game has come a long way. I can't say it's perfect. It's often monotonous, the quests really suck, the faction system is iffy, etc, etc. That being said, it's crafting system is addicting, the visuals and audio are great, and combat is engaging. If you are predisposed to grinding, this is definitely the game for you, for better or worse.

Did it have a rocky start? Sure. All MMO's do. However, this team has spent 2 years with updates, hotfixes, events, adding content, and their labor has really shown. This game has become one of the best MMO's I have played in years. And now, after 2 years they released their first paid DLC and people want to jump up and down screaming they've made the game P2W. That's absolute garbage. Other MMO's release new paid DLC every year or two AND have a subscription model (which this game does not) and they are hailed as absolutely fantastic, when the truth of the matter is it's mostly rehashed content for a game that's severely outdated (Looking at you WoW). I would honestly have way more time in this game than I do if it weren't for the fact that I'm a father of young children and work full time.

The problem with appealing and listening to the MMO community in 2022 is the fact that they want everything to be easy, quick and they want to rush through the content as fast as possible using guides, and then complain that there is nothing to do (perfect example – crying about making rank 3 essences in World of Warcraft - Battle for Azeroth, Echoes of Ny’alotha account-wide, as people were too lazy to farm them on more than 1 character).

The game obviously had many issues at launch, and some still have not been fixed. As of writing this review, only 17% of people have gotten the Steam achievement of reaching level 60. But at the start of The Heart of Madness update the developers thought it’s a good idea to quadruple the amount of experience and double the amount of weapon mastery people receive. Some quests had been broken for months at the time, but instead of fixing them right away after receiving hundreds of reports about it on the forum, they had always waited to release a big patch fixing multiple issues at once. I don’t blame people for quitting, but for some reason the developers decided to punish people who actually stuck with the game and took the time to level up and grind weapon mastery, instead of making the levelling experience more enjoyable and bug-free so that people can go at it at the initially intended pacing. Speeding up the pacing makes more sense in MMORPGs like World of Warcraft, where after a new expansion comes out, the previous one becomes irrelevant and it is impossible to find parties for content from the previous expansions (on top of that, in World of Warcraft you oftentimes have to make new characters if you want to try out different classes/professions, which is not the case in New World). FOCUS ON MAKING CONTENT BETTER AND MORE ENJOYABLE, NOT ON APPEALING TO LAZY PEOPLE THAT WILL COMPLAIN ABOUT THE GAME ANYWAY.

As of April 2023, there are pay to win elements in the game. If you have Amazon Prime, you can get Vials of Suspended Azoth and Umbral Shards on Twitch after linking your accounts. On top of that, there is a premium Battle Pass which rewards you Gypsum Orbs, coins and other things affecting the gameplay like the territory standing boosts which translate into having faster gathering time, lower taxes as well as more storageroom.

In October 2023 they released the first "expansion", which in reality was a $30 patch that was more comparable to the free Brimstone Sands update size-wise, than to any proper expansion in proper MMOs like FFXIV or WoW. On top of that, it seems that they will keep releasing four Battle Passes a year, with multiple pay 2 win elements mentioned before. It is also the first time that achieving all Steam achievements is not possible anymore; you cannot earn territory standing in First Light anymore as it has been transformed in the new expansion's map, but the achievement still remains. It has been clear that the developers do not play the game from the very start, there are bugs I have been encountering daily since the game was released more than two years ago that nobody seems to care about (like the visual bug of displaying gaining territory standing for the zone you are currently in when paying upkeep from the map UI, or the bug of not being able to use hotkeys/click on items to separate them), and now they are asking the community to nominate the game for the "Labour of Love" for Steam Awards 2023. If anything, they could have had the award for the greediest developer, but it seems that Blizzard put Diablo IV and Overwatch 2 on Steam.

As the first experience for Amazon company, it can be said that this company has been able to attract many gamers.
This game can be considered as a successful experience for Amazon.

  New World is an attractive and enjoyable title that can entertain you for hours.
 
This MMO is a single-player adventure experience with PvP elements.

It is enough for you to experience this title for an hour, then you will see that this one hour has turned into several hours.

Meanwhile, you might be wondering why you should spend so much time running from one point to another, when having a horse or speed would have made the game itself more enjoyable.

All in all, New World is one of the most enjoyable MMO titles in recent years. This game is also a good starting point for players new to the MMO genre.

New world has an amazing core. I love it. Its why I have over 500 hours in game, but sadly the devs of this game ignore huge issues have no clear direction. Feedback takes months or even years for the devs to act on, all while the game bleeds players. Balance patches are done with an iron fist rather than small tweaks, and ignore core issues.

The devs seem to keep following the same loop. Players ask for x change, they ignore the feedback or tell us they not going to do it. Players leave. Devs see this then finally listen to the feedback. Then this loops over, and over, and over again for every key bit of feedback. It happened with mounts, fast travel, levelling, quest, group finder, the main end game loop, etc. Now its happening again with the economy, game balance in pvp, the pvp track, cost of changing skills. I'm sure they'll fix all these issue, like they have with the past ones, but they'll keep their head in the sand and only finally do it when players really leave.

I would love the say the game is good now, to tell people to come back, but I can't. I only wish that this game was in the hands of another team.

Played this game for approx 2,5k hours on 3 accounts, grinded the shit out of the game to earn money for a strong set of PvP Gear (Which you can only get by being lucky, either gambling with insane amounts of high level materials or being insanely lucky to get a good itemdrop). The big summer update which they released did not only contain a summer event based literally only on the least liked tradeskill (fishing) and the new instruments tradeskill. So to summarize the event: Its an RP Event no one should take serious. A shitty event wouldnt be the only problem though. After introducing Gear Downscaling for new lv60 players earlier this year (or at the end of the last year, cant remember), AGS though it would be great to make their game more casual friendly and remove "gatekeeping".

How did they do it? Not by removing the downscaling, but by overtuning the drops so absurdly that literally anyone collecting 5-10 lootboxes of the PvP gamemode "OPR" (which takes maybe 4-5 hours to do) will very likely get a Best in slot item for PvP, even a neutral "universal" BiS if theyre somewhat lucky, therefore invalidating the time and effort of PvP players who spent a lot of time getting their hands on decent equipment.

Lets talk about the "PvP" mode OPR... you will see people chopping down trees in this mode since they can use the wood to put up gates in the forts (controlpoints) their team owns. Whats so bad about this? They can repair those gates. And you can literally outrepair those gates at max level against 10 players trying to tear it down. How is that supposed to be PvP?
There is the option to construct a respawn point for your own team in those forts as well. Those were towers people could see and shoot while being outside of the fort, therefore forcing the enemies to do something about you, if you didnt want to lose your respawn for free. The update changed those so that there is no way for you to damage them without either opening the doors or already being inside. 
The game has become a shitshow which keeps catering towards casuals and PvE players while constantly fucking around with the stuff that makes PvP interesting. fun, or at least good enough to keep playing the game.

If you want to casually play a game for PvE or RP? Sure, go ahead. But I recommend not even thinking about it ever again if you want your game to be more than an unrewarding, dull and stupid farming sim.

New world isn't as bad as people say.... 

The game has issues like lack of end game content, poor leveling system that seems repetitive, and lag issues. Sadly it does feel it needed another year of development. Though in the meantime it's worth the price of $40 without a subscription. 

The game currently is fun and I will continue to play because in a year it will be one of the better MMOs on the market. The developers have been listening to the fans and have been putting out videos to show they are listening and staying transparent with the players. It may not make a final fantasy turn around but the game will rebound.

This games current story so far really does its best to engulf the player into the world. 
Crafting and hunting is simplified enough that both casual gamers and hardcore gamers won't complain about it.
The cities and towns are big and plentiful and each really feel like their own But a few have a copy a paste thing going on.

Enemies aren't that impressive. It seems every region you go to you're facing the same enemy types over and over. The few bosses and event bosses I've encountered were very unique. Though I had little to no trouble soloing them. 

My only negatives so far is getting gold is kind of like real life. You get paid 40.12 gold for a completing a quest but, items or even houses you want to buy are very expensive. 
Swimming is none existing in this title. If you go into deep waters you have 20 seconds to walk out or you die. This game has been out for two years and a simple swimming mechanic hasn't been added.
So far, trading seems to be done between players only. So if you have junk you want to sell, You gotta hope a player wants it. I hope this gets updated later on. I've collected alot of trash items since I started that I'd like to get rid of without having to scrap or drop.

I'd like to see companions and new races added to the game in the future. I'm mostly a solo player due to my work schedule and others schedules never lining up. 

Overall this is game is a very decent MMO.
Story- 8-10
Combat- 7-10 (Would be higher if the enemy types weren't annoyingly similar everywhere you went.)
World building- 10-10 (7-10 for the copy and paste)
Graphics- 10-10
Crafting-10-10

[Update] 500 hours ago, I said it failed to deliver PvP, is a monotonous & grindy PvX, and that patches break things. After a couple years, these things are all very true still - I mean, they still have the same bugs from original launch (like trading post, haste bug, etc.). Endgame is literally grinding whatever a player thinks is BIS just to do all the redundant, unchallenging content they had to grind to get there.

It has the skeleton of something that could be quite good, but there's still no meat on the bones after all this time. 

[1500 hour review] Ok. I have some hours clocked, right? I was incredibly enthusiastic about this game because it was promoted as a PvP heavy game. Now, it's a poor quality PvX. The dungeons aren't challenging - Gear Score (grinding to level up your gear) is the only real inhibitor to doing dungeons easily (gems for elemental resistances and race specific armor resistances recommended). Not skill. Not mechanics. Not synergies. PvP has been reduced to: 1) a 20v20 that incorporates no balanced/ranked matchmaking, 2) 3v3 arena that is not rewarding so no one is queued, and 3) open world...if you flag (few do)...for next to no rewards. Merging servers has broken apart my communities and made it difficult to find new, active groups; this has happened several times. Finally, things just break or don't work after every patch, and at this point it's just disheartening.

Overall, I'd give New World the rating of "meh." I'm about tapped out, but once I quit, I won't return unless glowing reviews from peers start coming at me - something the last shred of hopium looks forward to.

I've been playing "New World" since its launch and it's honestly a blast, especially the PVP. It's really fun and feels right. The devs seem to be hitting their stride lately with new updates making the game better than it was at release. The Artifact weapons are a cool touch for collectors and the combat has a solid, satisfying feel to it.

Dungeons like the Tempest Heart are immersive and some of the best times I've had in-game. The atmosphere they've created is top-notch.

As for negatives... the tooltips can be misleading—they don't always match what's actually happening in-game, which can be a bummer. But overall, "New World" is worth sinking your teeth into if you're into MMORPGs with substantial content.

Also I wish each weapon had one or two more skills, 3 is not quite enough. Or maybe make both weapons attacks usable without having to swap weapons first.

Note I am currently writing this in a not so happy state of mind, This game is amazing. The mechanics and world building are some of the most fun I have experienced in my time gaming.

The problems

The quests are uninspired fetch quests and generic kill quests – nothing to keep you engaged or excited about the next objective.

The touted player-driven economy is a joke. The market system is poorly designed, and it's impossible to make a decent profit without sinking an exorbitant amount of time into mindless resource gathering and crafting. The whole concept of player-driven economy ends up being more of a chore than a rewarding aspect of the game.

Graphically, the game is mediocre at best. While some environments are visually appealing, the character models and animations are outdated. It's like stepping back in time to the early 2000s, and not in a nostalgic way.

The gear progression system is flawed. Certain armor sets and accessories clearly outshine others, creating a clear hierarchy that renders many items obsolete. This lack of diversity in viable gear options makes the grind for better equipment feel less rewarding, as the endgame essentially becomes a quest for a specific set of overpowered gear rather than a meaningful exploration of different playstyles.

Crafting also suffers from poor item balancing. Some crafted items are so powerful that they completely overshadow the rewards from challenging PvE content. This undermines the sense of accomplishment from defeating tough bosses or completing challenging dungeons when the loot they drop is less valuable than what can be crafted with relatively common materials.

Save your time and money for a game that truly offers a next-level gaming experience.

good and bad

While the expansion in general is a correct step forward.  The problems in the game are ones of design.

* Economy.
* Gathering.
* Loot acquisition.
* Technical Debt.

The economy of this expansion has capped the cost of items.  But the drops you can earn randomly by playing can be BIS (outside of certain perks being unavailable).  So it becomes a "how quickly do I earn gold" vs "how quickly do I win the loot lottery" vs "players are constantly devaluing items due to competition with players with less and less gold".  There will be a point where the best path to equipping a new character will be 'start over, do the quests for gold, and buy from the auction house'.  Even supersizing your houses (and their weekly taxes).

Gathering.  The game has a tiered pyramid system where A is ued to make B which is used to make C.  However the tools the developers have have very limited abilities to add new resouces to the map.  They can change what drops per spawn, but apparently in a resource gathering game, adding resources is "hard". It has been this way for years when the devs said adding Trees to OPR (to add more musket/bow/firestaff defense) was difficult.  Players optimize their time, afk farm resources, and players running around for resouces spend a lot of time finding already exhausted resources.  Then you have the "Can I craft for myself, as a solo self bound?"  The answer is: Yes, maybe, do you have a life... do you hate yourself?  You will likely give up, because the 10s of 1000s of resources required aren't worth solo farming.  And this is the problem: One persons investment in their gear is NOT the same as anothers.

Loot Acquisition. If you gold buy you can have bis in hours.  If you solo farm resources and craft, years.  The devs can decide your items are useless almost on a whim.  Demoting your playstyle with perk changes.  Basically this game is a "Farm the patch" game (earn artifacts/seasonal events the first days/week they are released) and check the auction house for your specific needs at other times.  Gradually earn dark matter given your playstyle and realize you will have far more items that need dark matter than you can acquire so you stop caring.  Your bank will be filled with tons of 'maybe someday' items.  Items that used to be 600 and useful and you pushed to 625 for specific needs became 632 and required 15k gold and weeks (or hours of dungeons) in Dark Matter to "see" if the item is useful.

Technical Debt.  The tools/software the developers have do not allow them to maintain quality and it is left to a revolving door of team members who lack deep understanding.  Ex: You can find Flails with Bane as Named Drops.  The expansion removed Bane.  The existence of these items to veteran players is proof the developers don't care or the tool used to create the items is inept. The devs appear to have meetings and argue over usage reports. The reports will nevershow apathy,

Can you enjoy this game? Yes. Unless you have a guild, or have specific self formed goals, just play the patch.

Game has alot of potential, I'd recommend giving it a try. 

There is alot of bugs, I've yet to run into a bug that has caused game breaking/progress denying issues...

(asfaik gamers I've met from WoW tend to struggle adapting to the ui ... somehow imo the ui is super simple but it might be confusing due to lack of information outside the boundaries of translations)

Sometimes the waypoints become finicky and changes based of your location

 (when moving between territories it will try to prioritize the missions in that territory it gets confusing as you'll have to manually pin quests if you accept too many to avoid running back and forth wondering why the waypoint keeps looping you around )

The crafting is interesting however collecting resources can become the most competitive thing in this game since all the resource points are shared. If someone else takes it you have to wait 5-15mins and race to the next one. im not a fan of due to. 
Some "bots" or extremely efficient players make it difficult. imo 250 player servers feel just right in resources, but near impossible to find expeditions.

(this will change with upcoming updates according to a roadmap as of 2023~ giving expeditions ques to "all servers/worlds?" )

The Populated servers have alot more players, and not enough resources so the 1000+ population worlds are... not entirely enjoyable in comparison to lower population servers

(wish you could freely choose your server on log in but I understand why this is still common in older <- mmos being in a seeded que on login to place you in the best possible server location, but able to join friends would be nice too... but it might change the economy/enjoyment of community/guilds given the way the territories in the game work)

The community is quite.... unique... overly political and easily angered.... individuals i've encountered scream a inferiority complex so some of those individuals try to shit on others instead of trying to help newer players from what I noticed in both EU/US servers... relatively speaking its unfriendly to newer players.... unfortunate...

If you're expecting to do dungeons or have "competent" teams with PuG matches its not going to go well most of the time.... gear does matter in this game compared to some other MMOs and 2 random dungeons have mutations which furthur increases the difficulty of the enemies and your Gear Score matter at an noticeable degree even though they dont really increase the damage from 10 to 100 but it feels like that (the enemies tend to be "weaker?" to higher gear score weapons and do less dmg to higher gear score armor) I really like the Gear score Mechanic as it adds more depth to your builds, 

This game isn't bad at all I'd still recommend giving it a try, however don't depend on most guides as the game changes become drastic over time asfaik which is honestly pretty well done imo as it makes tinkering with builds and trying new things less "meta" however there will be constant "opinions" on what should be done~

Also here a recipe that i copied from somewhere else xD 

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

the combat system and gathering of open world resources (the world is beautifully created and can provide you some very nice scenery screenshots with your character) are the only thing that is good in the core game and what keeps me coming back after every 6 month or so break from the game out of frustration from the countless issues in other areas.

i do not recommend this game unless you want to see the combat system and the resource gathering in action. the msq and side quests will provide enough game time to get your money worth out of it while you do that.
