New world is one of the few MMos I've been able to bring myself to play and keep playing for a very long time. Unlike most Mmos, New world has some weapons that allow a way more interactive combat system that requires you to actually aim to hit your targets, even having head shot bonuses instead of a click and charge ability that can't miss unless rng decides. 

The progressions starts of kind of clunky but gets real fun once you learn the basics and picked what weapons and playstyle you want to use. Unlocking abilities and gear to better suit your playstyle is also really cool. 

However, the game gets extremely repetitive fast and you find yourself doing essentially the exact same quests and activities over and over and over until you finally reach lvl 60 and can try out PvP for the first time only to find it all has devolved into any other MMo PvP with absolute spam shitfiesta fights consisting of nothing but dodge spam, Aoe spam, aim assist melee spam and some more spam. It's incredibly annoying and unrewarding trying to use any sort of accurate aiming abilities especially in many fights where the servers are performing so bad that many shots never even register. 

This wouldn't be as bad if it weren't for one small detail. You can't use any sort of mounts or level up past 60 in the game unless you buy a 30 dollars season pass in the game that already has an item shop and battle pass. 

In any sort of PvP scenario which there are a few of, this makes the game plain and simple Pay 2 Win. 

There is no point arguing this to the currently insanely delusional, obnoxious and toxic playerbase because 1. They don't posses basic math skills and logical understanding or 2. They suffer from excessive amounts of sunk-cost fallacy and are high on copium trying to make up excuses for the game and do mental gymnastics on why It's not Pay 2 Win to pay real money to get an advantage over someone in a PvP game scenario who hasn't paid real money. 

Overall decent start to an MMo but quickly devolves into garbage. There's not a bright future for this game with how boring it gets long term and the fact that it allows blatant Pay 2 Win in a fully paid 40 dollar PC game in 2023 is fucking madness. 

Also, it certainly doesn't help that the game has lost over 95% of its playerbase. Hmm I wonder why.
Healers are overpowered as fuck in 3v3. Unbalanced and GMs dont give a shit, and keep nerfing damage weapons.

Great mmo and would recommend for people who like grinder games like hypixel skyblock.

It has potential in buckets the game, but its constantly failing to deliver now and turning into a hot dumpster fire of frustration. 

The content is wafer thin, it has all the feel of a paid beta at this stage that's been released onto us, they had a duping bug problem for about three weeks which gamers have gotten away with now to the resentment of a lot of the player base as their running around in gear they shouldn't have and ferreted away on alts as I understand it, though no proper explanation from the dev team if they dealt with this stuff, 

It has too numerous bugs top mention at this stage and a dev team which does very little interaction with the player base outside of the token minimum on their forums when people scream enough, there's no road-map for the game and no development plan we can see at all yet.  The devs also failed to secure their bug reporting forum properly so it basically became a library of exploits instead of just hiding posts between the dev and the person reporting it, then they wonder why you suddenly get mass exploits taking place when they effectively hold a library of them on their forums fully accessible to all of the player base.

The amount of content as you progress through the game becomes wafer thin the more you level, as you hit 60 the max level then,  you get to then have to level up a "watermark" system that you cannot see in game and it gives you no clue as to what you should do to level your gear, the dev team made changes then to all of the elites pretty much locking the people out of this gearing up who were slower levelling as it wasnt worth the effort anymore and anyone who didn't have all this gear farmed now have much less of a chance of getting gear like other players now, they did this in an "undocumented change" in a patch too which was particularly galling as it was done hush hush and then hastily apologised for with a weak explanation for fundamentally changing the game.

It has got systems in place which do things like auto-ban people on mass report abuse which player companies do in game a fair amount and I have seen repeatedly now and if you get banned  then Amazon have zero decent customer support behind it to be able to deal with that smoothly and swiftly for the person their system has been abused to ban, there's no point raising an appeal as the people you raise it with don't seem to have any easy ability to deal with it either to add to the frustration, the offenders then get away with it too while my friends get banned out of wars, this whole auto-ban setup makes you not want to talk in global chat at all or interact with anyone in the world for fear of being banned from the game for nothing now other than being in an area where other people who outnumber you have decided to farm also, it needs turning off and they need to employ actual GMs or Admins in game that are contactable live to deal with issues in game.

The numerous bugs I could put up with as they were dealing with them quickly and timely, but the most recent one has broken me really, - Despite me having uncovered all of the towns and all the fast travel points in the game, it decided then in a bug after the latest patch, that it was going to completely remove my inn recall and all fast travel points and teleport ability to towns that I had accessed previously, to sort that out I would have to walk the entirety of the map again picking up these points for the second time which would take me about 4/5 hours because of the map sizes and pathing I would have to take.

I cannot recommend the game to anyone as it stands, I will say that I do like the game a lot, its very enjoyable and different to other MMOs in the genre coming from a WoW point of view it was refreshing to begin with, but at the moment, its so volatile from patch to patch with the dev team seemingly overwhelmed that I just cannot recommend it to others, maybe a year down the line this can be revisted to see if its improved, but as of now my opinion stands.

Update: 
I returned to the game after leaving it as I said above, its fresh start realms free of the cash rich dedupers and the game is in an infinitely better position than the first review that I made, its now an enjoyable experience free of annoyances like Expertise grinds and features an infinitely better story driven levelling experience than it did at launch and I would recommend it based on the multitude of improvements the developers have made.

Since launch the player experience has continued to improve. Yes you need to complete the main story to have full freedom in the game, but you don't need to focus on it. It's a good game when you have an itch to grind something or play solo or play with a guild. It may feel daunting to excel at every tradeskill and weapon, but if it was easy then it would get boring quick. The server population is mainly end-gamers but that doesn't mean they've done everything. Likely a very small portion of players have everything maxed out. I am a veteran MMORPG gamer, its my favorite type of gaming. I have end game comps in every popular MMORPG game that has been released since 2000.

My biggest beef with New World is the resource nodes are far and few and they are shared between everyone on the server. You run into never being able to collect higher tier resources because they are camped by people farming them almost 24/7.

My other huge complaint about New World is the inventory and storage system. The storage is based off of town and weight of items. Most cities you cant even store the resources you need to level up your crafting to max. The town storage is not shared, so you have to either go to each specific town where your specific resources are to craft (which is limited because you have to spend Azoth salt to teleport) OR you can pull out the crafting materials from storage into your inventory which don't fit because you cant carry that much weight. It is very inconvenient to have to pull 1-2 resources run to the crafting station craft a thing or 2 then go back to the storage for more resources. This game is HEAVY on crafting and if that is the case at least implement a storage and inventory system that can support your games main mechanic.

Furthermore the PVP in this game is not very good. It consists of alot of people running around drinking potions or all together just running away from you. 99% of players don't even flag for PVP and most players try to play only PVE. New World should force players to flag for pvp 100% of the time unless they are in cities or at teleport shrines.

Why would you have a mostly pvp based game and give players the option to never partake in the action.....

The dungeon system is quite boring. There are very few dungeons and the way you get better gear is doing the same exact boring dungeon on a hard difficulty which M1 and M2 aren't even a big challenge. M3 is quite easy also.
Most items you get are BOP so you just salvage a ton of gear and you can only salvage so much before you max out salvage parts to 2000 then you are forced to go craft repair kits and repair kits are useless in the game because you can repair at any time in your inventory (not using repair kits)

Gathering the artifact gear is very simple but just a waste of time really. You sit at a boss or monster which dies in 2-3 hits and kill it 5-10 times and you have an artifact. OR you can just pay real money for the season pass and get a full set of artifact gear from paying real money.

The transmog system is absolutely TRASH. EVERYTIME you want to add an item to your transmog set you have to pay REAL LIFE MONEY. You only get 1 transmog token for free while leveling to max level.

There are 3 pvp factions in New world that fight for control over zones and its sad because at any point in time you can change factions. This creates a huge imbalance and 1 factions controls the entire map with no hope of anything.  With the majority of players not participating in PVP it makes the game seem worthless.

Another scam from Amazon Studios. To get end content you need to later buy a DLC. Huge amount of grind (which was fine, till some moment). End game is actually still not there yet (it's really boring). Hard to get into fun mass pvp fights. 
Not worth your time.

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

Important note: This review IS NOT being sponsored by anyone. No one urged me or paid me to write this. This review reflects my views and not the views of others, Amazon Games Studio, their employees, blah blah disclaimer here. I am stating this because of certain nasty elements who like to call people that disagree with them "AGS brown-nosers" (this will come up later, I assure you).

There are a LOT of misconceptions by a LOT of people about this game, made worse by people who only want something to trash-talk about (like those people that call others AGS brown-nosers. See? Told you it would come up later). So read up, people. I am going to tell you how it really is. I know, I know. Many say that and then proceed with a lot of whining, crying, and excuses. Ignore that garbage and read closely. I am going to tell it to you straight, whether you want to read it or not (though I imagine if you did not want to read it, you would not still be reading this...)

[b]How Well Does Amazon Games Studio Listen?[/b]
Pretty freaking spectacularly, actually. I mean, they are not going to take every suggestion you throw at them, of course. No company would. Also, sometimes bugs take time to fix, and people need to realize that. But when we told AGS, "HEY! You got botters and gold sellers!" They listened. Hard-core, too. These days you are hard-pressed to find these jerks in-game. If you do, make certain to report them, please. There is even a special category on the report screen for these low-life assholes. Also, please stop giving credence to people that rant about "AGS brown-nosers" and that garbage (they make claims such as that AGS hires people to go in-game and talk about how great it is, etc.) I assure you, "AGS brown-noser" is nothing more than a made-up phrase by people trying to humiliate and degrade others that disagree with them.

[b]What About Mounts?[/b]
Do they have mounts? Yes, but only if you purchase the Rise of the Angry Earth DLC. For those of you that do not have the DLC, Auto-Run is still your best friend. Even having mounts, Auto-Run is your best friend. The good news is that you do not see 99.9% of the population using their mounts to out-run others to nodes and fights in low level areas. Surprisingly, even those with mounts are running on foot to these things, to make it fair to those without the mounts. Kudos to the community for this! You also do not see people running amok in the cities with mounts, blocking NPCs and other things. Part of this is no doubt due to the inability to use the Dash (speed boost) in cities. Another part of this is that you cannot stand in the same space as another person while on a mount; one of you has to move. The rest? Call it being polite? Whatever it is, it is nice to see.

[b]Is Player Housing Available?[/b]
Yes. Yes it is. So the up-side is that you can use your house in this game to add to your storage capacity and as a free teleport to the city it is in pretty frequently. You can even decorate them and craft furniture in-game for the house, or purchase furnishing packs from the in-game Store with Marks of Fortune. The down side to this is that you have to pay in-game taxes each week to the Company that runs the city. If the company is charging high taxes, you might be screwed. You can opt to not pay the taxes for a week if you wish. Not paying them simply means that you do not have access to that house nor its upgrades for the week. The choice is yours.

[b]Are You Lagging, Stuttering, Rubber-Banding, etc.?[/b]
If you are lagging, stuttering, rubber-banding in this game... This is a YOU problem by this point, not a GAME problem. Do I experience any of this whatsoever? Nope! Do I have a top-of-the-line computer? Nah. Close, but not fully. Anyway, any issues that New World had on their servers with such things have been long since fixed, I assure you. Anyone that is still having these problems either has an issue with their computer not being good enough to run it, OR their internet connection is having issues, OR their ISP sucks, OR they need to alter their settings. No, really. I am not joking. So THUMBS UP to AGS for fixing the issues they did have (which, honestly, were not that many in this field).

[b]Systems: How Well or Badly They Work[/b]
AGS is constantly making improvements and changes to their systems based on feedback by the community (and probably other things like research, but who knows? Only them...). With the majority of the big initial bug issues now resolved, they are focusing a lot more on these things, and it is showing in both their patch notes and in how things are working in-game. My personal experience is that for a long while the leveling was tedious, the crafting was tedious... and, honestly, as a result I did not play New World as much (that, and I have too many games to play!) That experience is quickly changing as these systems are now being tweaked to better play to a fun experience in-game. The XP events are freaking awesome, though, and I do hope they continue in the future, as they help those lower than level 60 to catch up on a lot. I do plan to try to find more time to play New World if I can tear myself away from Guild Wars 2, Lost Ark, and Elder Scrolls Online.......

[b]PvP vs PvE:[/b]
Great news!!! You are never required to PvP. Ever. At all. BEST NEWS EVER, right? At least, coming from a PvE-only player, I find that fantastic news. Now, there are some perks to enabling PvP, such as you get to level some trade skills and such faster while it is on (watch out for those other PvPers though. They will not hesitate to interrupt you from chopping that tree to murder you). Second... It used to be that PvE players would suffer greatly from the actions of PvPers due to the fact that the Azoth cost to travel depended on whether or not your faction owned certain territories. Thankfully, no more suffering is required. This is another example of AGS listening to those who write thoughtful and meaningful forum posts (you know, not the ones that just whine and scream at the game or AGS employees?) explaining why it was not working out, and fixed it! One last thing. You cannot PvP in cities. Not going to happen. The game does not allow it.

For now, stop listening to the people that hate on things because it is the cool thing to do and just try it for yourself if you really want to. That decision should be yours only, based on your desire to see what it is like or not.

Do I like New World? Sure! Is it my favorite? No. I like it enough to keep playing, though, and as it grows older it continues to improve (in my opinion, of course). I want to see where this one goes. Climb on board or do not. The choice is YOURS alone.

This game truly brings something brilliant and unique to the table when it comes to MMOs. I am really happy to see the work AGS has been doing on this game since its messy launch and slumps; I initially gave up on this game out of frustration but it is honestly coming alive again.

[h3] Bugs are fixed en masse. [/h3] One of my biggest gripes with NW was how insanely unpolished and messy it was. Main story progress was softlocked for so many players, quests did not function properly, performance declined across all PC specs...I could go on. AGS has done a great job of addressing these bugs and smoothing out HUNDREDS of bugs in one patch. 

 [h3] Combat in PVP and PVE alike is fluid, simple, and satisfying, yet challenging all the while. [/h3] Do you want to be a standard Sword/Shield player? A Lifestaff Healer? Too plain? How about a Blunderbuss and an Ice Gauntlet? Oh you changed your mind? Nice and easy switch. You can choose to build your own unique playstyle, perks, weapons, gear, etc, however you want; there is no set rules for 'classes'. Spend time learning intricate combos you can perform for insane damage/debuffs/cc. 

[h3] DO WHATEVER U WANT! [/h3] Do you just wanna chill and farm/harvest/explore the beautifully crafted Aeternum, undisturbed by other players, after a hard day at work? Are you bloodthirsty and seeking PVP in Arenas or Outpost Rush or Wars? Maybe making 500 pieces of jewelry to sell to other players is your thing. Or you could farm whatever event is going on. You are genuinely free to experience this game in any way you like, and I have yet to run out of things to do or progress in. 

[h3] WHAT ABOUT THE DLC? [/h3] I'm somewhat disappointed that mounts, a zone, and flail are behind a paywall. I much rather would have expansions be part of the base game, especially since AGS has normally done a good job of sticking to Buy Once, then Free to Play, since the beginning of NW's life cycle. However, if you do end up loving this game, I think it is well worth it. If you cannot justify the price, that's ok! Mounts have not made a marginal difference in my travelling since Azoth (material used for fast travelling) is plentiful and easy to get  without focusing it, plus fast travel spots are littered throughout the land. The Flail is a niche utility weapon that only specific builds will use, and most players will find themselves getting more value out of literally any other base game weapon. Elysian Wilds (the zone that comes with the dlc) on the other hand, is quite nice to have access to. 

Overall, I think New World once again has a good future ahead of it as one of the greatest MMOs of the decade. Is it flawless, or even close to it? Not at all. But to see a game being taken care of well like this is rare, and I plan on sticking with this game for a long time. I encourage you to explore each and every aspect of this game.

Title: "A New World, But Not Quite the Promised Land"

Rating: ★★☆☆☆

I embarked on my journey in "New World" with high hopes, ready to carve out my legacy in its sprawling wilderness. Unfortunately, what I discovered was less of a brave new world and more of a beautiful facade with hollow promises.

Let's talk aesthetics first. Visually, "New World" is a feast for the eyes—the lush environments, the attention to detail in the lighting, and the texture work are top-notch. However, even the most beautiful scenery can't mask the emptiness of the world. Compared to the richness of environments in games like "The Witcher 3," where every nook and cranny tells a story, "New World" feels like a gorgeous stage set waiting for a play that never starts.

The gameplay mechanics showed promise but quickly became monotonous. The combat lacks the refinement and satisfaction you get from titles like "Dark Souls," where every encounter is a dance with death. Here, battles often feel like a clumsy brawl rather than a skillful showdown. Moreover, the quests are as generic as they come—a far cry from the narrative depth and variety seen in "Final Fantasy XIV."

As for the MMO elements, "New World" seems to stumble over its own ambitions. The promise of player-driven economies and territory wars sounded groundbreaking, but in practice, it's plagued by imbalance and exploits, leaving it leagues behind the community engagement found in classics like "World of Warcraft."

In conclusion, while "New World" shines in graphical splendor, it fails to deliver on gameplay innovation and MMO dynamics. It's like being served a gourmet meal with no flavor—it looks good on the plate, but leaves you unsatisfied. Perhaps with time, it could evolve into the game it aspires to be, but for now, it feels like an unfinished symphony.

Alright, so I will be honest here. I've deleted my review on this game a few times because I wrote them when I was tired or just annoyed. 

However, below you will read my honest opinion of this game, Amazon, and the Developer team.

[u][H1]The game:[/H1][/u] 
Firstly, let me just say this. The game of New World itself is in one of the best states that it has ever been. The game is thoroughly enjoyable and quite honestly, it's easy to get lost in all of its systems. Me, being someone with ADHD really struggles (but enjoys) the activities of this game. I find myself getting distracted with profession, uncharted landmarks, and  exploring non-stop while trying to finish my Main Story Quest(MSQ). Recently, I've been cutting down all the tree's where the MSQ takes me, otherwise, I'd never make it very far from settlements. This is my new strategy to stay focused, but also distracted at the same time. :D

The world is absolutely beautiful and some places are breath taking. The amount of time the art team put into this game is astonishing. With that being said, this game has quite a few performance issues. I don't have the weakest system (Game is installed on an internal SSD, 64gb of ram, intel core i7-7700k 4.20GHz, and a nvidia RTX 2080 Super 8gb) and I very much so experience FPS drops quite randomly and frequently. Changing the settings to the lowest of low, doesn't fix anything for me. However, I can look past this seeing how it doesn't ruin the experience for me as I mostly do PvE in these style of games.

I also enjoy the fact that we are pretty much just adventurers in this game. We aren't gods, or world saviors and I hope that it stays this way. The MSQ is nothing special either. So far it hasn't caught my attention, but I am hoping this changes as time goes on.

[u][h1]Now let's talk about Amazon[/h1][/u]
When Amazon first announced that they were going to create a studio that focused on creating the next big MMO with an AAA budget I was extremely excited. (As were many others) I thought, "Sweet, a company that can afford to not be greedy when it comes today's style gaming market with in-game cash grabs. They'll be able to revolutionize the gaming industry back to the good ol' days." Boy, was I ever wrong. Amazon, is actually one of the worst offenders in this field. 

Here is why: 
Players have asked for mounts since the launch of New World. This was the #1 most requested thing. Well, the finally delivered, but locked them behind a $30 paywall. The #1 missing thing that drove players AWAY from this game and they lock it behind a paywall? Talk about being disconnected with your own community. I get it, they have to make money. But, that's why they have an in-game store. 

Speaking of the in-game store, this is one of the only games that I have played where you pay money up-front for the game, and so many features are locked behind the in-game store, that is considered a base-game thing is so many other AAA MMO's. Want to transmog? You have to pay. 

With that being said, they could go about this whole in-game store thing completely different. I feel like ESO does everything right. You B2P the game and expansion, and you can choose to pay a sub that gives you minor perks and monthly in- game store currency. The big part being, THE MONTHLY IN-GAME STORE CURRENCY.

In all honesty, Amazon should sell their gaming studios to a company that can afford not having so many pathetic cash grabs. Amazon is their own worst enemy in this aspect.

[u][h1]Now let's speak about the Developer team[/h1][/u]
I honestly feel bad for this development team. I don't feel like many of the choices are up to them when it comes to the cash grabs. I feel like they're told what to do in this aspect and they just deliver what Amazon wants. The dev team is honestly trying their best, and they've seriously created quite an amazing game with the cards they're dealt. 

So that is my review.

Played this game at release and enjoyed playing through the main quests mostly PvE untill reaching lvl cap 60. From there I changes focus to expertise-grinding and PvP stuff, which was okay, but mainly a means to an end, getting them juicy drops. Stopped playing in the end after Amazon kept failing to fix any of the several game breaking issues, the main ones being ruined balance due to gold dupes, and the game becoming pretty much unplayable from performance issues during big PvP fights. I returned now in hopes that they fixed the biggest issues, only to be greeted with constant frame drops, even at lowest setting and 30fps cap. A quick look on reddit and I see I am far from alone. At launch I played on high without any performance issues while PvE, and now after 2 years it is somehow worse. Such great potential, really sad they couldn't make more of it. And them releasing a DLC rather than fixing the game for the people buying a 50$ game that was pretty much still in Beta is also something.

Hello Steam users!

First of all I would like to clarify I'm not a fanatic MMO player, I rarely play MMOs and my experience on this genre is limited. New World has offered me a very pleasurable gaming experience in my journey so far. I'm a PvE player and I enjoy doing such activities as expeditions, events, farming loot, mining, fishing, etc. For a casual player like me this game feels a lot relaxing and fun. There are some bugs here and there but I have not encountered any game breaking. If you're looking for a casual chill game, this is a very nice choice.

As for the Rise of the Angry Earth expansion released, well... People seems to forget what an expasion of a game is. It expands the game content! That means if you want to progress further than the base game, get items with more gear score, get mounts, compete with other players that have the expansion as well, get MORE content and overall keep up with the development you need to buy it. It's not like Amazon made an inovation in 2023 by adding an expansion to their game. Games have expansions for at least 10 to 15 years already. If you don't wish to buy it (yet) you can still enjoy all the content prior to Rise of Angry Earth but you will play among other users that may have it.

That's all, have fun.

ORIGINAL REVIEW HAS BEEN MOVED DOWN
So here we are again. I came back to New World recently to see what has changed.
What can I say? AGS did a complete 180 with this game.
So many updates, so many new things, things were reworked, things were fixed, and now it's just better than ever.

It just works.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When I played this game at launch, it was a bloody blast. Everything was fresh and brand new, people everywhere, a new world (pun intended) to explore. And I'm not gonna lie, the 40 something levels I played back then were pretty damn fun, even tho the game practically turned my then laptop into an electrical stove, so I had to get a desktop PC.

However, by the time I got it, the server I was on felt like a bloody ghost town, and most of my company was already just half gone to god knows where. And from there, things only started to get worse. That magical feeling of a brand new game was lost, everyone was abusing the living shit out of every possible exploit, finding groups for expeditions was near impossible since everything felt deserted, and the Lag Wars... Good God the bloody Lag Wars. People jumping around the entire map, tons and tons of AoE spells on a single spot, being unable to capture points in wars thanks to said lag... It was a right mess..

So I was gone for 7 months, and I come back right in time for the nearest update, and what do I find?

The same fucking game I left 7 months ago, only somehow much worse for wear and practically on life support.
Going "strong" with ~20k players at peak times. Sure, the servers still get populated up to near capacity of 2k players. Those that remain, that is... Can you imagine that the game had so many servers at launch? 1 Million people, all queuing up to play this one game, and damn near every server being full to the brim with people.

Now it has been reduced to a measly 35 servers out of which ~25 have a population of at least 100 players, and out of those 35 servers, only 13 currently have a population of over 500 players. Only 4 out of those 35 servers have a population of at least 1000. Currently, at time of writing, only 2 servers are near capacity, being: Barri and Dry Tree.

Can you imagine? The game is not even a year old, and from 1 million players, it's down to 20k. This is a massive fall.

Some games have absolutely god awful launches, and recover over time.
Some games start strong, but lose players over the course of a couple of years.
Some games don't even launch at all, for whatever reason.

But New World has managed to lose damn near it's entire playerbase within the span of like 7 months-ish.

Not much has changed since I left it 7 months ago.

This apple looks so bright and juicy, but on the inside, it's rotten to the core.
I say, this game censors criticism even! I cannot even say "This game was made by a dev team with no mmo experience", the message simply never gets sent! You cannot even say the dev team has no prior MMO development experience because it just gets filtered! Can you believe it?

Game experiences lag spikes, quests still lack any character, characters lack any soul, mobs are the same all across the game.. Open world is still, in a sense, a running simulator cuz there's not much else to do other than run at a painfully slow speed..

It sucks, you know? I really wanted this game to succeed. Still do. It's got some nice visuals, and the combat's quite simplistic and cool. But overall it's getting killed by being a grindfest with no endgame, repetitive and unimaginative in it's world building. Not every game needs to bring something new and innovative. You don't have to reinvent the wheel to make a good mmo. Simply improving on already existing features can feel quite fun and refreshing. But New World doesn't do that. If anything, it does the same thing other mmos do, but worse somehow.

Game was really made in a vacuum, crafted by a team that didn't even know what an MMO is like it's some brand new concept that only recently got invented.

I expect the game to shutdown sometime after their Autumn update, if not sooner.

Prove me wrong. Please.

EDIT: To clarify, I say "prove me wrong" as in please just prove me wrong. This is one of those times where being wrong is just objectively better than being right. This is me pleading you to prove me wrong. Dear God, please just prove me wrong.

EDIT 2: I'll probably continue playing and follow the game's development, and hopefully it'll someday be good enough to deserve a recommendation. A man can dream lol.

Introduction:
New World, the highly anticipated MMORPG developed by Amazon Game Studios, arrived with great expectations. However, after spending significant time exploring its vast world and engaging in its gameplay, I find myself deeply disappointed with the overall experience. While the game showcases some promising ideas, it falls short in several crucial areas, hindering its potential to be a standout title in the genre.

Lackluster Gameplay:
One of the most significant shortcomings of New World lies in its gameplay mechanics. The combat system, touted as one of the game's main selling points, feels clunky and unresponsive. It lacks the fluidity and precision that players expect from modern MMOs. The limited variety of abilities and lack of depth in character progression further contribute to the monotonous grind that plagues the game.

Uninspiring Quest Design:
Questing in New World quickly becomes a tedious and repetitive endeavor. The quests often lack creativity and fail to provide meaningful or engaging objectives. Players are left with a series of fetch quests and generic kill missions, which do little to immerse them in the game world or offer a sense of purpose. The lack of compelling storytelling and memorable NPCs further detracts from the overall experience.

Unbalanced PvP and Endgame Content:
New World heavily promotes its PvP-focused gameplay and large-scale battles, but the implementation leaves much to be desired. The PvP system is imbalanced, favoring high-level players and groups, which leads to frustrating and unfair encounters for newcomers. Additionally, the endgame content feels lacking and fails to offer compelling activities to keep players engaged once they reach the level cap. The lack of meaningful rewards and progression beyond the initial stages of the game further diminishes the motivation to continue playing.

Technical Issues and Optimization:
New World's launch was marred by numerous technical issues and performance problems. From long server queues and frequent crashes to optimization struggles, the game fails to provide a stable and smooth experience. These issues significantly hamper the enjoyment of the game, causing frustration and a sense of wasted potential.

Conclusion:
While New World had the potential to be a groundbreaking MMORPG, it ultimately falls short of expectations. The lackluster gameplay, repetitive quest design, imbalanced PvP, and underwhelming endgame content hinder the overall experience. The technical issues and optimization problems further compound these shortcomings, making it difficult to fully immerse oneself in the game world. It's a disappointing outcome for a title that promised so much. Unless significant improvements are made, New World fails to deliver on the potential it once held.

The game is kind of all over the place. I am a new player (3 weeks in). To me (YMMV) I am playing an impossible game of catchup on skills and PvP gear (which is the endgame of New World). Sure I can get ilvl 700 gear, but its not going to have the perks needed. Each skill needs ridiculous amounts of gold to get caught up, each piece of gear also detracts... want a decent house for your trophies (which add in-game bonuses), still further behind on gold. Want to experiment with different weapons, well those respec costs and regear costs will eat you up too. PvP should be doing more material farming trees, wolves and ore, but thats all a new player can do in OPR or in the open world. Healing in this game is f***ing hot garbage, especially going UP stairs. Can't break down items (which is a method to getting gold) due to stupid a** material scrap limitations, which cannot be discarded. It just needs developers playing the game to see the glaring issues and then to actually do something about it.

PvP, usually a highlight for me, falls short in this game.

I'd suggest not purchasing this game without testing it during a free trial, especially if you're not keen on repetitive chest runs and waiting on world bosses, only to abandon the grind once you've achieved a singular goal.

Game has so much potential but falls short in so many aspects

1. PVP -  PvP is so unbalanced it's not even fun.  You either steamroll or get steamrolled in OPR.  Very rarely is it a competitive game.  3v3 Arena is a little better.  The reward track for doing PVP just contains so much junk, you rarely get a good item.  You also feel like you need to do PvP because the reward track MIGHT contain a crafting perk called Adamant which is a highly sought after item and is only obtained by doing PvP or from Armoring Aptitude crates.  

2. Storage - Storage is still a major qualify of life disappointment.  It is a major pain to try and manage it and you can forget about organizing.  It needs to be one full storage system with the combined weight.  AND you should be able to craft from storage instead of RP walking to crafting stations because you are encumbered

3. Ultimate Trophy's - The made a nice step forward with the Ultimate Trophy HOWEVER they cost 45,000 gold and 900,000 faction tokens each.  And in reality you need to have 9 of the ultimate trophy's.  I don't mind a grind on the tokens but 45,000 gold x 9 = 405,000 gold and in all of my hours playing I have maybe hit that gold threshold.  

4. Gathering and Crafting system is like none I have ever encountered in an MMO.  It is almost perfect IMO.  I love getting the different armor sets for each gathering profession or crafting profession.  The only downside to gathering is that I wish there was a node sharing component to the game.  Sometimes you will come across people that will try to aggro mobs on you while you are mining, or skinning or people will outright steal some of the skinning you are doing from killing beasts.  For crafting I don't like the fact that to craft a BiS you need to have so many different "buffs", I will say, for the lack of a better term.  You need the crafting armor set, you need to have a food buff, you need to have a town buff (which isnt controlled by you the player) ... it's just a little too much

5. Combat - The combat is alright.  I enjoy the classless aspect to the game.  You can choose any weapon you want and that almost takes on the class itself.  I just wish there was more to it, better Vfx or a few more abilities.  It seems monotonous at times and lackluster.
I really enjoyed this game so far. Miles better than launch. I wish expeditions were more popular esp leveling up but the combat is pretty fun.

I recently got back into the game after the newest expansion after a long hiatus. The devs have clearly been hard at work making the game better. My initial review was negative, but hopeful. My current review is less negative, but also less hopeful.

Let's talk about the good, because there is a lot. 

The world itself is beautiful. It's large & expansive, and littered with plenty of points of interest. It was clearly crafted carefully and I'm always impressed with how real it feels. The open world is fantastic.

Combat is fascinating. The game utilizes a two-weapon system that allows you to swap between each somewhat seamlessly in battle. This allows for plenty of unique builds and play styles. 

They've removed the disgusting azoth price on transferring items to and from town storage and a lot of the annoying gear/expedition key systems from the base game with the new expansion. Slowly but surely they're making a lot of these elements from the game more appealing. 

Now onto the bad: 

It's Amazon. Can we all just agree that Amazon is evil as hell? Don't believe me? Here are some of the more egregious elements from the publisher:

Elements that *should* be in the base game that are paywalled:
Transmog
Gear Sets
Mounts

Cash shops are an unfortunate reality and for a purchase to own game like this I understand the necessity for it. But they've taken a page out of the Everquest playbook and added seasonal emotes. Not too bad, right? Except these emotes you pay REAL MONEY for are only available for 24 hours. Now you RENT emotes. I've never been more disgusted by a cash grab in all honesty. 

OH and these emotes are non-refundable. As is the expansion.

The economy is in a pretty rough state as well. It's a completely player-driven economy with no options to sell items to NPCs. Some of the items you want for crafting/upgrading gear are time-gated and purchasable through vendors, but are insanely expensive. New/Returning players simply cannot earn enough gold to keep up. 

It seems like for every 2 things they fix they break 5 things. It's really sad because like I said there's a ton of great elements to this game.
its a a small indie company game don't buy it will suck your soul using bugs

I'm going to say it up front, I haven't hit max level yet and there is a lot I have not done. This game is MUCH BETTER than it was at launch from pve content to pvp, the economy, azoth collection, traveling and mounts. I've just come back to it recently and I'm willing to see it through for quite a while longer. If you are one of the people who heard bad things about it from launch, just forget it. It's still not fantastic, but not for THOSE reasons anymore. I do think the average MMO player who hasn't yet played it would actually like it today.

My favorite thing to do is equip a musket and shoot turkeys. I'm not a sweaty min maxer in any game. I just wanna have fun. Am I having fun here? I guess. 

My feeling on this game is that AGS said "Look, we put all the things in an MMO that are supposed to be in an MMO: Progression, crafting, gathering, housing, auction house, gear scores, meta builds, seasonal content, fishing, dyes, mounts, group content, pvp, pve, story based quests. Now please love me."

If you expect to find it in an MMO, It's here. So. There's that. No denying it. If you want a game that gives you a lot of opportunities for progression and min maxing, this game can do that. If you want to just chill and do some mindless pve or gathering, you can do soooo much of that. Wanna decorate your house or play music? do it. 

The thing is, that despite it all being there, the only time I feel connected to the world is when I'm just kinda riding through it. It's gorgeous. It's immersive in small moments. The sounds and visuals are top notch. I literally don't even have a sense of smell at all, and I feel like I can smell the zones and some of the stinkier looking NPCs. 

The story makes no sense to me overall and it does not hook me, and I really can't stand the "every player is the chosen one" lazy writing for an MMO, but it's nothing unusual for the genre. There is some more solo-cooperative stuff with Town Boards where you just dump materials and quest objects into a literal bulletin board, not even an NPC. I find it disenchanting and lazy, but hey its like an XP dispenser that helps build up the town so...why not. It works. I'm not in love with it.

The game feels like it always actually just wants money. I have never bought anything from the shop but the feeling this game is not rewarding me for my time and REALLY just wants my money is very strong. Idk why I'm playing it. Its not the worst thing I can do with my time I guess. 

Gathering is top tier. You won't find a better dopamine hit imo. They nailed every aspect of that. Make number go higher. Yes. 

I'd think there'd be more RP going on, given how nice the taverns and environs are in the game. None to be found at all. Wish there was more of that to be seen around.

Bugs are introduced every patch and maybe or maybe not fixed promptly. Whatever. Content updates are regular and only the sweats are getting bored. 

If you have a nice pc, it runs great.

PvP is fun. The Influence races really help with the open world action.

7.5/10 for now. Let me see if I can see it through to max level and end game content.

The game is probably great again, though.

When this game originally came out, I had honestly zero interest in it. It looked good but it just seemed like it was all looks. With the GPU issues happening at launch with EVGA cards (I have a 3080 EVGA) I stayed far away. But i enjoyed watching people stream it. Fast forward to nearly 2 months ago,this game went on sale for $15 and i decided.....why not give it a try? 

I jumped in and I was actually impressed and had a pretty fun time playing the game. I managed to play up until about level 30. There is a fun and relaxing feeling when gathering and running around in the world. Its a very appealing setting(most of the time). Unfortunately I was hoping to get some close friends involved in the game and can have a memorable group experience. Sadly nobody was interested in joining the game.

The community from what i saw reminded me of shades of WoW's good old Trade chat. Someone is upset about something and someone else argues with that that person that is upset. It seemed constantly there was a back and forth happening in the global chat.
I currently am off and on FFXIV WoL and a former WoW player for 15-16 years and am considering going back. I hardly have time for one MMO. With New World I think there is value with playing this game and it seems to be in a much better place than launch or the first year. So I would strongly recommend this MMO for anyone who craves a newer and more modern(visually) MMO experience . For me personally don't think I will commit much further into the game.

The good tactics made the rush of the game feel great. Those moment kept me playing it all the way to my 600th hour.

Most of my grievences with New World is because of the devs... 
They started this development as a pure survival game, then added a storymode and optional pvp flag.
You can clearly tell, this game would excel, if only they stuck to the core development.
Ever since release, the game has struggled with mechanics ad-hoced into the game, although most of these has since been resolved.

As the game was released and patched/expanded devs allowed bugs and poor balance creep into the live release, increasingly giving the hardcore players more and more advantage over the casual player.
This has continued to this day with the release of the first expansion. Massive advantages was rewarded to the hard core players, only to be removed before most casual players could partake.

Finall, the game lacks any incentive to socialize beyond companies, there is no single raid as it is known to most players, and the limited development being done to the game, shows most of AGS has moved on to future releases like LOTR.

I see no future for this game beyond 2024, but would love to be proven wrong

I have played this game a lot, and each time I get close to the end of the game and notice how the endgame content works, I am discouraged and pushed out of playing the game. I want to love it, and I do to some extent, but the game is developed in a way there the DEVs try their hardest to prevent you from having fun. I normally don't do reviews but my experience in the last two-three weeks has really pushed me to do this.

I have been grinding for the Scorpion Sting spear artifact, as it seems really strong and fun in 3v3 arenas. So I go grinding for it. I don't have the rune for the door, the game doesn't teach me where to find it, and google won't give me answers, so I just jump into the hole at the top. Eventually the server restarts and I lose my Inn and have no home. So I am stranded in this hole, with no teleporting out. I log in and wait. I get bored after 10 or so minutes and get kicked for being AFK for trying to escape this hole. Log back in, and nobody is there to let me out. Eventually I get to escape, set my inn, and continue grinding for the spear. Never got it, but that's its own monumental problem.

I get tired of grinding for this spear for a week with nothing else to show for it, so leave the hole today and try to grind my PvP track which moves at a snails pace and locks named items that are required for good builds behind it. However I only queue up with no healer into a healer comp and get steamrolled every time with nothing we could do about it. Mad at that, I decided to go to The Great Cleave and engage in the most boring gameplay known to man because AGS doesn't want their players to be able to level their character in a fun way. Now, me being a bruiser with tank gear in medium armor, running these PVP missions gets camped by some Bow/VG build with light armor. This constantly slows me, hits me with dots, and heals him to full everytime. Me winning this fights don't rely on my playing well, but him making stupid mistakes. Otherwise I cannot win. Right before I rage quit the game, I wanted to post some recruitment posts for my Company in the recruitment chat... All my messages all day work, but posting a recruitment message for my company would not post. Every attempt of me having fun or progressing my character has been stonewalled.

Overall, for the past week, I have been engaging in New World to try to have fun, but am being cornered into not having fun or being able to make meaningful progression in any which way. This has enraged me more than anything else has in terms of gaming. I hope AGS can figure out that the important part of the game isn't restricting the gameplay from the players, but allowing them to have fun in the first place. Recently it feels like their goal is simply placing a framework for fun, and then spending all of their time putting needless barriers around the important parts.
If you enjoy grinding for months maybe years of mind numbing content and then pay for an expansion that makes all your gear and work meaningless , Then this is the game for you.

Closing in on 1k hours, I feel like I need to update my review to provide a more accurate detailing on how this game actually plays. 

New World is a fantastic MMO for a casual audience to pick up and play. Over the years, it has grown into a massive, content rich game with a variety of things to do. PvE is fun, engaging at the higher levels, and pretty rewarding. PvP is good, but has it's ups and downs from time to time (currently in a down). 
If you like crafting, this game does it a great justice. With refining and crafting life skills to level up and spec into, putting commitment into a profession can have a pretty large payoff.
Combat is very fluid and feels great! No lock on means combat never feels like it's too mmo-ish, and allows for a good cinematic and engaging feeling combat system, letting you mix in good movement and decision making on the fly.

The game is really repetitive, monsters and sprites are resued over and over again just the level changes, the documentation of the game is poor and guides are often outdated, asking a question in the game is pointless. Only way to get some help is if you already know something but if you ignore the group dunegons, the game can be enjoyed solo. 

If your going to play, be sure to play on the most popular servers, even if it doesn't let you make a character just wait, i was forced to a smaller server and its so shady, as people with money buy out a lot of the most comment items and resell for anywhere from 10-200x the price from the market shop as there is no cap or regulation on prices, which i respect black desert online for doing, its alright to make money but its down right shady to exploit it to make it harder on others when there is no need.

Plus side, there is a wide range of weapons to use which you can respec and go full beast mode on those weapons which is good, however there is only 6 skills to choose from so it also gets repeative, but its best to try finding what weapons you like and still have fun with it. For me i wanted to be greatsword like gutts from berserk, but its style was boring damage wise, its good for taunting and fighting outnumbered but the skills dont have the power or awe factor. But magic was fun and i really enjoyed the spear and bow.

You will have really fast progression, levelling is super quick, but make sure you focus on the story mode as that will save you a lot of effort to get gear, join one of the three factions asap for faction low level gear, its best from 15-35 but once you hit 45, dont get the gear just buy from market place, but still do quests for making inventory bags that they call satchels. 

I was disappointed with mounts, they slow off roads which makes no sense, id expect them to be fast in the forests and off road especially with a lion and wolf. Be good if there was mounted battle or can fight on your mount for a new dynamic, but its just a road of transport, best mount system hands down goes to guild wars 2. Mounts serve purposes and are just fun.

I never read the story, i skipped all the dialog so i cant comment on it, but it wasn't really interesting, midway i got interested in the ancients immortals but even that was easily seen through and can be summed up in a line. 

So the game can be fun, but its repetitive, like bat **** crazy repetitive and reused, in dunegons your likely to be with people end game levels that wont explain and you just gotta follow along but its great looting with little work. Its a once of purchased but there is a cash shop for skins and appearances, once of the things that upset me with it is some stuff is too overpriced like bundles with have 16 skins in it, 4 will be beautiful done rest dont like, but you gotta spend 64,000 cash shop coins to buy only the items you want. Not only that, there where a lot of cool looking monsters towards max level like the angry earth mobs, and even some of the human bandits that look so much better then anything you can get to wear. So players tend to look weird but enemies have better armors and appearances.

First off you gotta buy this game, then you get your way to level 25 just to be met with a $30 paywall to get access to mounts (and yes dlc too, d***riders) but mounts are a basic mechanic of every mmo and this one is stuck behind a paywall. Not only that but you can get your glorious monthly subscription battlepass!!! Another thing is if you live in central us youre just screwed (minimum 100 ping). My experiences with eso, gw2, albion, wow classic, and runescape have been way better.

2023 Edit:
Lol. Haven't played since last review, but just had to add a laugh. What a dumpster fire this whole thing turned out to be, eh?

2022 Edit: 
My friend convinced me to try again with the Fresh Start servers. There have been constant and consistent updates since I'd played it last, and it seemed like maybe there would be something different.

I have to admit to myself and others that the beginning of the game, the leveling up of gathering skills, is fun. I enjoy harvesting, organizing, and storing materials. I enjoy the sound design most especially. Those things alone are, in some way, worth the initial cost of the game.

But when we got to the end game (even sooner than the first time despite less effort), I found it to be largely the same. There's daily tasks and improvements with the Gypsum system which is interesting, and much better than the invisible watermarking of days past. But while there are things to do, there's very little that I want to do. The same frustrations I had in the beginning are just features of the game. Being stunlocked by enemy hits while never being able to affect the same type of stagger on them. So many little things that I just don't really like. There's still amateur-ish graphical errors and glitches. Things that really shouldn't be in a game with this much constant support a full year after release. (Can't access stash, have to fast travel or restart the game to make it work for one example.)

I don't know man. I want to give the game a thumbs up, for the fun I have gathering. Cause I do, and did. I really enjoyed that aspect of the game. But it would be a misdirection because this isn't what the game is for. (Unless you join with the sole purpose of gathering for a company and never doing anything else. But that's a specific decision you'd have to make while playing.)

Is the game worth the price tag? Yeah, it is. I got 421 hours out of it. I fell for a couple of their stupid store offers, but it's still worth the price tag in total. But I just.. after all the time I spent I've uninstalled it again cause it just seems so empty. Like a movie I paid for and laughed at a couple of times, but I'll forget it soon.

Original:
I really enjoyed the game for all the time I spent... but it needs a lot of work still. So much so, that I'm changing my recommendation to No right now.

There are too many small oversights and quite a few game-breaking issues that slipped under the radar, that makes it feel like they really did push this game out too soon. Playing it has felt like a polished beta.

In retrospect, we all should have waited before jumping on the bandwagon here. For all the joy I had with the game, knowing the bitter taste of what awaited us a few months later - I wouldn't have bought this game in the first place.

First time in a while where I've actually felt like an MMO is work my time and commitment. PvE is good, but has room for improvement. Expeditions are pretty fun and there's lots of reason to run the same ones again due to mutations (higher difficulty) and quest objectives.

PvP is very fun. Running OPRs, open world PvP, influence races, wars all feel rewarding. You and your company can work with other companies in the same faction and build allies.

Having a "no class" system is awesome because I don't feel the need to grind 3 separate characters just to have different specs. You technically could have any spec or class on one character. At that point it's more about organizing your gear.

If it goes on sale this holiday, snag it. Sell some CSGO skins for the expansion.

Not good.  I played it a little bit and started getting into it, but it's not really in a playable state.

Here's my main gripes:
1.  It's full of bugs, gamebreaking bugs that will stop you from progressing through the story quest kind, where you need to complete them to unlock key abilities to progress in the game.
2.  It started as a survival game and it shows.  As a solo game it's okay, but PvE is meh and PvP is moreso something you do when you're fully geared at level cap and there's nothing else to do.  Worst implementation of a healer I've ever seen in an MMO hands down.
3.  I don't see much of a future for the game, I'm sure there will be people who try it out after some marketing for each expansion with promises of 'improvements', but the issues it has are systemic and I doubt they'll ever change (unless they rewrite the client/server architecture and redo all combat systems, so it won't happen).

I cannot recommend new world because of the game progression bugs surrounding Azoth Staff tier 3, 4, and 5. I am a returning player and mounts do help traversing the map a lot more. However I cannot reap rewards from activities nor progress a main story quest Accursed Ahpopsis due to not having azoth staff tier 5. I cannot equip heart runes because the quest secrets of the heartgem requires azoth staff tier 5 to complete it. Locked out of abilities everyone gets to have and locked out of story progression. The update that came out today gave me.... azoth staff tier 4. With no way to obtain tier 5. So with 200+ hours in the game this really sucks. Apparently the Azoth staff bugs have been in the game since 2021. finding a solution to this does not seem to be a priority for New World Devs. its sad because I have been enjoying this game for a while now. EDIT to now not recommended as of 11/3/2023:

OK... so now that the devs ripped off the arms and legs and sense of humor, off the base game, such as the 5 level brackets above 60, to a new total of 65... that in so doing is denying you the following: 
the improved player stats, the top gear score of items. 
the only area that has the ingredient drops you'd need to make the better food that not only gives better stat boosts, but for a longer duration.
A new weapon that is so OP that it kills you with a few slaps.
The DLC region? it used to be a place called, "First Light" they just recycled it into this "new" region and then locked it away.
You know all the hype for the mounts? they locked it away as well, but whoop de doo! there is literally a fast travel point not far to travel to, all over the map! You kinda don't need a mount at this point so meh?
Anyhow, all of this is locked out of base game.


All of this restricts you from ever again playing any amount of PVP taken seriously! which is most if not the main reason why you'd suffer through the leveling up from 1 to 65, with the poorly done story missions. and building up so much, to you know. not get mopped by too many people? oh and not to mention the and outpost rush and 3v3 pvp arena as well, now you only get to feasibly do PVE! 

And even then? a bad, watered down PVE because the top levels of dungeons demand top gear score to survive in them for longer than two steps. Oh, and you can forget about being recruited for participation of the invasions, that absolutely have to win the invasion, otherwise the entire town's workshops and armaments get downgraded! Which is an awesome mechanic on paper and practice for an ongoing challenge and leveling the playing field for town ownership, and in the past it really was cool to play in invasions... but now this quickly becomes a problem when you have a significantly smaller pool of battle ready players willing to defend the town!

And the devs? They placed these newly ripped off arms and legs and sense of humor, into a box, wrapped it up and locked it away into a now deemed overly essential DLC ($29.99) that is almost as expensive as the base game (39.99)!

I'd be mad already if it was a $1 or as high as $15 for this shameless, and now made into an overly essential DLC, I might even get the itch to play the game and fork out the $15 to get back to it... but $29.99? when base game is $39.99? 

Oh my God, how does that even register as fair to you devs, or give you any reason to attempt to explain it away? 

I mean c'mon! Take me to dinner first! Make me feel special! Talk to me dirty! SOMETHING! ANYTHING! before you try to shame me twice, and sell me such a dynamic duo, of another bucket of crap! 

The first shaming being the initial base game purchase of, "Bucket of crap"... now downgraded to, "bucket of crap: classic" and the new DLC's, "bucket of crap: extra!"

So yeah! that's my line in the sand, crossed a few miles back I will admit. 

New world devs, I genuinely loved the world you made, I spent a lot of time in your world, and loved it even with the toxic, clannish, and elitist keyboard warrior warts and all, even after it became a shameless corporate greed cash-in, I stuck by it, hoping it wouldn't get any worse. Well you proved it can get worse. 

Look at it like this, maybe they will give you the equivalent of a Razzy award for worst DLC and updates! if so, an early "Congrats!" is in order.

As a dedicated healer who has spent a little over 1500 hours in New World, I'd like to share my perspective on the game, particularly focusing on the healing experience. New World offers a satisfying healing experience, though it could use more attention in terms of balance and end-game content for healers. 

Healing Gameplay (8/10):
New World offers a unique and enjoyable healing experience. The combat system, while not exclusively healer-oriented, adds an exciting dimension to healing. Managing cooldowns, aiming heals, and providing support during intense battles is rewarding. However, I'd love to see more healing-specific abilities and mechanics to further enrich the healing role.

Healer Balance (6/10):
The game has seen its share of balancing issues for healers. Some weapons and abilities have felt overpowered, making it challenging to maintain a balanced PvP experience. Amazon Games has been actively working on these issues, but there's still room for improvement.

PvP Healing (8/10):
Participating in PvP battles as a healer is a thrilling experience. Your role as a support class can be crucial in determining the outcome of fights. Coordinating with your team to keep them alive and secure victories is immensely satisfying. I've had some of the most intense and memorable moments in the heat of battle.

End-Game Healing (7/10):
The end-game content for healers is somewhat limited. While healing is essential in high-level dungeons and expeditions, there could be more end-game activities designed to specifically challenge and engage healers. Expanding on this aspect would be a welcome addition.

Community (9/10):
The New World community has been generally positive and supportive. Players recognize the importance of healers, and I've found camaraderie in my company and faction. The community's welcoming attitude has made my healing journey in Aeternum all the more enjoyable.

Optimization and Bugs (8/10):
The game had its share of issues, including server problems and bugs, which occasionally impacted healing gameplay. While many of these problems have been resolved, ongoing optimization and bug fixes are necessary for a smoother healing experience.

You know how most MMOs and games in general get better optimisation with time? Not The New World! This game became practically unplayable for many returning players after running good for 2 years. New DLC brought along serious issues that cannot be justified by simply being a hardware demanding product.

30 Hours in:

+ Game requires x2 the disc space it actually takes to run properly
+ Launches 1 in 4 tries, mostly becoming unresponsible after logging on (forcing you to delete settings folder to get back on feet)
+ Random desktop crashes during gameplay
+ Terribly optimised - framerate spikes and drops from 80 down to freeze in towns.
+ Borderline unplayable on Low settings in towns (despite being on an SSD drive) while running ultra smooth on High anywhere else. 

Will probably add some more issues soon.

Reviewing an MMO is always something of a fool's errand because games change so much. 

NW encourages a love/hate relationship. If you're a mage or a light player, the game loves you, otherwise fuck you. 

+ Classless progression ("class" abilities are tied to equipment: change gear, change abilities)
+ Beautiful world (lovely graphics, exceptional sound design)
+ Interesting world that isn't a cookie-cutter RPG (no elves, etc.)
+ Significant PVP elements
+ Players meaningfully affect the world
+ Fairly dedicated community (servers get curb-stomped by super-companies that shit all over an otherwise healthy server, then leave). If you think that's hyperbole, play the game for more than a month.

- Gear costs can be prohibitively expensive at endgame. All content is now endgame content
- You'll have to turn your settings down or the lag will be game-breaking (e.g., in war)
- Because is telling a new story, most people don't bother with the narrative
- PVP design encourages worst aspects of online play. System issues will be a recurring frustration (rubberbanding, death by desync, etc.)
- Limited ability to participate in some endgame content:

War is a 50 v 50 fight for control of a territory (with significant rewards), which is a useful balance. But, because the stakes are high companies are very reluctant to give war slots to new people.
Not a perfect game but certainly a fun one! New World is at its best when adventuring with friends and interacting with the community.

Bom, é o seguinte.. Cansei de outros MMO RPGs mais precisamente ESO e tava em busca de outros games pra jogar, claro mantendo o mesmo gênero que é um dos meus preferidos. E acompanhei o lançamento desse game deis de um tempo atrás e percebi que talvez ele poderia não me agradar por algumas razões de gosto pessoal mesmo.. tipo estilo, época, cenário, essas coisas. 
Um tempo se passou e eu decidi comprar pra realmente poder gostar ou não. Fiz a compra e assim não mudou praticamente nada deis do lançamento do game. Eu até gostei de como as coisas funcionam lá, como por exemplo a dificuldade não é tão casual ela pode ser um pouco punitiva se você não tiver pratica nos comandos de ataque e defesa. Os territórios lá são marcados por Lvls então você precisa evoluir pra poder avançar.. até ai tudo pq a dificuldade foi uma das coisas que mais me agradou.
Falando um pouco da comunidade é claro que sempre irão existir pessoas ruins porém eu apenas encontrei pessoas que me ajudaram e até me deram um suporte financeiro no game ^^, itens lendários e tal. Então assim, eu não reclamo da comunidade tal qual o servidor q joguei foi Server BR.. Incrível. 
Eu realmente não gostei do game em outras perpectivas e poderia ter visto mais vídeos e gameplays de como o game se comporta e talvez eu não teria me decepcionado. Esse game tem o seu próprio estilo.. me refiro a: Eles não copiaram.. É bem original com artes da própria humanidade. O que não me agradou foi o fato de não ter montaria pq o mapa é grande só que ele só é grande pq não tem nenhum tipo de meio pra você se locomover de forma rápida. Mais ai você me diz porra Faw tem pontos de viagem rápida no game e o personagem anda meio que correndo. e então eu respondo: É ai que não me agrada pq talvez a ideia deles foi boa do tipo preservar mais horas de jogo pro jogador e fazer com que ele explore mais o cenário.. certo porém o lvl endgame não é tão alto assim e uma hora ficar andando e coletando recurso que inclusive é umas das coisas mais legais de se fazer nesse game pq o mapa é extenso e tem matéria em tudo quanto é lugar.
Mas voltando pra questão da montaria.. Porra, poderia ter iria ser mais divertido e evitaria eu ficar andando pelo mesmo caminho sempre que eu voltasse pro ponto de viagem rápida no caso da morte.
Outra coisa que não me chamou a atenção foi que o game não tem Raça cara.. E isso me chama a atenção pq tipo cada raça tem um tipo de habilidade pra somar com a sua classe e build e tal pra ser uma coisa mais completa. Mas não tem e isso faz com que perca a graça. Só tem humano mano, wtf...

MMO that looks beautiful, feels great, has a nice story but it still doesn't live up to its expectations. This game has been out for a while and it should have way more content than it does now. If New World had even half content than other big MMOs it would be one of the best if not the best MMO games out there. Right now this game will entertain you for about 100 hours but that's pretty much it. Yes, 100 hours is not a small number but for this genre it is. When developers add mounting after 2 years and it's not even a free addition you know something is not right. Despite everything I've written here I would still recommend this game because I've had really good 150-200 hours in this game with my friend, yes we could have more content and play this game for even more time but I'm still thankful for good times.

Game is ruled by company of scammers who thinks that their TOS is bigger then return/refund laws in your country.

I'm warning you to think twice before buying something in their marketplace.
If something happens during transaction, like game crash or their potato servers lag - you will lose money and buy nothing
(I got this problem twice!).

Support will NOT help you because there is a rule in their TOS - do not refund anything, 
even if it is because of problems on their side!
Also, if you ask about compensation using in-game currency they will ignore you.

What you might not like:
- 6 abilities on your bars total, 2 weapons, 3 abilities each. Every weapon only has 6 abilities to choose from. Snoozefest combat for the majority of the game. Pretty sure most bosses don't really have mechanics either.
- Weapon skilling and leveling up is abysmally slow. But hey, they sell boosts!
- The battle pass, for those juicy premium track boosters, is 25$
- You can only track 5 quests. Tracked quests appear bigger on your map. The game eventually floods you with quests and the map is riddled with points and things and pins and stuff that realistically make it really annoying to look for the smaller, untracked quests. Typical AAA UI Design. Btw most of the really distracting stuff on the map isn't relevant to you until high levels.
- 35$ mount DLC. It's like Oblivion horse armor but since they judge "learning to ride the mount" is worth about 30$, it evens out.
- A ton of budget into voice acting the most disconnected, irrelevant story in an RPG ever written.

What you might like:
- Graphics are okay, but if you look closely, you'll see why. Lots of "tricks."
- The audio's alright. At first you'll think "Wow, is that really what mining rocks sounds like?" and think it's cool, but it's a bug. The woodcutting sounds are really good though. You might get annoyed at how your character winges all the time. "HUARGH UARGH" non-stop.
- It's simple.

A solid game with an ease of entry for those coming from action RPGs with elements reminiscent of survival games. My only complaint is that there is no building system extant in the game. That aside, the combat is smooth, the gameplay engaging, and the story (unlike other MMOs) is actually worth following rather than skimming over. The voiced dialog is a nice touch, though not the first of it's kind. Implementing VoIP communication was a good idea too though I would like to see some polish on it, perhaps adding group and guild VoIP with a mute toggle. All in all a solid MMO and a fun game. It's still early days for me but I can see myself dropping another 1k hours into it over the next several months.

Former...and maybe future if there's ever a classic+.....WOW raider.  WOW had its time in my heart, but the meaningless cycles of borrowed power, pandering, boring "touchy feely" retconned story line, continued button bloat, overly complex class powers designs, and the fact that you literally require addons to have a chance to maximize dps rotations has made me feel like its a job just to keep one character up to end content viability.

I already have a job...and they pay me to do it I'm getting tired of paying blizzard to do what feels like un-fun work.

Enter New World...my brother talked good about it so I tried it out. It still has some bugs I'd expect from a newer released game not from one a few years old, but I'm enjoying my time. 

Adult, full time job, kids, so not as much time as I used to have but when I get on game there's lots to do and at present none of it seems boring, even fishing is fun and relaxing.....( come from a RL fishing family ). I often head out to do one thing then end up on a tangent because some run of materials was there for the taking, or a Lost town is nearby and I want to raid some chests for resources...sometimes I even end up doing the quest I set out to do, lol.

Anyway, will the fun last? Maybe. Will I eventually get bored? Possibly. Do I think Amazon should get rid of/ severely lower the monetization of certain fun and/or quality of life things ( I'm looking at you Gear Sets and mog tokens )? I do.

Do I think the money I've spent on the game and my Best buddy armored wolf mount were worth it? Yes, yes I do
